entry.title: Album Digest, September 2017
entry.content:
Note: Recent months have been very busy, so this album digest combines a review of the new album by The National with a couple of reviews left over from earlier in the year.

I‚Äôve written a few more album reviews in the past months but I‚Äôm so far behind (February and March have already been published on a considerable lag) that I‚Äôm just going to pepper forthcoming digests with additional reviews of older albums.

The National ‚ÄúSleep Well Beast‚Äù

The National are one of my favourite bands. Up until this album, they would release a great album every two years. However four years have passed since 2013‚Äôs ‚ÄúTrouble Will Find Me‚Äù. Not that you would know it from the opening pair of ‚ÄúNobody Else Will Be There‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Day I Die‚Äù. The first is a slow burner, creeping in like ‚ÄúTerrible Love‚Äù on ‚ÄúHigh Violet‚Äù but without that song‚Äôs eventual pyrotechnics. It‚Äôs a song about wanting to get to a party early so that you can leave the party early. It seems as though The National have aged in the same way I have. On the other hand, ‚ÄúThe Day I Die‚Äù is about as poppy as they‚Äôve ever deigned to be. It‚Äôs a simple and catchy song, and, as it it turns out, it‚Äôs a palette cleanser for the more experimental fare to follow.

‚ÄúWalk It Back‚Äù stretches three song fragments over six minutes. A twitchy riff and a detached vocal line (mostly just the title) dominate the opening minutes, before a spoken word and found footage collage takes over. The track closes with a beautiful instrumental interlude with another of The National‚Äôs highly underrated string arrangements. ‚ÄúWalk It Back‚Äù also manages to bleed into lead single ‚ÄúThe System Only Dreams In Total Darkness‚Äù without too much fuss. It‚Äôs a mid-tempo song that descends into squally guitar riffs, it sounds National-like but without being clich√©. You can say the same for ‚ÄúBorn To Beg‚Äù in which a languid vocal lolls over an insistent yet delicate beat but in keeping with their new sound, it also gets a bit fuzzy in the middle.

Next up is ‚ÄúTurtleneck‚Äù which is the most raucous song The National have produced since ‚ÄúMr November‚Äù1. That song was about the disillusionment the band felt at the re-election of George W. Bush in 2004. You can guess who this one‚Äôs about. It‚Äôs a song of bitter disappointment rather than anger, full of pithy lines about politicians.

Following this there are three more beat-driven tracks. ‚ÄúEmpire Line‚Äù is one of those songs that The National write effortlessly, a sort of cross between ‚ÄúGreen Gloves‚Äù and ‚ÄúFake Empire‚Äù. It even has a touch of auto tune. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Still Destroy You‚Äù is the best song on the album, with another drawn out ending like ‚ÄúWalk It Back‚Äù but this time with a clatter of drums and an epic string arrangement that somehow manages to cut through in between, like shafts of sunlight through clouds or overhead lights on the motorway. ‚ÄúGuilty Party‚Äù features perhaps the glitchiest musical backdrop and a lyric that reminds me of ‚ÄúPink Rabbits‚Äù from ‚ÄúTrouble Will Find Me‚Äù. It also reminds me of when I saw them live in 2007 and they did ‚ÄúAbout Today‚Äù (one my favourite songs ever), expanding it to over eight minutes with a crazy drummer jam at the end of the lyric. I love how The National‚Äôs amazing rhythm section makes tracks like these seem completely effortless.

Afterwards there are two slightly more straightforward songs, ‚ÄúCarin at the Liquor Store‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Dark Side of the Gym‚Äù. The former is another ‚ÄúPink Rabbits‚Äù style ballad full of self-deprecation and word games. The latter initially sounds a bit like the opening of ‚ÄúDark Side of the Moon‚Äù but it turns out that the title does indeed come out of the content of the lyrics - ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna keep you in love with me‚Ä¶ for a while‚Ä¶‚Äù. Once again, they deliver a completely new and modern kind of love song in the vein of ‚ÄúMistaken For Strangers‚Äù or ‚ÄúKaren‚Äù.

The last track is the title track, which for me is the only disappointment. Another twitchy track that resembles ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Still Destroy You‚Äù but doesn‚Äôt quite work for me. Perhaps it will given a bit more time. Tucked away as it is right at the end of the album, I haven‚Äôt given it too much consideration so far. At the moment, it just feels like a weird bonus track or remix. Nevertheless ‚ÄúSleep Well Beast‚Äù (the album) is well worth a listen and is full of songs that will sit well in any playlist of great songs by this band.

Nelly Furtado ‚ÄúThe Ride‚Äù

This new album from Nelly Furtado follows on from ‚ÄúThe Spirit Indestructible‚Äù and ‚ÄúMi Plan‚Äù, both of which I liked. I noted in my review of The Spirit Indestructible that it was all over the shop. The only version of it on Spotify now is the deluxe edition, a hot mess that confuses quantity for quality. Mi Plan was a nice tack back to ‚Äòproper‚Äô song writing but it wasn‚Äôt successful enough to warrant a sustained change of direction.

I am a big fan of Nelly Furtado and her music. I think that ‚ÄúWhoah Nelly!‚Äù and ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù are both really great albums, choosing the latter as an understated classic. Each album differs a little from the last so she seems to grow with each step. She‚Äôs also been judicious with her choice of collaborators. These have been distinctive enough for her to raise her game without overwhelming her identity. ‚ÄúThe Ride‚Äù is self-released and features no collaborators save for a new producer, John Congleton, who has worked on albums by St. Vincent and Goldfrapp among many others.

I first listened to ‚ÄúThe Ride‚Äù on headphones and hated it. The new production style is hostile to headphone listening. I found this a surprise because so much music is now geared toward headphone listening. Moreover, given that this album is meant to be a return to more personal song writing it seems silly to make it so awful to listen to on headphones. If you‚Äôre aiming for intimacy and feeling, why layer the songs in such gimmicky and prickly production?2

So the best thing about ‚ÄúThe Ride‚Äù (and it‚Äôs not much of a win) is that it doesn‚Äôt quite sound as awful out loud. However, the songs themselves indicate that this album may be one reinvention too many. If you want a Doctor Who reference - and who doesn‚Äôt? - this is her Colin Baker album. It has moments where the material transcends the presentation and it‚Äôs not so awful as to suggest that future incarnations will be as bad.

Take ‚ÄúCold Hard Truth‚Äù and ‚ÄúPipe Dreams‚Äù for example. These are objectively great songs. In fact the former wears the new production so well that maybe this was what convinced Nelly to run with it. It‚Äôs punchy and marries well with its subject matter. ‚ÄúPipe Dreams‚Äù echoes ‚ÄúExplode‚Äù from ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù, telling the story from an older, more jaded, angle. Again the production doesn‚Äôt wave around unnecessarily and there is also a wonderful spooky video to accompany the song on youtube.

The rest of the album is okay, provided you don‚Äôt listen on headphones. The trouble is that none of it is going to set the world alight. That‚Äôs a shame because she‚Äôs been brave enough to self-release an album that does experiment and innovate. The problem is that some experiments do end in failure. This is one of those. The big question is what happens next? I hope she carries on regardless: grows a little, changes a bit and keeps on singing.

Goldfrapp ‚ÄúSliver Eye‚Äù

From one album to another, Goldfrapp slalom between sleepy pastoral idylls and futuristic sexy techno pop. On ‚ÄúSilver Eye‚Äù they once again make this transition, opting for a noisy bravura sound following the gentle strings and croons of 2013‚Äôs ‚ÄúTales of Us‚Äù. I said of the last album:

‚Ä¶if ‚ÄúTales of Us‚Äù proves anything, it‚Äôs that there will be no nicer place for Goldfrapp to graze out their dotage than on the foothills of Felt Mountain.

Well as it happens there‚Äôs plenty more glitter balls and white horses in the band yet. Silver Eye is a mostly sparkly and stompy return to form. Unlike the last uptempo Goldfrapp album ‚ÄúHead First‚Äù which played things pretty straight, this album contains some songs that are downright peculiar and it‚Äôs all the better for it.

Lead single ‚ÄúAnymore‚Äù sticks to the template for Goldfrapp singles by songs like ‚ÄúNumber 1‚Äù and ‚ÄúOoh La La‚Äù, though there‚Äôs something squelchy low in the mix that gradually overtakes the song as it progresses. Joe Goddard‚Äôs remix on the 12‚Äù is even better, it‚Äôs very much the Dr. Hyde to the album version‚Äôs Mr. Jekyll. On the album, the de facto title track ‚ÄúSystemagic‚Äù also succumbs to this transformation, it‚Äôs a rollicking beast almost dripping with bass lines. It‚Äôs a fissile song, one that‚Äôs about ten seconds from corroding through your speakers. It‚Äôs also insanely catchy, which always helps.

‚ÄúTigerman‚Äù returns to ‚ÄúFelt Mountain‚Äù-type material, channelling ‚ÄúLovely Head‚Äù. It‚Äôs also got these weird whooshy bits that seem to throw themselves around your speakers and on headphones it produces a disorienting effect.

In a first for Goldfrapp, ‚ÄúBecome The One‚Äù is almost entirely spoken word. The lyric has a Laurie Andersen feel but also reminds me a little bit of ‚ÄúHappiness‚Äù and ‚ÄúClowns‚Äù from ‚ÄúThe Seventh Tree‚Äù. This might be another track that responds well to remixes. ‚ÄúFaux Suede Drifter‚Äù pulses and drifts for five minutes, a weird little torch song. I love the way it picks up just after the three minute mark, it‚Äôs very eighties - sounding a bit like the atmospheric bits of Whitney Houston‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Wanna Dance With You‚Äù.

‚ÄúZodiac Black‚Äù begins like a folk song, it could almost like a leftover from ‚ÄúTales of Us‚Äù or a song that would have sat well on JFDR‚Äôs ‚ÄúBrazil‚Äù in March. I really like the way that the atmospherics hiss behind the lyrics like misty moonlight. Unfortunately, while the song always feels like a moment of catharsis is coming, what ultimately arrives is disappointing. The song doesn‚Äôt really go anywhere. This seems to be a problem with the majority of the tracks on ‚ÄúSilver Tree‚Äù: they‚Äôre good but they don‚Äôt really amount to much. In the end songs like ‚ÄúMoon in Your Mouth‚Äù and ‚ÄúOcean‚Äù and the others already discussed sound like the more forgettable tracks that will be scraped for another greatest hits comp in a few years‚Äô time. I really wanted to like this album, but in the final analysis it‚Äôs good but not great.

  1. Mr November is the first song I ever heard by The National. I was in Moles nightclub in Bath and I even went up to the DJ to ask what the song was. I bought a copy of ‚ÄúAlligator‚Äù that weekend and was hooked.¬†↩

  2. The same approach was successful for St. Vincent on her self-titled album precisely because she was singing about the alienating experiences of our increasingly digital lifestyles.¬†↩

entry.title: Eric Schlosser, Command and Control
entry.content:
‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù by Eric Schlosser is about the history of nuclear weapons and their safety. This might not seem like a thrilling subject, but it‚Äôs absorbing from start to finish. I started it three years ago but only finished it more recently as the subject of nuclear weapons has become more pertinent to current affairs1. There are many people who would stand to gain a great deal from reading this book2.

Schlosser manages to make the subject so absorbing by weaving together the history of nuclear weapons, the history of nuclear weapon safety, and the tale of one particular event involving the explosion of a Titan II missile at a silo in Arkansas in 1980. By doing so, he gives the reasons why nuclear weapons were so often unsafe, he gives us examples of how things went wrong, and he shows how on that September day in Damascus, everything that could go wrong did go wrong. It‚Äôs a story that takes in an incredible range of characters. Some are well known to the reader, such as the various presidents of the USA, Nikita Khrushchev, Henry Kissinger, Jimmy Stewart (bizarrely) and so on. Others less well known include the scientists at the various laboratories, airmen, top brass at Strategic Air Command. The story also takes in locations all over the United States and around the world, such as Japan, Greenland, and Spain. There are mind-boggling stories of radar systems, advanced computers, and site R, the city-sized nuclear bunker built into Raven Rock mountain in Pennsylvania.

Throughout, despite telling some stories that could only be as strange as they are by virtue of being true, the tone remains measured. Schlosser does not resort to rhetoric and never allows the subject matter to overwhelm the writing. He tells the stories of ordinary airmen in a sympathetic and natural way. The complexity of the weapons is contrasted to the rote nature of the tasks of the maintenance men. He describes the absurdity of the situation with the missile in a detached manner, almost befitting of a sequel to Dr. Strangelove. The way Schlosser describes them, it‚Äôs hard not to become attached to the men caught at the scene in Damascus. The details of how supposed command and control instead becomes a game of Chinese whispers between men on walkie talkies talking to men on the radio who are talking on a conference call made me gasp. In the descriptions of historical incidents, it‚Äôs one face-palm incident after another. This quote sums up the scale of things:

The military now used Native American terminology to categorize nuclear weapon accidents. The loss, theft, or seizure of a weapon was an Empty Quiver. Damage to a weapon, without any harm to the public or risk of a detonation, was a Bent Spear. And an accident that caused the unauthorized launch or jettison of a weapon, a fire, an explosion, a release of radioactivity, or a full-scale detonation was a Broken Arrow. The official list of nuclear accidents, compiled by the Department of Defense and the AEC, included thirteen Broken Arrows. Bill Stevens read reports that secretly described a much larger number of unusual events with nuclear weapons. And a study of abnormal environments commissioned by Sandia soon found that at least 1,200 nuclear weapons had been involved in ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù incidents and accidents between 1950 and March 1968. (page 327)

I can also recommend the audio-book, as read by Scott Brick. This helped me get through it a bit faster. I‚Äôve been snooty about audio-books in the past, but I found it helped me stick to a schedule of reading chapters, usually to re-cap where I fell asleep listening to it at night. It was also good to listen to on the way to and from work in fifteen minute snippets. On one occasion I listened to a section about the US army, the US air force and the US navy all planning to bomb the same targets in Russia many times over. I don‚Äôt think anything else I‚Äôve listened to on the way to work has provided so much insight into how the council works!

Finally, I should also re-mention ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù. This is a tangent from ‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù. I wrote it about two years ago. This picks up on the nuclear protest movement, something that is almost absent from ‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù. Presumably it was assembled from material that didn‚Äôt make it into the original book. Like ‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù it‚Äôs able to discuss one issue as a subtext for another, highlighting an aspect of weapons safety more pertinent to current events: is it safe for nuclear weapons to be guarded by private contractors who were the lowest bidder? I recommend ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù again too, especially if a 632 page tome on nuclear weapons seems a little too much.

  1. Suffice to say that when I bought the book over three years ago, I would not have believed that it would be so much more relevant by the time I had finished it.¬†↩

  2. The name at the top of the list rhymes with Dump.¬†↩

entry.title: A little trip to Italy
entry.content:
We bought a cheap package holiday in the British Airways Black Friday sale. The weekend spanned Ingrid‚Äôs birthday, so it was ideal. ¬£99 each for flights and a hotel, and we bagged a hire car quite cheaply too.

Because our flight was from Heathrow and the trains from Chichester are both expensive and inconvenient for early flights, we spoiled ourselves with a taxi to the airport. It felt very strange to be whisked through the Sussex and Surrey countryside at six am on a Friday morning!

We picked up our little hire car. There were snow chains in the boot and we hoped we wouldn‚Äôt have to use them. Ingrid set to understanding the mind boggling experience of driving on the right hand side of the road. I set to understanding the mind boggling experience of navigating on the right hand side of the road. It took us three circuits to get out of the multistory car park. After that though, it was fine.

We pootled along the motorway from Milan to Bergamo, and then on to the little town just outside Bergamo where we would stay. We settled in to our room and went for an exploratory walk. We found a pizza place that catered to Ingrid‚Äôs allergy to both gluten and to tomatoes. Pizza bianca! (Literally, white pizza!) Just as well, because there was no way that I wasn‚Äôt going to eat pizza in Italy!

On the way home we stopped off at the Gelato shop. There were almost too many options but we managed!

The next day, our only full day, we set out to Lake Iseo in the car. We got to see lots of the countryside, stopping on the way to buy some lunch and more senza glutine products. The surrounding hills were beautiful and the lake itself was just gorgeous. We stopped off for lunch in Sarnico, a sleepy town next to the lake. We drank tea and coffee and played Lost Cities in a Phileas Fogg themed cafe.

After this we drove on to Iseo, parked the car, and went for a walk alongside the lake. It was cold (there had been a week of heavy snow prior to our arrival) but with the sun just low in the sky, it was the perfect light for taking photos.

The next morning we drove to a different airport, Malpensa, with Ingrid ever-increasing in confidence on the Italian motorways. We made good time and had plenty of time to return the car and have a good look around the airport. It was a brief visit but we really enjoyed it. We could have booked another hotel in Milan and stayed there for the weekend, which is what we might do next time.

entry.title: Understated Classics #35: Snivilisation by Orbital
entry.content:
I came late¬†to Orbital‚Äôs work. I knew of them through a few remixes and because as a mad Orb fan, they could not have avoided my notice could they? Apart from that, one of my college friends tried to get me into ‚ÄúIn Sides‚Äù just after its release in 1996. The same friend got me into ‚ÄúSecond Toughest In The Infants‚Äù by Underworld. I cannot now understand the reason, but ‚ÄúIn Sides‚Äù just left me cold.

‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù precedes ‚ÄúIn Sides‚Äù. Released in 1994, it is their third album. I got my hands on a copy about thirteen years later. Ten years ago, in 2007, I lived¬†in a house in Bath with my landlord. One day she leaned in to the doorway of my room, listening to the music I was playing. It was something by the Orb, or it might have been the Shamen‚Äôs ‚ÄúArbor Bona Arbor Mala‚Äù, and she said ‚Äúthe guy who used to live here liked music like that.‚Äù She explained that he left some of his CDs behind and that they were in the attic if I was interested.

Well dear reader, my reward for overcoming my immense fear of ladders was to find a stash of about 10 CDs of mid-90s dance and indie music in the attic, perched on one of the roof struts. Three of them were by Orbital (‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù, ‚ÄúIn Sides‚Äù and ‚ÄúTimes Fly‚Äù). I do not remember what the others were, probably stuff by the Chemical Brothers and some ropy compilations. Some of the other albums I already had, but two of the Orbital albums were new to me. I also took an interest in the Greatest Hits of the Stone Roses but the CD wouldn‚Äôt rip Óêì.

In retrospect, ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù is the sound of a band waiting to go mainstream: an inflection point where great tunes, command of their equipment and artistic vision all combine to produce a great album. It‚Äôs the sound of a band who had made great tunes (for example, Chime and Halcyon) putting all those elements together. For all the hair-raising catchiness of their early singles, their first two albums, both called ‚ÄúOrbital‚Äù but referred to by everyone as the green and brown albums, were rather scattershot affairs. By adding elements of rock music to an already heady mix of trance and techno, ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù sees Orbital taking a massive leap forwards.

Adding rock elements (i.e. samples of guitars) to dance music happened lots¬†in 1994. Six weeks before the release of ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù, The Prodigy released ‚ÄúMusic For The Jilted Generation‚Äù, an album that also incorporated rock samples on tracks like ‚ÄúVoodoo People‚Äù and ‚ÄúPoison‚Äù. The funny thing is I had a cassette copy of ‚ÄúJilted Generation‚Äù soon after its release, but never heard ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù at all. I remember hearing ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù in the charts but, even though I loved The Orb‚Äôs ‚ÄúBlue Room‚Äù, I thought it sounded thin. I found a copy of the single online while writing this review: how wrong I was! It goes to show how the choice of singles can make or break an album.

‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù is spiky and rude. In keeping with the time of its release it‚Äôs furious about the state of the world. The parallels between 1994 and 2017 are obvious: a country stagnating under a failing tory government and a right wing press stomping all those who oppose it into submission. The hot topic back then was the Criminal Justice Bill, which sought to prevent mass raves; something¬†the burgeoning dance music scene saw as an attempt to curtail artistic expression. As a result the album is as much an artefact of social history as it is one of electronic music.

One thing that drew me to ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù¬†in 2007 was¬†the way it explores the relationship between people and technology. The cover is a walkman distorted into a cartoon character shape over a banal grey background. The cover of the ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù single is Jesus wearing an old-school Virtual Reality helmet. Several of the tracks are collage pieces that overlay concerns about technology with old world concerns. On ‚ÄúI Wish I Had Duck Feet‚Äù, a carnival barker exhorts viewers to see his freak show while additional samples whisper about plastic surgery. Opener ‚ÄúForever‚Äù slices and dices a rant about the inequities and iniquities of capitalism in such a way it‚Äôs impossible to date the sample. Is the ranter talking about the 1990s and the 1960s, or the 1890s and the 1860s? I guess the point made is that it doesn‚Äôt matter. The excellent ‚ÄúPhilosophy by Numbers‚Äù riffs on the weird adverts you used to see for home-based learning in the early 90s. It sounds dated now though, what with the internet and everything.

‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù‚Äôs excellent first half uses the collage tracks to¬†augment¬†‚ÄùCrash and Carry‚Äù, a raucous techno number, and ‚ÄúSad But True‚Äù, which is one of two tracks that feature Alison Goldfrapp. Appearances on albums by Orbital and Tricky that paved the way for the success of Goldfrapp‚Äôs ‚ÄúFelt Mountain‚Äù. In 1994 she seemed to be on almost every half decent record.

The second half of ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù begins with ‚ÄúKlein Trink Wasser‚Äù which interweaves piano samples to form a wonderful meta-riff that feels like it‚Äôs dropped out of a 33 1/3 RPM recording of a Mozart piece played at 45RPM. Almost three minutes in the techno begins but the tune never shakes those pianos, which come rattling in whenever things sag. At points, check out the seesawing synth line that enters at 3:58, it sounds like early Kraftwerk, which might explain the title. Next up comes ‚ÄúQuality Seconds‚Äù, a two minute smash-and-grab that throws thrash metal shapes while also¬†sounding like a CD skipping. To finish, we get a fifteen minute version of ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù (more Alison Goldfrapp vocals) and the twelve and a half minute ‚ÄúAttached‚Äù. This third of the runtime contains the nucleus of the ideas and styles that Orbital explore in their subsequent albums.

The ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù single features four remixes of note, along with a version entitled ‚ÄúCriminal Justice Bill?‚Äù that is just four minutes of silence, and a radio edit. It is tempting to look at the single and its remixes as a prism splitting ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù (and by extension ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù) into other forms it could have taken. Of particular interest is ‚ÄúDo They Here?‚Äù, which crumples the track down into something metallic and industrial. I wrote at length about how rocky ‚ÄúSnivilisation‚Äù is but those elements don‚Äôt appear as often as I remember. The murky industrial funk of ‚ÄúDo They Here?‚Äù suggests a much darker version of the album could have been on the cards. I also find it interesting that the album version of ‚ÄúAre We Here?‚Äù contains sections of what might be called proto-Jungle, yet these loops are not significantly developed on any of the remixes.

‚ÄúAttached‚Äù floats, squelches and drifts along. On headphones, it has a strong presence, with a low synth line that pulses through most of the run time. When I played it to Ingrid through our TV the other day that same synth line seeped away and the whole track sounded different, floating somehow. I love music that changes like this and as a result, the soft throbs of ‚ÄúAttached‚Äù make it my favourite track.

Overall, I commend this album to your ears dear readers. It sounds both of its time and of any time. It makes time pass in unusual and interesting ways. Even now, ten years after I first heard it (and 23 years after I first should have heard it), I hear new things within it. I urge you to give it a go.

entry.title: Valleys
entry.content:
In my last post, I wrote about hills.¬†I tried to use¬†them as a metaphor to explain nagging sense of incompletion when you single out¬†one activity over another. The feeling that there‚Äôs always a more exciting hill off in the distance to go climb, instead of the one you‚Äôre¬†on.

I said my next post would be about how to pick between different options, particularly when you have many to choose from. This post is not that. This is a short piece about an experience I had in South America that relates to the hills post: about contentment in the moment and letting things go.

On the first day of the Inca Trail in Peru (December 2013) we marched along as a happy band. The foothills were easy to cope with and the weather was great. The course of antibiotics I‚Äôd started¬†back in Cuzco was¬†taking effect and I was feeling better than I had in weeks.

Mid-afternoon¬†we stopped for a while on a saddle in the hills. The pathway upward led us onward for the rest of the day‚Äôs walking, while down in the valley below, as our guide explained, there was another fascinating Inca ruin. He told us that the trail was so important to the Inca because it connected all these large settlements along the route. It was the beautiful remains¬†of a stone town, laid out as an archeological curiosity. I stood there wondering about who built it and what their lives must have been like. I thought about how far I was from London and how different my life was from the people who lived down there in that valley.¬†

It was a moment of clarity.¬†

What also dawned on me at this point was the knowledge that this was the closest I would¬†get to that town. I peered down and took a photo. Maybe two or three. Until then, I‚Äôd been very much ‚Äúsee all the things‚Äù, ‚Äúdo all the things‚Äù. I was Inca-mad. Until that day,¬†the realisation I wouldn‚Äôt see any more of the town would have saddened me. But there, looking down and reflecting as I was, it didn‚Äôt seem to matter. I didn‚Äôt need to hang on to the idea of going down to see it. There were other things to do, other hills to climb.¬†

So, this is not that promised insight into how to choose your battles, obsessions, reading material, or Netflix series. It‚Äôs just a moment where I was album to let go of that ‚Äúnext hill‚Äôs better‚Äù attitude and keep climbing the hill I was on. Sure, being part of a group meant I had no real say in the matter, but I could choose not to pout and throw myself into the next section of the walk. And¬†the funny thing is that I now remember that valley far more than I otherwise might have done.

Next up: rivers.

entry.title: Hills
entry.content:
I‚Äôm a big fan of books. The way they transport you away to other places and so on. As repositories of knowledge and adventure they can‚Äôt be beat. I can think of no better way out of an existential fix than reading.

The trouble is I tend to hoard them. I‚Äôve posted pictures of book stacks before (on more than one occasion). I could probably repeat that every month if I wanted to, perhaps even more often. I‚Äôve always been a networked thinker, able to see (at least superficially) the connections between all sorts of things. Because of this I get excited and enthusiastic about all kinds of things, and I want to learn them all.

My motto: learn all the things. If only I had some sort of heraldic crest below which those words could float on a trompe l‚Äôoeil fluttering scroll. I can picture it now: a Bear rampant on yellow and black quarters, above a scroll featuring the words omnia scire.

Of course the problem with always wanting to learn new things is that you might not learn anything. There‚Äôs always something better, newer and shinier over the hill. It‚Äôs a perverse kind of perfectionism: in wanting to be the best and know the most, you end up underestimating the work involved in what you want to learn. As part of my PhD I learned that sometimes there is no scenic route up to those hills and sometimes you have drudge on in order to get there.

That is less exciting. There isn‚Äôt much shiny or new-seeming about the word drudge. It‚Äôs boring. That‚Äôs partly why the ‚Äúnext‚Äù new thing seems so exciting by comparison. And this whole process doesn‚Äôt just manifest in fun things like learning programming languages or techniques for statistical inference, but also on the micro scale in the horrors of admin minutiae and email.

And just because I know something, it doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean I put that knowledge to use. We always remember the view and not the walk up the hill. Well apart from that time in the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, which is very much a memory of the climb thanks to a mini panic attack but that‚Äôs a whole other story. The point here is that knowing that the reality is boring and knowing how that boredom will probably deflect me on to attempting something else doesn‚Äôt really prevent it from happening. So what do you do? Well‚Ä¶

Do you want hear about something else that‚Äôs boring? The single most boring sentence in the whole English language? Ready? ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs make sure these are SMART objectives ok?‚Äù There are variations but pretty much any sentence that invokes the SMART acronym is a crime against sentences.

Well, not really. Despite the fact that I have to break up recalling what the acronym actually stands for into two sessions (divided by a quick espresso) in order to avoid falling into a sweet unproductive sleep, it is a pretty sensible set of guidelines for managing your expectations about any kind of goal, objective or project. It might be boring, but for the sake of your sanity it pays to be SMART.

That involves making sure that goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable‚Ä¶ (Sorry, hang on, I have to go and look this up‚Ä¶)

‚òï üí§ ‚òï ‚òï

‚Ä¶ Realistic and Time-bound. Of course, it‚Äôs hard to be SMART in bookshops when confronted with so many lovely books and the different ideas contained within them. Though I‚Äôm often a decent judge of which books should be read, this still leaves me with too many to read. That‚Äôll be the subject of my next post: how on Earth do I pick what needs to be done next?

entry.title: Wonder Woman: A Short Review
entry.content:
I enjoyed Wonder Woman, which came as a surprise to me given my growing distaste for superhero movies. I can remember seeing the Superman reboot Man of Steel with its phallic rockets and its boring boring fight sequences. But almost everything about Wonder Woman exceeded my expectations. It‚Äôs a well-made superhero movie and better still, it gets to the heart of why these kinds of movies matter.

Whereas Man of Steel ended up levelling cities and criminally underusing Amy Adams, all while giving us no stake on why Superman even matters as a man or a hero, Wonder Woman focusses tightly on its main character and explains what matters to her, and in turn the movie then explains why she should matter to us. In other words, it‚Äôs not boring and it‚Äôs not pointless.

This is a complete reverse on many recent superhero movies. In Christopher Nolan‚Äôs Batman movies, the titular character has an arc more concerned with vengeance and petty squabbles than with saving people or making their lives better. I get that those movies are also about the complexities and burdens of being a hero, but even so, show us why we‚Äôre here! Sure Batman gets to stop a lot of bad stuff going down, but who cares if the Scarecrow manages to take over Arkham or Bane manages to isolate Gotham from the world? In The Dark Knight, the Joker only cares about beating Batman and Batman only cares about beating the Joker. There‚Äôs nothing in three whole movies about how ordinary people are affected, nothing in it for us.

As a movie Wonder Woman concerns itself with showing how deeply invested Diana is in helping humanity. She understands her responsibilities toward humanity and thanks to some good old fashioned storytelling at the start of the movie, so do we. Her beliefs get challenged and we as an audience are often asked whether we believe in what is going on. Is she really fighting a god, or is she taking down some bad Germans? It‚Äôs good that you are kept guessing about this for quite a substantial portion of the film.

This is a movie that will get even the most stone-hearted among you behind Diana and willing her to win. Not just for her sake, but for the sake of all the characters we meet in the movie. To paraphrase one of the characters, it‚Äôs not about whether humanity deserves this intervention but whether Diana has enough love to make it happen anyway. Obviously that is something that resonates with my core beliefs. It‚Äôs refreshing to see a movie with values where you root for the main character because she‚Äôs believable and credible - even though she‚Äôs whipping around a lasso made of glow sticks and dodging oncoming machine gun fire. You will leave the movie wanting to believe that she exists!

You can also leave the movie believing in something more plausible: that the message of responsibility and the call to action can live within you. Diana, in her gilded secret paradise, chooses to leave in order to fight. You don‚Äôt have to do that, but you can act to help people around you. You can opt to not ignore what is going on in the world around you, and you can choose to shape the world rather than be shaped by it. You will note that I have not mentioned the power of all this being embodied in a female character, but you can be sure that this movie will make girls and young women believe in themselves more than any other superhero movie in quite a while.

Sure, it is a smidge too long and the final fight between Diana and the big baddie is as unsatisfying as special effects laden battles often are. Nevertheless, I‚Äôm glad I managed to catch Wonder Woman while it was still on and I really recommend it.

entry.title: Create
entry.content:
It can be a struggle to keep writing. I‚Äôve found this happened a lot since I moved the blog. First, there was the business of moving things over. That meant a lot of thought about old posts and which ones I should keep. A lot of the time I thought ‚Äúhow on earth did I have time to write this?!‚Äù

Then there seemed to be a lot more barriers to writing than previously. We can say what we like about the machinery that WordPress runs on, it does make it easy to write regularly. It also provides a lot of tools for making writing fun and for learning things as you go. I still have access to those things but it‚Äôs a little different now.

And of course, with it coming up for a year of living with Ingrid it just so happens that my creative outlets are a little different now. Our creative outlets. And they haven‚Äôt changed that much anyway. We cook. We visit places. We talk about culture and politics. It just seems more fun to do than to reflect. As I said, a different form of creativity.

And then it also goes without saying that the world continues apace, producing all sorts of interesting, strange, and terrible happenings. Things that I don‚Äôt feel that confident writing about. It can be quite hard to put a pin in it and not write about certain events. I know I‚Äôm not qualified to offer opinions on most things, but one of the reasons that I write is to understand what‚Äôs going on in and around me.

Of course, I managed to write about the election. I guess that story came to me and it felt right to tell it. But there‚Äôs lots of other stuff that I need to get around to. About work. About life. About music. About computers. All kinds of stuff. I feel like it will all tumble out eventually: this is just the start. It‚Äôs very exciting, even if a little daunting.

Of course, creativity manifests itself in many ways. Even if you do something like the dishes in new way that can be fun can‚Äôt it? And as for all the rest, I will try to write more and I will try to do more that is worthy of report. Work and my MSc have felt like a bit of a grind at times but I‚Äôm now resolved to trying to inject a bit of fun and creativity in there too.

entry.title: Tomorrow
entry.content:
I want to tell you about something that I saw while doing my paper round on election day in 1997. Even though I was at college by then, I helped my sister out when she couldn‚Äôt do it. Something like that. I was 17 and just off voting age. I had no real interest in politics at all.

All I‚Äôd known that people had been happy when Thatcher resigned a few years earlier. The morning she went the vicar from our village was speaking in our school assembly and the headmaster rushed in to share the news. All the teachers started cheering and clapping, and we, as exuberant schoolchildren, all joined in too.

I grew up in Emsworth. It‚Äôs a lovely place and really conservative. But something was clearly wrong with the country if vicars and teachers in dyed-in-the-wool conservative shires were cheering the resignation the prime minister. Thatcher‚Äôs government had become nasty and vindictive. It did not stand for Britishness or the British values. It stood for naked greed and everyone was sick of it.

I feel like that now with the present government. I know that there are potential Conservative-type governments that I could vote for. But not this one. Again it sits in the corridors of power, concerned only with materialistic greed - using the fear of the unknown to set neighbours and families against one another. It has a famine mentality that sucks away the hope from this potentially great country.

Back to 1997. On that election day an old man in Victoria road in Emsworth stood at his garden gate handing cups of tea to strangers. He had a big ‚ÄúVote Labour‚Äù sign strapped to his fence and he beamed big smiles at every passer-by. As I nursed my tea, he asked if I was voting. I said that I couldn‚Äôt. I said that my mum was worried about a Labour government and that I didn‚Äôt think it mattered.

Are you rich then? Is your mum rich? He said and he looked down at my bike, my shoes, and he knew that we weren‚Äôt.

I blushed and said no. I grew up as almost the poorest kid in my peer group. Happy. Clever. But pretty poor. And he said, well she doesn‚Äôt have anything to worry about then. I said that I hoped so, handed back the mug and got on with my round.

What struck me that day was the excitement of that man, how politics actually meant something to him. Even today, I marvel at the optimism of someone who was voting in a totally safe tory seat and yet still campaigning. I realised that I would soon be old enough to vote and that I would also have to think about what mattered. I decided I would follow things with interest.

I would learn later that this was not the first act of genorosity toward my family by a member of the Labour movement. The house I grew up in came to us via a Labour councillor, who swapped her two bedroom house for my parents‚Äô tiny flat in ‚Ä¶ you guessed it ‚Ä¶ Victoria road.

And now, on the eve of another election, I think of those people who changed and shaped my life - my family, my teachers, the crazy vicar who got arrested protesting the poll tax, that old man with his cups of tea, the councillor who helped my parents find their house, my house. I am as excited by tomorrow as that man was back in 1997.

To me, Jeremy Corbyn speaks to those values of generosity and solidarity in the same way. I‚Äôm pretty certain that he won‚Äôt be our next prime minister - but by God I‚Äôd be so proud to be British if he were. And I‚Äôll be handing out cups of tea to passers-by for a MONTH.

entry.title: Changes
entry.content:
Moving the blog to Jekyll (again, sort of)

Et voila, my blog lives! In a new body (Jekyll) and at a new location.

The Process

I set up Jekyll on my MacBook Air after loads of initial problems with installing the theme and getting assorted Ruby gems installed and working. Stack Overflow is a friend for life now. By way of comparison, getting things up and running on my new Mac was simple.

I converted ‚Äúall‚Äù my posts to markdown using a PHP script and my WordPress export file. Except for 90 or so posts that don‚Äôt get converted for some reason. I had to create posts for those by hand and paste the content in from Wordpress.

As part of this process I set up the sublimejekyll plugin on Sublime Text and that also took ages because‚Ä¶ well I still don‚Äôt know why. I did uncover the following pro tip though: if a program says it can‚Äôt find a directory, it probably means that said directory really isn‚Äôt there. Make the damn directory.

As I made the posts compatible for Jekyll I decided to delete a few older posts. Most were short and don‚Äôt add much to the overall flow of the blog. Image only posts never really added much. Besides I have Instagram for that kind of thing.

I downloaded all the images from the old version of the site: all 36,000 and 2.7Gb of them. Wordpress had created at least 18 copies of each image at different sizes. Oh dear. That resize image thumbnails plugin seemed like such a good idea at the time.

I deleted all the unnecessary images. I wish I could say I used some clever command line fu to get this done. I didn‚Äôt. I just used the innately useful keyboard shortcuts in MacOS.

Then I realised that some posts before 2013 had images from a single folder elsewhere within my Wordpress install. This meant I had another 200 images to track down. In the end I used very few of these images but I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt overlook them.

As I went through the posts every image asset got classified into hero / gallery / other. I used Automator to create small teaser versions of the hero images. In some places I‚Äôve just used the larger hero images. This is not very efficient but was necessary for getting the site up and running.

Then I have to go through each of the posts that I want to keep, changing the image references and setting the header and teaser images. The internal links all had to change too - and be warned that some of them may not have changed yet. (At heart I am very lazy.) I‚Äôve learned a lot more about Sublime Text as part of this process.

I‚Äôve not yet managed to sort out related posts for each post. The default Jekyll method is to use latent semantic indexing or lsi but for all my posts this takes an incredibly long time: about until the heat death of the known universe. It‚Äôs not that practical. Apparently there is a related posts plug-in that only uses tags (but I deleted all my tags because I thought they were what was slowing down lsi). Fixing this is very much on the to do list. Of course at this point I don‚Äôt have much idea of how to track down internal links that may have died in the transition: always listen to your regex teachers when you are in school kids.

2017 New Year‚Äôs Resolution: learn to regex.

Yes, it really is that that important!

The really geeky stuff

At this point I should confess that I‚Äôve used Jekyll before but because I was on shared hosting I had no ssh access to the server. This meant that I had to FTP over the whole caboodle every time that I ran Jekyll. However I‚Äôve fixed that side of things this time around. With the help of the rsync command I can deploy the site very quickly, only uploading the changes since last time. Compared to FTP it feels like magic.

The site is now hosted on a Digital Ocean droplet and has a new domain name. There‚Äôs an A+ rated security certificate and everything. My blog got hacked on shared hosting, though it may have been the fault of WordPress rather than most. Even so, with Jekyll there‚Äôs no database to infest with gribblies. My hope that this means I will avoid emailing myself a post shilling Christian Laboutin shoes1.

Assessing the performance of the new site using tools like Pingdom shows that there are still some optimisations to be made. However there are already a few little bells and whistles trilling away. If you add the site to the home screen of your phone or tablet, you should see my little logo. I can‚Äôt test it but it should also work with Windows 10 devices too.

There‚Äôs also a little Google analytics tracker. This is not a permanent feature. I don‚Äôt intend to spy on my readers. It is there for the first few months to check the level of traffic to the site. I‚Äôve not got wild expectations. I doubt I will even get the same numbers as I had for the WordPress version of the site.

What‚Äôs changed?

With my hosting solution change in mind, I decided that it would be better for there to be fewer images on the site. I still have backups of old posts so I can add some back at a later stage.

I‚Äôve cut the number of posts from just over 600 down to just under 240. I kept all the series like the understated classics and my posts about South America. Most of the book reviews remain. I jettisoned most of the pouting about my job and my life prior to going to South America, but some of it remains. Generally if a post changed my way of writing, I‚Äôve kept it.

Our memories of the past aren‚Äôt set in stone. The internet has an awkward way of setting things in amber. Forgive me for favouring the plasticity of thought over the precision of tapes and drives. If you want to hold me to account for my terrible writing, that‚Äôs what the wayback machine is for.

Another thing motivates the choice of posts retained from the old version of the blog. I want to get back to writing longer posts. Sometimes I used posts comprising mostly pictures as a way of churning out lots of posts, without really thinking about why I was writing them. I want to put a bit more thought in to writing. It would be nice if my posts were a reflection on my skills and passions, rather than mindless vanities or quick emotive responses to flash in the pan events.

Finally, I must thank Frank Hecker. His blog also uses Jekyll and the minimal mistakes theme. When I emailed him about how he set up his blog, he replied at length with many suggestions that were invaluable in getting things up and running. Also the documentation of minimal mistakes was incredibly good, to the extent that it‚Äôs given me lots of ideas about what to put into posts. Like the table of contents. How cool is that?

I wish I could say that I‚Äôve written lots of posts in the past six months and that they are all ready to go. Unfortunately the niggling details of the relocation process absorbed more of my time. Well, that and the release of Civilization VI. Fortunately the act of looking over my previous efforts gives me a few clues as to where I want to go. I hope you will join me.

  1. Note that there is no email subscription available for this version of the site. Yet. Expect massive fanfare when there is. You can follow @notmattischrome on twitter for links to updates in the meantime.¬†↩

entry.title: Album Digest, March 2017
entry.content:
Blanck Mass World Eater

This album is pretty extreme. It‚Äôs not for everyone and even for the people who can handle it, it‚Äôs not for all the time. This album is a soul crushing experience at points but there are also points of light. Perhaps this makes ‚ÄúWorld Eater‚Äù more reflective of life as a whole than any other of this month‚Äôs albums. On balance it‚Äôs probably less crushing than the last Blanck Mass album ‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù, which I reviewed back in June 2015.

World Eater begins with ‚ÄúJon Doe‚Äôs Carnival of Error‚Äù, a woozy fairground instrumental reminiscent of Orbital‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Wish I Had Duck Feet‚Äù from ‚ÄúSnivilization‚Äù (an upcoming understated classic). Just as that weird buttery instrumental gets going we lurch into ‚ÄúRhesus Negative‚Äù, which for me is probably the most extreme track I will hear all year. I certainly don‚Äôt want to hear anything more extreme! It‚Äôs just at the edge of what I can tolerate: about five different tracks all bundled into one and crash impacted against the nearest hard surface for nine minutes. It is not a track that will calm your anxiety. However, if you‚Äôre in the mood for it it‚Äôs a powerful track: one for your weekly primal scream therapy session.

If ‚ÄúRhesus Negative‚Äù is primal scream therapy, then the tracks that follow after are probably some sort of evil yoga. It‚Äôs pretty much the devil‚Äôs own mixtape and, as we know, the devil has all the best tunes. ‚ÄúPlease‚Äù hangs on a vocal sample that sounds ripped from some classic summery house record from the early nineties, but it‚Äôs repeated over and over so much that it becomes a plea. All the while beats are smeared all over the please. It‚Äôs not as tough as the previous track but it‚Äôs still deeply unsettling.

‚ÄúThe Rat‚Äù is the most upbeat track - a stellar synth propelled by a demented bass line that sounds like a demonic remix of the Doctor Who theme. Like the other tracks, it‚Äôs weird and disturbing, particularly as elements of the mix are thrown around the stereo image towards the end. ‚ÄúSilent Treatment‚Äù is built around what sound like choral samples and the whole track sounds like a hyper-accelerated rush of adrenaline, pretty much what I imagine falling into a black hole might sound like. A rush of beats pushes down and compacts you, though when the vocal kicks in at about two minutes it briefly calms down. It‚Äôs mellow but only by the standards of this album: I don‚Äôt think it will be on your gym playlist any time soon.

The intriguingly-titled ‚ÄúMinnesota / Eas Fors / Naked‚Äù begins with some unsettling and bewitching noises that might be running water, radio static or something else entirely. Probably all three. There‚Äôs something deeply compelling about the twitchiness of it. At four minutes it almost settles into a melody but strange spoken word overlays also appear just at the edge of your hearing. It‚Äôs almost like the point where you go under before an operation. By about six minutes I‚Äôm convinced I‚Äôm listening to a drawn out transformation of the opening minutes. At this point there is a melody and it feels like the whole track is pulled out and stretched over itself but backwards in time.

The niftiest trick of all is when the end (beginning?) of ‚ÄúMinnesota / Eas Fors / Naked‚Äù lurches into the staticky beats of ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù. This is the most accessible track on the album and it even has discernible lyrics. If I were you, I wouldn‚Äôt listen to those lyrics to closely‚Ä¶ especially if they‚Äôre saying what I think they‚Äôre saying. Maybe the whole album is a kind of musical Rorschach Test designed to make you see rats, bats and other assorted monsters.

‚ÄúWorld Eater‚Äù is not for everyone. When I listen to it I think it‚Äôs not really for me most of the time either. However, when you‚Äôre in the mood for it this album is utterly compelling - just as ‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù was.

The Shins Heartworms

This is a reasonable collection of new songs from The Shins. It‚Äôs been awhile but ‚Äúthey‚Äù are back - but really it‚Äôs just James Mercer now. This makes it rather tempting to read all the songs as autobiographical. I imagine songs like ‚ÄúMildenhall‚Äù actually are, which adds an extra layer of earnestness to them. The Shins‚Äô best songs though have always retained a bit of mystery, which is why the fun of ‚ÄúHalf a Million‚Äù and the layered vocals of the title track are more welcome.

Sure, there are some wiggly bits borrowed from his work with Danger Mouse on the Broken Bells albums. Those sounds - like the filtered vocals of ‚ÄúPainting a Hole‚Äù and the squelches on ‚ÄúCherry Hearts‚Äù and the aforementioned ‚ÄúHalf a million‚Äù - were also present on ‚ÄúWincing the Night Away‚Äù and ‚ÄúPort of Morrow‚Äù. To summarise, there‚Äôs plenty to enjoy if you like those other Shins albums but maybe there‚Äôs not the same magic as way back on ‚ÄúChutes Too Narrow‚Äù.

Rolling Blackouts CF The French Press

The full name of this band is Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever. I like to think that their name, like a Mexican surname or an Edwardian football club, is simply that of some previous band names strung together. I heard them on the radio on our drive down to Cornwall and so I paid more attention when they popped up on my Discover Weekly as well. They‚Äôre from Melbourne, Australia (like many great people üòâ) and are similar to The Strokes in their pomp, at least to my naive ears on a first listen. ‚ÄúThe French Press‚Äù is an EP but as it‚Äôs almost as long as another of this month‚Äôs albums, I thought I‚Äôd give it a little review.

In fact this EP mixes and matches a lot of other bands that I like. The title track blends The Strokes with the artier janglings of their successors like Parquet Courts. ‚ÄúJulie‚Äôs Place‚Äù sounds like a mellower Oasis (but not shitty mellow like ‚ÄúGas Panic‚Äù) and ‚ÄúSick Bug‚Äù emulates the Pixies convincingly. To my surprise things even take an antipodean turn on ‚ÄúDig Up‚Äù where they manage to sound a bit like Crowded House.

The songs as a whole are pleasant and jangly. Playing spot the reference is quite fun. The lyrics don‚Äôt really go anywhere too deep, though I do like the title track‚Äôs pleas for clear communication under surveillance. It could be a relationship metaphor but I wasn‚Äôt sure if any deeper meaning was intended. The lyrics to ‚ÄúSick Bug‚Äù are probably the closest to making sense: that age old subject matter of wanting to get horizontal with someone in their bedroom.

Give this a spin if you like jangly guitar pop playing in the background while you work. It‚Äôs not going to start a revolution but it‚Äôll help you feel cool. It‚Äôll sound great at that artisan coffee shop you hang out at. Vive le French Press!

JFDR Brazil

Like many albums in the digest these days, ‚ÄúBrazil‚Äù came to my attention via a song in my Discover Weekly playlist on Spotify. In this case it was the arresting song ‚ÄúInstant Patience‚Äù. Clocking in at just under five minutes, breathy Bjork-like vocals are arranged over a delicate synth line. The first time I heard it I was listening to Discover Weekly in bed and almost asleep - this song almost made sit bolt upright. In the dark it sounded like a spooky moment of instant clarity.

JFDR is the professional name of J√≥fr√≠√∞ur √Åkad√≥ttir, an Icelandic singer who records most of her music with her twin sister in a band called Pasqual Pinon. ‚ÄúBrazil‚Äù is her first solo album. It‚Äôs so good that I‚Äôm confident that it won‚Äôt be her last.

What I so much about the album is the way that it slowly builds up over 9 songs and 35 minutes. (Regular readers will also know how much I love short albums.) ‚ÄúWhite Sun‚Äù is a beautiful simple folk song borne on a plaintive vocal. The melody slaloms around for a few minutes gradually accreting synth noises. Each track repeats this process to some degree, with each song becoming more complicated as the album progress.

The second song ‚ÄúAnew‚Äù piles on overdubbed vocal harmonies to a simple guitar line. Imagine Elliott Smith crossed with Bjork! I did, and I was hooked. ‚ÄúInstant Patience‚Äù iterates the formula but often cuts away those same vocal harmonies, creating the sense of space that makes the song so spooky and appealing.

‚ÄúWires‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAirborne‚Äù later on, play with drum arrangements. Until ‚ÄúWires‚Äù there‚Äôs barely any percussion at all, save for some cymbals that rush up into the mix at the end of ‚ÄúAnew‚Äù. ‚ÄúWires‚Äù throbs with intent under that same detached cool voice but completely cuts away halfway through, almost like discovering a sunny clearing in a dark forest.

‚ÄúHigher State‚Äù is a piano ballad punctuated by strange rushes of noise. ‚ÄúAnything Goes‚Äù is similarly delicate. Things pick up again with ‚ÄúAirborne‚Äù which introduces skittering drums with a vague drum‚Äôn‚Äôbass feel. Yet even with the pace of the drums, the song still has a languid air in keeping with the rest of the album.

The last two songs keep up the sonic experiments with ever busier arrangements. ‚ÄúDestiny‚Äôs Upon Us‚Äù even has an electric guitar sulking in the background and there‚Äôs a weird 8 bit synth noise that‚Äôs most likely off that 1980‚Äôs Casio keyboard your mate owned. And yet JFDR‚Äôs voice is never overwhelmed by these arrangements, always striking out clear over them. Part of that might be the preparation from earlier tracks, and part of it an otherworldly voice as able to command a noisy backdrop as an entirely silent one. The final song ‚ÄúJourney‚Äù is so much a complete song that it feels the whole album has built up to it. A folky ballad with lilting guitar and sparky synths behind it.

I really like this album. It‚Äôs short and coherent. It builds to its ending but each individual song stands alone despite being a component of a larger whole. I‚Äôd love to hear remixers get to grips with some of them. It also goes without saying that I‚Äôll be researching the Pasqual Pinon albums. I‚Äôll also be looking forward keenly to new songs from JFDR.

entry.title: Album Digest, February 2017
entry.content:
Grails Chalice Hymnal

Some albums are good because a band continues making the music that you love. Some albums are good because a band takes their ideas a step or two further than before. Chalice Hymnalis that rare album that does both of these things.

The references to past albums include the track Deeper Politics and Deep Snow II, and, as per albums past, these tracks evolve slowly out of languid guitar hooks and smoky atmospherics. If it ain‚Äôt broke don‚Äôt fix it.

However Grails are also a restless band as well as a restful one. The sheer number of side acts that members of the band are involved with, including Watter and Lilacs & Champagne, are testimony to that. As a result there‚Äôs also some revolution mixed in with the revolution here.

Take Tough Guy for instance. The Lilacs & Champagne project grew out of repurposing Grails tracks as instrumental hip hop. This track feeds that process back in the other direction with a swinging swagger that keeps the track in motion. As the title suggests it‚Äôs more robust than your average Grails tune.

Pelham is a noise-fest reminiscent of bands like Russian Circles. The slightly-too-long closing track After the Funeral is a reminder that while this band once named one of their albums Doommonger‚Äôs Holiday, their tongues may not have been firmly in their cheeks.

My favourite track is called Rebecca. It‚Äôs a beautiful and folky tune, the sort of thing that Grails seem able to dash off without even thinking about it. Its seemingly improvised nature gives it an emotional heft, after all it‚Äôs often more meaningful when we express emotion without intention, when we don‚Äôt even have to think about it.

To conclude this is another interesting and compelling album from Grails. It would serve as a good introduction if you‚Äôve never heard their music before. If you have heard them before then you‚Äôll know what to expect and I think you will like what you find.

Elbow Little Fictions

Guy Garvey could sing the ingredients of a can of tomato soup and make you cry. That said, it‚Äôs felt like more recent Elbow albums lost their way. They became a bit too narrative: it became possible to map stories about his personal life on to the songs. ‚ÄúBuild a rocket boys!‚Äù seemed preoccupied with serious subject matter. Perhaps they felt that serious statement songs were needed once everyone started playing ‚ÄúOne Day Like This‚Äù at their weddings. Meanwhile, ‚ÄúThe Takeoff And Landing of Everything‚Äù made the mistake of thinking that tales of transatlantic living were somehow interesting to those of us who got caught up in the original camp fire glow of songs like ‚ÄúRed‚Äù and ‚ÄúAny Day Now‚Äù.

There‚Äôs no doubt in my mind that both albums have redeeming songs. But the thing that made both ‚ÄúThe Seldom Seen Kid‚Äù and ‚ÄúAsleep in the Back‚Äù so darn irresistible is that they were each a knockout run of eleven great songs from start to finish. For elbow there‚Äôs very little elbow room these days: the bar is set high, beyond the reach of many other bands. I‚Äôd started to wonder if they were out of reach of themselves.

The great news is that ‚ÄúLittle Fictions‚Äù is another fantastic album. It‚Äôs knotty and tricksy, perhaps more in keeping with ‚ÄúCast of Thousands‚Äù or ‚ÄúLeaders of the Free World‚Äù. The title refers to how they have returned to writing about characters and the details of their invented lives. Some bands need to tell you how it is, Elbow will more often break your heart with modern fairy tales.

Dreadzone Dread Times

As regular readers will know, I‚Äôm a big fan of Dreadzone‚Äôs Second Light. As I discussed in my review of Grails‚Äô new album above, sometimes the hardest thing is for a beloved band to give you new material that doesn‚Äôt slavishly depend on the past. Dread Times might be thought of as a jukebox album, taking elements of past Dreadzone albums to produce new tracks that recombine and remix those elements. As with the Grails album, it‚Äôs an evolution rather than a revolution.

There‚Äôs much to like on Dread Times, which inverts a the band‚Äôs usual trick of peppering techno tracks with trad reggae. This time the approach is more song-based. While this means that the samples are not quite as extensive or clever (there‚Äôs little of the mood building of Second Light or Earth Radio here), but it does mean that there‚Äôs a bit more to hang onto. Other Dreadzone albums have been song-based but Dread Times is one of their more successful.

There‚Äôs Rootsman, which gets things off to a garrulling start - especially with its ‚Äúall of the youth‚Äú chorus. Mountain mixes Tricky-like rapping with can-do positive messages, a combination that sounds better through speakers than it does as typed out text. 16 Hole makes a plea for an end to gun violence and does so with an ear worm for a chorus: the best advice is catchy advice.

Area Code is a hyper-kinetic party song that is all over my playlists. It has the best reference to the rings of Saturn in any album this month, or most months come to think of it. It‚Äôs a belter of a song that really gets you up and running.

The album tails off with Where is my Friend?, a near-acoustic song about a missing DJ. It‚Äôs touching and demonstrates that for all Dreadzone‚Äôs occasional over-production they do know their way with a good tune and how to leave it alone. The last track After the Storm echoes Out of Heaven off Second Light, perhaps even making a cheeky nod to the YouTube video that set Out of Heaven to the tornado scene from Wizard of Oz (Needless to say, that video is not up on YouTube anymore.). After the Storm is slightly more upbeat and is a nice salve for those hankering for the other side of Dreadzone throughout.

It‚Äôs good that Dreadzone have kept going and also nice that they‚Äôve been rewarded with their highest chart placing for many a year. Long may it continue!

entry.title: Album Digest, January 2017
entry.content:
Mike Oldfield Return to Ommadawn

With Return to Ommadawn, Mike Oldfield revisits his third album Ommadawn. He has past form for this, having revisited his masterwork Tubular Bells twice (the third revisit and fourth instalment Tubular Bells 4 is due next year). I wrote about Tubular Bells II for my understated classics series. Of course Mike has in fact made many more than three Tubular Bells albums1, and this is not a first ‚Äúreturn‚Äù to Ommadawn. His 1990 album Amorok was a similar affair.

It‚Äôs important to mention Amorok as it makes for an interesting comparison to this new album. While recording Amorok Mike was disenchanted with making music or at least the political side of it. At that time, Virgin Records didn‚Äôt even bother to promote his records. It‚Äôs telling that one of the bigger rarities of the Oldfield canon is a promo cassette containing three extracts from Amorok that was sent to readers of the WHSmith magazine.

The trouble with Amorok is that it also distilled the worst of Mike Oldfield‚Äôs music at that time. It‚Äôs slipshod in places, relies on jokes that aren‚Äôt funny and continues with half baked ideas for longer than necessary. In places Amorok seems to say ‚Äúwill this do?‚Äù and ‚Äúhow about this?‚Äù It‚Äôs an album that gurns more than it smiles, and is worse for it. It‚Äôs not helped by being a single hour-long track or that the cover art defensively excoriates ‚Äúcloth eared nincompoops‚Äù before you even hear it. For all the prettiness and invention of long passages of Amorok, it did not do much to enhance the memory of the original Ommadawn. Hostility towards editing usually means that you need an editor.

It is good that Amorok doesn‚Äôt get to settle the legacy of ‚ÄúOmmadawn‚Äù. The original album, released in 1975, is the one that settled whether Mike was a one hit wonder or not. Tubular Bells sold by the bucket load and so Hergest Ridge, a quickly-composed follow-up that replaced catchy themes with anger and bluster. Ommadawn was intended as a counter to this. Mike took his time to compose it and made sure to incorporate themes that were important to him. Chief among them are the Celtic instruments that appear throughout the album.

Until composing Ommadawn, Oldfield had been writing under pressure since demoing the first half of part one of Tubular Bells to Richard Brandon. Writing the remainder of Tubular Bells and the entirety of Hergest Ridge at pace did yield some successful moments: the instrument roll call at the end of Part one of Tubular Bells, the sleepy sunny intros to part two of Tubular Bells and part one of Hergest Ridge. However, the miraculous sunrise intro to Ommadawn is something else entirely. I think it should be regarded as highly as those opening lines of Tubular Bells.

The rest of Ommadawn works when it doesn‚Äôt try too hard. It revels in its oddness, something that Oldfield learned to do as the monster success of his debut began to grate with previously supportive critics. Oldfield‚Äôs contributions are virtuoso throughout, though long passages find him hiding behind his collaborators. These sections are uneven and the whole piece ends up tripped over into silliness by the last four minutes of Part Two. Some track listings represent this section as a single track called ‚ÄúOn Horseback‚Äù. It‚Äôs a song about a man who‚Äôd rather be on horseback. Unfortunately it also features a children‚Äôs choir and makes Clive Dunn‚Äôs much-maligned Grandad sound like black metal.

Return to Ommadawn differs from Tubular Bells II. It‚Äôs not a ‚Äúshot for shot remake‚Äù and the technology is placed firmly behind the speakers rather than through them. The liner notes say little, save to point out that no synthesisers appear on the record2. What we get as listeners is a thorough exploration of all Ommadawn‚Äôs themes filtered through a lifetime of experience. It took a while to convince me but after a few listens it is in fact rather marvellous.

Perhaps the most important feature is just how sensitive it is. There are phrases and sections that make me shiver. Other parts will make you think of rain drops tracking their way down window panes. Others are strong and bold and confident, all shiny with winter sunshine. It‚Äôs a beautiful melancholic experience with a radiant happy ending. ‚ÄúOn Horseback‚Äù gets transformed into sampled pulp (see earlier footnote) and apparently the only original vocal contribution to the album is for Mike to say ‚ÄúOn Horseback? I‚Äôd rather be here!‚Äù. Of course mate, you live in the Bahamas now.

This is probably Mike‚Äôs best album since Tubular Bells III. It has that album‚Äôs sense of exploration, the sensitivity of ‚ÄúThe Songs of Distant Earth‚Äù3 and a self-restraint lacking from the likes of ‚ÄúVoyager‚Äù and ‚ÄúAmorok‚Äù. It bodes well for Tubular Bells 4, but those reissues of ‚ÄúIslands‚Äù and ‚ÄúEarth Moving‚Äù (also coming this year?) will look a little jaded by comparison.

Bonobo Migration

When I decided to review Migration I worried that I might repeat my review of The North Borders from a few years back. On a first, loose, listen it doesn‚Äôt sound like a lot has changed. In fact the opening bars of ‚ÄúMigration‚Äù sound a bit like the music Apple uses to soundtrack your Photos memories. It‚Äôs still soulful tasteful dance music that you tend to nod to rather than dance to. Because I listen to a lot of music and to my ears Migration sounds like other Bonobo records more than anything else, it‚Äôs hard to hear (at first) whether it‚Äôs any sort of step forward from The North Borders. That is to say, why should you pick this record over any of his other records?

However, I found that when I listened repeatedly and deliberately to Migration I found a lot to like within its layers and beats. Every track is beautifully produced, many elements are sounds that only exist within software. This mannered approach is not new, it‚Äôs a case of evolution rather than revolution.

While the title track might form a sonic comfort blanket and Rhye‚Äôs contributions to ‚ÄúBreak Apart‚Äù aren‚Äôt much to get excited about, the album does pick up with ‚ÄúOutlier‚Äù. Lasting eight minutes, it does something pretty cool at about 4:30: a synth line that‚Äôs repeated throughout takes over the whole track and becomes meatier than anything on ‚ÄúThe North Borders‚Äù. As an assertive action reaching out to the listener, it‚Äôs the most arresting moment on the entire album.

‚ÄúGrains‚Äù features some interesting voice manipulations but Holly Herndon and Kaitlynn Aurelia Smith cover this ground more convincingly for me. ‚ÄúSecond Sun‚Äù is a gorgeous chill out track, the strings in particular are very enjoyable as they cut in over the synths. Nicole Miglis of Hundred Waters appears on ‚ÄúSurface‚Äù, a track that is more polished than the work of her band but one that lacks their appeal.

‚ÄúBambro Koyo Ganda‚Äù seems more in keeping with the album‚Äôs title and premise, a collaboration with Moroccan band Innov Gnawa. It‚Äôs loose and funky and best of all it isn‚Äôt lulling you to sleep. There should have been about five tracks featuring these guys, I will have to check out more of their stuff4. ‚ÄúKerala‚Äù is also upbeat, though also not a million miles from ‚ÄúJets‚Äù on ‚ÄúThe North Borders‚Äù. ‚ÄúOntario‚Äù is great though, mixing up lots of live instrumentation samples into a compelling whole like a less woozy Lilacs & Champagne.

I don‚Äôt like the vocal on ‚ÄúNo Reason‚Äù, it sounds too much like the anonymous stadium dance of Avicii and his ilk. That said, there are some nice moody moments in the mix: I think I‚Äôd like to hear an instrumental version. ‚Äú7th Sevens‚Äù slowly retreads through ‚ÄúOutlier‚Äù but with less menace and more soundtrack samples. ‚ÄúFigures‚Äù closes out the album with slow strings and more ‚ÄúGrains‚Äù-style vocal manipulations, it‚Äôs pretty but it‚Äôs not going to save your life.

Overall, this is a good hangover album. Enough to keep you awake, but not too much to tax you. There‚Äôs no real mission or direction, despite how pretty everything sounds. And of course, I don‚Äôt really get hangovers any more.

The xx I See You

The xx continue their progress into colour. Jamie‚Äôs solo album last year provides the template for much of ‚ÄúI See You‚Äù, in which the band take more steps toward revealing themselves and the characters that populate their songs. Remi in particular sounds like a revelation, lending songs like ‚ÄúSay Something Loving‚Äù and ‚ÄúTest Me‚Äù with real emotional weight rather than the icy detachment of songs from their first two albums.

The most interesting thing about ‚ÄúI See You‚Äù is that it continues to play to the main strengths of The xx, that of producing music pared back to particular principles and ideas. While ‚ÄúI See You‚Äù may be less detached from the listener, it still maintains a wary distance. Not for the nothing are the songs about isolation or disquiet in relationships. It‚Äôs an album that needs subject matter that matches the tensions in the music.

At some points, I thought that it might be too aching, too self-aware, too self-contained. There‚Äôs certainly a lot of repetition in the track list, even if the songs themselves manage to cast light on similar things from different angles. Essentially ‚ÄúSay Something Loving‚Äù, ‚ÄúPerformance‚Äù and ‚ÄúBrave For You‚Äù are all about the same thing: taking the strain in a relationship that‚Äôs in difficulty. They deserve some slack because that‚Äôs pretty universal subject matter for pop songs and it‚Äôs certainly interesting to listen to how the production tricks combine to create very different-sounding songs from essentially the same lyrical ideas.

At the end of the day, I enjoyed this album more than their other two but I still get the feeling while listening to it that it‚Äôs all too arch. I still can‚Äôt quite care about their songs enough to rave about them (except for ‚ÄúSay Something Loving‚Äù, which is great). However, I like the fact that the workings are shown and that, once again, The xx promise great things for the future.

  1. Personally, I like to forget that oddities like Orchestral Tubular Bells, The Millennium Bell, and Tubular Bells 2003 ever existed.¬†↩

  2. However, ‚Äúvocal samples‚Äù are used. If you listen carefully, this even includes the ‚ÄúHappy?!‚Äù sample from Amorok. There is no explanation of which gadgets or software helped make this possible.¬†↩

  3. The album that I should have written about for Understated Classics!¬†↩

  4. There‚Äôs an eponymous EP on Spotify from 2016 that I‚Äôll try to cover in a future digest.¬†↩

entry.title: Understated Classics #34: Stray by Aztec Camera
entry.content:
The next instalment in my understated classics series is "Stray" by Aztec Camera. Released in 1990, it features two hit singles and the cover is my favourite colour: green.

My angle for writing about ‚ÄúStray‚Äù was that it was an album that I "caught" from my parents. I soon realised that I wrote about some of those already, for example ‚ÄúThe Circle and the Square" by Red Box. Besides, I‚Äôm not sure that my parents liked this album that much.

I remember my dad having a C90 in the car with this album on one side and Billy Joel's album "Storm Front" on the other. "Storm Front" is a good album but not a great one. It starts with "We Didn't Start The Fire" but goes downhill from there. But that cassette might as well have had only one side because we rarely heard any of "Stray". My dad‚Äôs always been one for sticking to what he likes and he didn‚Äôt seem to have any time for ‚ÄúStray‚Äù.

And nor did I until about 1996. I remember a rainy day in June or July of that year, between the last of my GCSEs and the start of my summer job. I was bored. So, in an age with much less choice and at a time when I had fewer sources of new things to listen to, I settled down to listen to some albums belonging to my parents. I avoided the LPs because back then turntables weren't as glamorous as they are now and I didn't want to scratch the records either. To a novice that needle-dropping stuff looked complicated.

I imagine my fingers tracing down the spines of the stack of twenty or so CDs wedged between the hifi and the acres of vinyl my parents owned. Billy Ocean? Nope. Billy Joel? Heard that. Bruce Springsteen? All the good ones are on vinyl. The Three Tenors at the Hollywood Bowl? No thanks. What's the Story Morning Glory? Again? Nah. And so I happened upon "Stray" by Aztec Camera.

Of course you'll remember Aztec Camera as the 'band' that released ‚ÄúSomewhere In My Heart‚Äù in the 80s. Even if the band name means nothing to you, you'll know the song. It's irresistibly catchy: in another universe you're being rick-rolled by it rather than "Never Gonna Give You Up". But Aztec Camera aren't really a band. They started out as a collection of session musicians arranged around a talented songwriter Roddy Frame. As he gained confidence in his songwriting he embraced a solo approach and now he records under his own name, rather than Aztec Camera.

"Stray" is an album at a transition point, showing off a songwriter halfway between torch singer and the leader of a fake band. Tellingly he‚Äôs alone on the cover. It's torn between two views of the world, uncertain of itself and quite unlike the records he'd released beforehand. The songs themselves are either slow and moody, or raucous and agitated. There's no middle ground on "Stray" and as such it barely holds together, stretched in two directions by opposing forces.

Maybe it was that tension which drew me in. Faced with my own line between the past of school and the future of working to earn my keep, perhaps I embraced the dichotomy of sneering songs like ‚ÄúGood Morning Britain‚Äù rubbing up against ballads like ‚ÄúOver My Head‚Äù. And of course, it might just be that it was a fine album featuring songs of a kind that I hadn‚Äôt paid much heed to before.

Listening to it again as a ‚Äúgrown up‚Äù, I‚Äôm taken by how much of it I wouldn‚Äôt have understood. The title track seems to be a plea for a one night stand, but from a perspective I wouldn‚Äôt have appreciated until a few years ago. The sentiment of ‚ÄúGet Outta London‚Äù is something that I would have only got behind in the last few years (and listener, I did). At sixteen the line ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be too gay‚Äù in ‚ÄúGood Morning Britain‚Äù is something I might have glossed over or tried to ignore, these days it makes me angry just how much it enscapsulates the prevailing views of the establishment at the time.

The other interesting thing about ‚ÄúStray‚Äù is that it‚Äôs an album that inverts song styles. The ‚Äòsad‚Äô slow songs are the happiest ones and most of the faster ‚Äòbrighter‚Äô songs drip with cynicism.
