The opening track ‚ÄúSunday‚Äù is a creepy shimmering track about a forgotten world full of chants and allusions to degredation and decay that only bursts into life in the last minute or so. It borrows much from those quiet moments on ‚ÄúLow‚Äù and ‚ÄúHeroes‚Äù.

His cover of the Pixies‚Äô ‚ÄúCactus‚Äù takes a bit of getting used to: he moves from emulating Black Francis in the first verse but by the end he‚Äôs giving it the full Bowie treatment. Bands like the Pixies - outsiders driven on by the power their songs and the stories they have to tell - probably owe their existence to Bowie.

‚ÄúSlip Away‚Äù and ‚ÄúSlow Burn‚Äù are both amazing songs that have been largely ignored even though they‚Äôd probably be lauded had they been on one of the albums he released prior to 1984.

I think ‚ÄúEveryone Says ‚ÄòHi‚Äô‚Äù is probably the first of the songs that Bowie started writing about knowing he would eventually have to stop writing songs. It just captures that hopeful dislocation of someone getting in touch after a long time apart. I remember hearing it on the radio on my birthday one year and it was wonderful. It‚Äôs not a song with a profound artistic statement, in fact it‚Äôs benign and domestic, but it has this innate storytelling quality to it. It just reaches for you from out of the speakers.

The album closes with ‚ÄúA Better Future‚Äù which has this brisk and beautiful little eight note riff underpinning the verses, and ‚ÄúHeathen (The Rays)‚Äù which revisits the subject matter of the opening track. Both have a downcast outlook, particularly ‚ÄúHeathen‚Äù where he asks ‚ÄúHave I stayed too long?‚Äù and realises ‚ÄúI can see it now / I can feel it die‚Äù. The point here is that Bowie pretty much treated every album like it was his last, that‚Äôs why they were usually so good.

Blackstar

The exceptional title track of Blackstar begins ‚ÄúIn the villa of Ormen / Stands a solitary candle / In the centre of it all / Your eyes‚Äù. If you Google ‚ÄúOrmen‚Äù or ‚Äúvilla of Ormen‚Äù, you get nothing. Perhaps this is a reference so arcane and obscure that we‚Äôll never know what or where it is. But perhaps it‚Äôs just an act, one built from words disguising of others: ‚Äúthe veil of performing‚Äù. To me it seems like a song about seeing your pain reflected in the responses of others. The whole ten minutes are remarkable.

When ‚ÄúBlackstar‚Äù was announced much was made of one PR chap saying that it sounded ‚Äúpretty out there‚Äù and most people, confronted with that downright weird video for the title song, might have agreed. But it is in fact a pretty accessible album, especially when you consider what it says. Some people might find the free jazz noodling on ‚Äú‚ÄòTis A Pity She Was A Whore‚Äù a bit much but it‚Äôs a pretty song and the more I listen to it, the more I love the jazz parts. The version of ‚ÄúSue (Or in a Season of Crime)‚Äù is shorter and less obscure than the one on last year‚Äôs ‚ÄúNothing Has Changed‚Äù compilation.

In between those jazzy tracks, we have ‚ÄúLazarus‚Äù, another song that will be better remembered for its video and the message seemingly encoded in its title. It is quite simply the best song of what we will no doubt call Bowie‚Äôs all-too-short late era of ‚ÄúThe Next Day‚Äù and ‚ÄúBlackstar‚Äù. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs sentimental to say that. When I first heard it I thought about how there would one day be a day where we wouldn‚Äôt hear new songs from Bowie ever again. I thought it might be quite soon, that he would soon retire for good. I just didn‚Äôt expect it to be two days later.

The last three songs are also excellent. I love the mixture of polari and nadsat (the slang from ‚ÄúA Clockwork Orange‚Äù) even if it does encode the song to such an extent that you wonder if it means anything at all - but then does it have to? Does Jean Genie? It works well musically, I especially like that self-sample of ‚ÄúWhere the fuck did Monday go?‚Äù and the rolling sinister synths that start to appear in the mix toward the end.

‚ÄúDollar Days‚Äù and ‚ÄúI Can‚Äôt Give It All Away‚Äù both sum up his situation in ballad form. The former pokes fun at his place (or lack of it) in the establishment ‚ÄúIf I never see the English evergreens I‚Äôm running to / It‚Äôs nothing to me‚Äù, while the latter explores the business of needing to write autobiographically after a lifetime of vowing not to do so: ‚ÄúSaying no but meaning yes / This is all I ever meant / That‚Äôs the message that I sent‚Äù. Both songs are heartfelt and they tap into that tranquil reflective side of Bowie‚Äôs work that I highlighted earlier. It truly is a fitting farewell.

entry.title: The Nutcracker
entry.content:
For Ingrid‚Äôs birthday, we went to see The Nutcracker performed by the Moscow City Ballet at The King‚Äôs Theatre in Southsea.

The original conversation went something along the lines of ‚ÄúMatt, please come and see some ballet with me on my birthday! It might not be your thing but I‚Äôd love someone to come and see it with me‚Äù. As I‚Äôve always loved a bit of Tchaikovsky, I said yes.

My only previous encounter with a ballet was an adaptation of Christopher Marlowe‚Äôs Edward II by John McCabe during my English Literature A-level. We got a day trip to exotic Bristol out of it, which when I was 17 meant the chance to visit all the cool record shops looking for rare KLF vinyl that I couldn‚Äôt afford. We also got underage hammered at the pub before going to the Hippodrome to watch a ballet in which a man flounced around with a giant pink strap-on on (as if male ballet dancers didn‚Äôt have enough of that action going on already!). Needless to say, it did little to convert me.

The Nutcracker is an altogether more benign proposition, full of childlike wonder and hummable tunes. The latter attested to by the elderly gent in the seat next to me suddenly humming the odd couple of notes now and then. I think if any ballet show could win me over it would be this.

The initial set, that of a Christmas party, would normally be a little out-of-place this far into January. But not in Portsmouth ahead of FA cup fourth round weekend. As you may or may not know, hardcore Portsmouth fans don‚Äôt take down the decorations until the team is out of the FA cup. Most years this is a wry slight on the team‚Äôs tendency to get eliminated at their first sight of a half decent team, but this year is one of those years when fans get to let their tinsel linger a little longer. (At time of writing, this author expects that Ingrid‚Äôs flatmate will be taking down his decorations tomorrow!)

We loved our seats. When we booked online we though that as we were in row D of the stalls, we‚Äôd be just a bit back from the action and just right of centre. Lovely. When we sat down though it turned out that rows A to C had been pulled out to make way for the musicians (I‚Äôm loathe to say orchestra as there weren‚Äôt that many of them) and we had front row seats. It meant that our view of the dancers was perhaps suboptimal but the added frisson of diverting your eyes to watch the musicians at work from time to time was a joy.

The first act passed me by a little and I was just getting into the swing of things - oh yes, the dancers are snowflakes now - when it ended. I was struck by two things in particular, both about the movements of the dancers. The first was how beautiful it was to see the dancers making abstract and artificial movements, especially when these are made by two dancers with each one fooling you into thinking one is a part of the other. The second is how you get sucked into the story (even if I didn‚Äôt quite follow it until Ingrid explained it at the interval) by the acting of the dancers. Once I noticed this, I was so impressed: not only are the dancers pulling off beautiful and complicated dance moves, they are telling the story with real emotions.

I found the second act easier to follow. I recognised a lot of the music and even remembered a few of the titles of the pieces. Tchaikovsky knew his way around a tune and in The Nutcracker he showcases many traditional Russian folk dances that the dancers of the Moscow City Ballet eagerly demonstrate. It was fabulous colourful stuff. I loved the woven stage backdrop of magical creatures and flowers, its gauzy transparency evoking a fanciful dream.

It was a lovely night out. We had a nice dinner near to the theatre beforehand in Rosie‚Äôs Vineyard on Elm Grove. In the interval we got chatting to one of the stewards and we‚Äôre now taking a tour of the theatre on February 13th, when we‚Äôre also seeing the matin√©e of Spamalot! Great!

entry.title: My Favourite Albums of 2015
entry.content:
Given that I gave up on writing album digests for a bit this year, I thought I would at least do a proper top ten list of my favourite albums. There are quite a few albums that I did not have room for and I might try to revisit those later. In the mean time, let‚Äôs crack on. (To save time, I have in some instances pasted my original review from the appropriate album digest.)

10. The Magic Whip by Blur

I bought this album on the day that I got my new job. What better way to celebrate becoming an economist than by buying an album you‚Äôve already listened to on Spotify? Besides, it has a nice looking cover so why not?

I was never that much of a Blur fan. Aside from the singles the first few albums passed me by. After ‚ÄúThe Great Escape‚Äù I paid more attention, but even then I usually caught up with their albums long after the fact (the one exception being ‚Äú13‚Äù, which I mooned around to in my first year at university). I like ‚ÄúBlur‚Äù and ‚ÄúThink Tank‚Äù a lot and have considered both of them for inclusion in the understated classics.

I found ‚ÄúThe Magic Whip‚Äù to be a good summary of their past records delivered in the form of new songs. That those songs happened to be by various turns cute, sorrowful, apposite and fun was an added bonus. A couple sound like Gorillaz offcuts but the rest is indisputably Blur. There is Parklife and Great Escape aping thrash-along ‚ÄúI Broadcast‚Äù, the Blur-the-album-esque ‚ÄúGo Out‚Äù and songs like ‚ÄúThere Are Too Many Of Us‚Äù and ‚ÄúNew World Towers‚Äù would nestle nicely on ‚ÄúThink Tank‚Äù.

Overall, the album is a solid collection of Blur songs that add to their already impressive back catalogue. If you get to see them live you won‚Äôt mind them slipping the best of these into the set. It is rare for comebacks to be this easy and in Blur‚Äôs case, they capture themselves both as they were and as they are - not an easy feat.

9. The Martian Original Score by Harry Gregson-Williams

This is my review of the movie version of ‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù and this is my review of the book.

This is my favourite soundtrack of the year. I don‚Äôt have a great deal to say about it except that for a film as tense as ‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù, its soundtrack is surprisingly chilled out. Even the music meant to evoke dust storms is fairly calm, perhaps because its job in the film is to focus you on the astronauts‚Äô actions in response to the storm. It‚Äôs more of a soundtrack to an orderly attempt to evacuate than a raging storm. Elsewhere, the score does more work in scenes where Watney totes around Mars looking at pretty red landscapes.

Fun fact: when I get pissed off because my train is late, I put ‚ÄúSprouting Potatoes‚Äù on repeat one. It‚Äôs a beautiful little piece and I can‚Äôt stay mad when I think of those little green shoots poking up through the soil.

8. No Cities To Love by Sleater-Kinney

I had heard of Sleater-Kinney before their boxed set ‚ÄúStart Together‚Äù was released in 2014 but had not ever listened to them. I was quite impressed that they curated their own Spotify playlist with the contents of the box. I added it and even downloaded the songs for offline listening but didn‚Äôt get around to much more than a cursory play of a few tracks.

The great thing about Spotify playlists is that any additions get pushed out to you. In fact you even get little notifications pushed to your phone. So when S-K released ‚ÄúNo Cities To Love‚Äù they added it to the ‚ÄúStart Together‚Äù playlist and this reminded me to check them out. For now I have just stuck to the new record because it‚Äôs good enough to hold my attention.

I love a bit of shouty punky guitar music so ‚ÄúNo Cities To Love‚Äù is perfect for me. It‚Äôs really well produced and the songs are beautifully constructed with thoughtful lyrics. Now that I have a walk to work each morning once more, it‚Äôs nice to find something amazing to listen to. My favourite songs are the title track (I start my morning walk with it and put the rest of the album on shuffle), ‚ÄúFangless‚Äù, and ‚ÄúBury Our Friends‚Äù. Magnificent stuff!

(This review first appeared in January‚Äôs Album Digest.)

7. Every Open Eye by Chvrches

I like Chvrches but I overplayed their debut album ‚ÄúThe Bones of What You Believe‚Äù. After a while its relentless assault of precision-tooled electro-pop began to grate a little. I swore that if I were to maintain my interest than their second album would have to be more varied.

I got my wish. The four songs trailed ahead of ‚ÄúEvery Open Eye‚Äù were each different, the best among them being the pseudo title track ‚ÄúClearest Blue‚Äù. The album opens with ‚ÄúNever-ending Circles‚Äù which has this monstrous repeating riff that propels the song along, rising and falling like the steps that run atop the impossible building in Escher‚Äôs ‚ÄúBelvedere‚Äù print. Lead single ‚ÄúLeave A Trace‚Äù sees Chvrches adding a little dirt and distortion to their perfect sound. The closer ‚ÄúAfterglow‚Äù is beautiful and emotional in a way that no other Chvrches track has been.

Small evolutions like this are what make ‚ÄúEvery Open Eye‚Äù into a coherent whole. They can write amazing pop songs and have a better grasp of the variation needed to sustain the listener‚Äôs interest over a whole album. Their third album is going to be one to look out for.

6. La Di Da Di by Battles

Most years ‚ÄúLa Di Da Di‚Äù by Battles would be much nearer to the top of this list. Mainly because I love Battles. In fact this year most of my Battles love manifested in playing Apple Music‚Äôs ‚ÄúIntro to Battles‚Äù playlist over and over ahead of the release of the new album. By the time my copy arrived, I was almost at peak Battles.

‚ÄúLa Di Da Di‚Äù is a good album that builds on the ground made with ‚ÄúGloss Drop‚Äù despite abandoning the guests that contributed accessibility as well as vocals to Battles‚Äô second album. However, from opener ‚ÄúThe Yabba‚Äù onward it‚Äôs clear that the instrumental-only focus has concentrated Battles‚Äô on making sure that the songs speak for themselves. ‚ÄúLa Di Da Di‚Äù - as its title suggests - is crammed full of hooks.

Throughout the album these hooks get deployed in different ways. On ‚ÄúThe Yabba‚Äù we get a slow build (side note: check out the totally trippy video for this track), while on ‚ÄúDot Net‚Äù they get straight to their shuffle and keep it going long enough but not too long. Battles‚Äô reputation for tightness and efficiency isn‚Äôt just because of their playing, but also how long they play for. They aren‚Äôt afraid to play with a simple idea for a little while and then toss it aside. In fact, these shorter and simpler tracks help pace the album with their direct interludes.

‚ÄúFF Bada‚Äù has a pretty straightforward structure, it‚Äôs my favourite track on the album because it‚Äôs direct and fun. The playing on it is immense and it‚Äôs great fun to listen to. The way that a little march forms towards the end is fantastic. I bet that if there‚Äôs another remix album whoever gets ‚ÄúFF Bada‚Äù will have a field day.

It‚Äôs true that some tracks like ‚ÄúSummer Simmer‚Äù take a while to get going but they‚Äôre worth your patience. These tracks often build slowly into something frenetic and compelling. I imagine that they‚Äôre even crazier live. In fact, ‚ÄúSummer Simmer‚Äù ends up slowly pealing into a sunset and the following track ‚ÄúCalcio e Pepe‚Äù reflects it with its slow opening lines of lyrical feedback. Guest vocalists faced with inventing lyrics for backing tracks like this often come up with something abstract and here without that to be worried about Battles manage to build an emotional connection through their tracks.

Admittedly some tracks like ‚ÄúNon-Violence‚Äù and ‚ÄúTyne Wear‚Äù come over as slightly generic, and perhaps ‚ÄúTricentennial‚Äù sails a bit too close to previous glories, namely ‚ÄúAtlas‚Äù. However, elsewhere there are yet more innovations: on ‚ÄúDot Com‚Äù Battles manage to sound like a thrilling modern take on Neu!. In fact, ‚ÄúLa Di Da Di‚Äù is probably Battles‚Äô most overt acknowledgment of the debt their sound owes to krautrock. I also love the way that the intro to ‚ÄúMegatouch‚Äù channels ‚ÄúUptown Top Ranking‚Äù before turning into what sounds like the weirdest sixties cop show theme ever. Finally on ‚ÄúLuu Le‚Äù we get Battles deconstructing a jam and turning into a song right before our eyes: it‚Äôs beautiful.

In the end, ‚ÄúLa Di Da Di‚Äù is enjoyable but it did leave me hankering for the more immediate zaniness of ‚ÄúGloss Drop‚Äù or ‚ÄúMirrored‚Äù. This is another album on which Battles stake out their own terms and create a lot of accessible music from what seem like very inaccessible elements. That alone is a triumph. We also need to acknowledge that this album wins best cover art of the year by quite a long chalk.

5. Ten Love Songs by Susanne Sundf√∏r

I found this album on Spotify‚Äôs new releases page and recognised her name. She featured on ‚ÄúRunning To The Sea‚Äù, one of the best songs on Royksopp‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Inevitable End‚Äù. As a result I decided to give ‚ÄúTen Love Songs‚Äù a go. I listened to the first minute of the first song ‚ÄúDarlings‚Äù, thought ‚ÄúOK this is weird, a bit like an album of Christian show-tunes‚Äù, and paused it there and then because it was late.

I started again the following morning as I walked to work, partly because I didn‚Äôt have the time to change to anything else. In that fifteen minute walk I listened to the sequence of the first four songs and was blown away.

First off ‚ÄúDarlings‚Äù swells into a wonderful bittersweet song (the first line is ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs definite then? / ‚Ä¶ everything must come to an end‚Äù) that really could be in a musical and then ‚ÄúAccelerate‚Äù lurches into your ears, which sounds like ABBA on bad acid: detached Nordic vocals over squelchy bass and a crazy ‚ÄúPhantom of the Opera‚Äù-style organ break. And later on in the song, both. At the same time. After that ‚ÄúFade Away‚Äù manages to sound like regular ABBA, which as everyone knows is no bad thing and very hard to pull off. Finally ‚ÄúSilencer‚Äù pulls off a wonderful film noir storyline with minimal string backdrop - key lyric: ‚Äú‚Ä¶no one heard you but the stars / Through the rain of the sprinklers, a bullet pierced your heart‚Äù.

From there the quality remains high, even if the lyrical conceit of ‚ÄúKamikaze‚Äù is a little gauche: you get everything you need to know about the song from the title. Following that, ‚ÄúMemorial‚Äù is a ten minute miniature masterpiece of murder and loss in collaboration with M83 (they previously collaborated on M83‚Äôs soundtrack to ‚ÄúOblivion‚Äù - the movie where Tom Cruise takes on aliens WHO BLEW UP THE MOON). The best bit is when it takes about six minutes off in the middle to explore a miniature classical piece. Throughout the whole album every element of each song sounds amazing and was, apart from three songs, produced by Susanne on her own. ‚ÄúTen Love Songs‚Äù is the work of a major talent.

‚ÄúDelirious‚Äù and ‚ÄúSlowly‚Äù are both amazing pop songs. The first begins slowly, perhaps attempting to follow ‚ÄúMemorial‚Äù somehow, before it bursts into a playful double-entendre lyric about BDSM. Meanwhile ‚ÄúSlowly‚Äù revisits the same territory as ‚ÄúFade Away‚Äù with an 80s vibe that one won‚Äôt make you cringe - her vocals are a hair‚Äôs breadth of those of Nina Persson on this song, bringing back memories of The Cardigans‚Äô excellent ‚ÄúLong Gone Before Daylight‚Äù album.

The last two of the ten love songs are ‚ÄúTrust Me‚Äù - a slow burning torch song that makes you want to do anything but trust its narrator - and ‚ÄúInsects‚Äù, a song in which a swarm of synths tries to overwhelm a lyric about keeping a clandestine sexual relationship a secret. The two combine to create a creepy end to the album, in particular the way that ‚ÄúTrust Me‚Äù slows things right down only for ‚ÄúInsects‚Äù to pick up the pace again and end the album on the wrong foot. It makes you want to play it all over again. I have done this. Repeatedly.

The only bad thing about ‚ÄúTen Love Songs‚Äù is that there are only ten. It‚Äôs one of those rare albums where an artists throws everything on to tape and it all manages to stick and congeal into something fascinating.

(This review first appeared in February‚Äôs Album Digest.)

4. Music Complete by New Order

The opener ‚ÄúRestless‚Äù sounds like a crap Electronic song at first, even if its lyric is a laudable deconstruction of middle class greed. The fact that it‚Äôs so surly and lazy is pretty subversive, there can be few occasions when Bernard Sumner has sounded be jaded and less enthusiastic. It‚Äôs certainly a bold gambit to open with such a downbeat song, but toward the end it begins to morph into something more optimistic: ‚Äúit‚Äôs not hopeless / if you take less‚Äù.

Things really take off with ‚ÄúSingularity‚Äù. Bass line that shows you don‚Äôt miss Hooky. Check. Synth line straight off ‚ÄúPower, Corruption, and Lies‚Äù. Check. One of the Chemical Brothers. Check. A chorus straight off ‚ÄúRepublic‚Äù. Check. Suddenly all that (deliberate, constructed) unease created by ‚ÄúRestless‚Äù seems like something of the past. The lyrics are important too, referencing Ian Curtis and Tony Wilson (and probably Peter Hook too, among others). It‚Äôs a really muscular song, there hasn‚Äôt been this much heft to a New Order track since ‚ÄúTechnique‚Äù.

‚ÄúPlastic‚Äù takes the Balearic sound that New Order perfected around ‚ÄúRepublic‚Äù and pushes it on another notch. (Actually it doesn‚Äôt sound a million miles from ‚ÄúDark Angel‚Äù, which is head-and-shoulders the best track on Electronic‚Äôs second album ‚ÄúRaise The Pressure‚Äù.) There‚Äôs a nice Donna Summer vibe to it too. The best bit of all though is the coda, where the cool detached lyric suddenly and briefly becomes intensely personal.

‚ÄúTutti Frutti‚Äù is my favourite song of the year. It starts off like a sleazy threesome between ‚ÄúRelax‚Äù by Frankie Goes To Hollywood, ‚ÄúThe Model‚Äù by Kraftwerk, and New Order‚Äôs own ‚ÄúFine Time‚Äù. Somehow it manages to morph into one of their most poppy songs since ‚ÄúTrue Faith‚Äù or, dare I say it, ‚ÄúWorld In Motion‚Äù. It‚Äôs the first of several tracks that are lifted by the presence of Elly Jackson (aka La Roux). I often stomp through Chichester miming to this song, I must look pretty scary.

Completing a glorious five song opening run is ‚ÄúPeople on the High Line‚Äù which is chock full of housy piano and is strongly reminiscent of their Arthur Baker period. It certainly stands alongside ‚ÄúTouched By The Hand Of God‚Äù and the like. The one criticism of it is that it, like ‚ÄúRestless‚Äù, might be just a shade too long. Mind you, that extended musical outro sounds a lot like something off ‚ÄúTechnique‚Äù - a great source of happiness for me.

From there, the album dips a bit. ‚ÄúStray Dog‚Äù is a spoken word track narrated by Iggy Pop, which is pretty weird. The worst aspect of it is not that Iggy Pop has nothing on Tom Waits for this kind of thing, but that the instrumental track behind the words is very pretty and probably warrants being heard on its own. ‚ÄúAcademic‚Äù is too long and too much like something off the previous two albums, though it is saved somewhat by its earnest chorus. ‚ÄúNothing But A Fool‚Äù is also too long, though if you were to isolate the opening ninety seconds as a separate instrumental track, I probably wouldn‚Äôt notice. The song itself is nothing to write home about though, especially compared to the first five on the album.

Things improve with ‚ÄúUnlearn This Hatred‚Äù which features the most modern sounding keyboard sounds on the album. It‚Äôs also a lyric crammed with typical New Order lyrics (‚ÄúHelp me win this human race‚Äù etc) but as usual it‚Äôs done with such giddy abandon that you can‚Äôt help but give in to its charms. In fact, I also like ‚ÄúThe Game‚Äù for pretty much the same reasons.

Finally, we have ‚ÄúSuperheated‚Äù which features Brandon Flowers of The Killers. I refuse to listen to their ‚ÄúMr. Brightside‚Äù because it always takes me right back to a difficult time in my life. And when I heard this song with him on, it reminded me of those same events and how much time has passed since then. It made me think about how great closure is and how important it is to let water go under the bridge. It‚Äôs a sweet and earnest end to this album too.

There are many way that this album could have been awful (viz ‚ÄúWaiting For The Sirens‚Äô Call‚Äù) and while ‚ÄúMusic Complete‚Äù doesn‚Äôt quite deliver on its title it comes pretty darn close. That opening run of five tracks (or four if you skip straight to ‚ÄúSingularity‚Äù) is almost as good as putting on their singles compilation, though of course that is a twenty-odd song run. It almost makes you eager for more!

3. Divers by Joanna Newsom

The top three albums in this list are - as with most ‚Äúbest of‚Äù lists - interchangeable. To shade one album from another in this ranking I‚Äôve used their accessibility. I tend to elevate fun and accessible albums over others. In the case of ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù by Joanna Newsom this isn‚Äôt fair. Its knotty depths and tangles are chief among its many pleasures. Even so, a list is a list, ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù is an album of the year, and no matter how we cut things we have to compare it to the other albums.

Newsom‚Äôs voice, her reliance on the harp as instrument of choice and her general abandonment of verse-chorus-verse structures are features that we can bemoan as well as celebrate. Let us celebrate them here. Let us celebrate that there is still an artist making music that demands that we listen to it. There is no way that a single song on ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù you can allow to skate over you. As background music it fails. But if you sit down with the lyric booklet in hand, the hour of your time that it demands will fly by.

The main draw is the lyrics. Few songs are stories now, so an album full of songs-as-stories feels like a glut. You need to make time and settle down with them.

It‚Äôs not easy to describe the opening song ‚ÄúAnecdotes‚Äù. I think it is about a child recounting a dream, though it‚Äôs only the final, italicised, eight lines of the lyric that lead me to this conclusion.

The next song is a little more obvious, at least if you have the lyrics (and Wikipedia) to hand. ‚ÄúSapokanikan‚Äù is the Lenape name for the area of Manhattan now known as the Meatpacking District. The song is about how the citizens of the modern city now forget and obscure the ruins and memory of Sapokanikan. Newsom connects Tamanent (Chief of the Lenape tribe) to Ozymandias (aka Rameses II) via Shelley‚Äôs sonnet of the same name, interpolating the famous line ‚Äúlook on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!‚Äù into the lyrics. The irony is that we know more (in a cultural sense) about Ozymandias‚Äô kingdom than we do about the Lenape native americans. You need the lyric booklet to discern all this though.

(It is no surprise to see Newsom acting in Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs recent adaptation of ‚ÄúInherent Vice‚Äù. Thomas Pynchon‚Äôs novels are famous for sprawling over many hundreds of pages stuffed with arcane references and counterfactual histories. I love them. Each of his novels have wikis that are almost as rewarding to read as the novels themselves. Newsom‚Äôs albums might benefit from something similar, collated from the many contributions about her songs to the various song meaning websites out there on t‚Äôinternet.)

I am aware that I have not discussed the music. With just the lyrics in front of you, it would be difficult to set them to a tune in your head. Newsom contorts her lyrics around the music. Sometimes the phrasing of a line in the booklet can break in ‚Äúodd‚Äù places compared to the music. The lines in the lyrics don‚Äôt always correspond with bars in the music in the ways you might expect in pop songs. This makes it tricky to remember the songs for quite a few listens. This is another reason why paying attention is important while listening to ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù. Because the lyric doesn‚Äôt always go the way that the music leads, it is easy to get lost.

I guess there are no more than two choruses on the whole album. Perhaps there are more if you expand your definition of a chorus to ‚Äúrevisiting the same musical phrase with the same or slightly different words‚Äù. None of this is a complaint. It‚Äôs just difficult to write about this album‚Äôs many joys without banging on for ages. It‚Äôs also why I will round out my discussion of it having mentioned just two of the eleven songs.

I‚Äôd urge you to discover the rest of ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù for yourself. It‚Äôs not on any of the streaming services so you‚Äôll have to pony up the dough for a physical copy. It‚Äôll be worth it. Do what I wish I‚Äôd done and get the vinyl! Like many others on this list, ‚ÄúDivers‚Äù is a meticulous album that rewards the attention that you give it.

2. Platform by Holly Herndon

This is an album that could teach robots to love. It‚Äôs excellent. It features pretty much every element I love about dance music and presents it to your with fresh ears. If you bother to listen to just one of my recommendations, make it this one.

Holly is a musician and sound artist, and her compositions on ‚ÄúPlatform‚Äù skip along that boundary between recognisable music and something other, something we might instead choose to call art.

At points it makes me think of Laurie Spiegel‚Äôs experiments in how to create electronic music in the first place, the experiments of Glass, Reich, and others in making a modern classical music, and then the simple visceral pleasures of techno‚Äôs throbs and thuds.

Elsewhere there are tracks that make me think of Prince, James Blake, Grimes, and Laurie Andersen. Most of it though just sounds utterly unique: all those comparisons are just me clutching at straws.

Take ‚ÄúChorus‚Äù, it‚Äôs propelled along by a throbbing beat and yet dominated by sampled voices. It‚Äôs so precise and full of so many small detailed elements that it is impossible to describe in its totality. Of course its idiosyncrasy and defiance of description does not detract one iota from the very real pleasure of listening to it.

And the thing is things just get weirder and weirder from there. ‚ÄúUnequal‚Äù takes what sounds a bit like a medieval plainsong and then wraps it around a barely there beat, before folding in the sounds of running water, bird wings, and samples of poetry. For some people it‚Äôs not going to make any sense at all but for the open minded it is genuinely mind expanding.

‚ÄúMorning Sun‚Äù uses a similar formula and is perhaps the most recognisable pop song on the record. It also has a cool video of her walking around on Mars alone, evoking ‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù. And again, it‚Äôs not just the fact that it sounds so incredible as a whole (and like a pop song despite of everything that‚Äôs in there) but that there is so much internal detail. Not only that, but that it can sound logical despite all the tangents and interruptions.

My favourite though is ‚ÄúLocker Leak‚Äù, which is part sung, part spoken, and all crazy. It‚Äôs full of tongue twisters, puns, and advertising slogans. There‚Äôs also a killer beat underpinning it all. I think it says a lot about the crazy mixed up world we live in: a maelstrom of small snippets that make sense on their own but sound surreal (and a little frightening) when all whipped together.

Seriously. Even if you end up hating it, you need to check out this album at least once on your preferred streaming service. (It might be better if you give it more than one try, it takes some getting used to but it‚Äôs worth the effort.)

(This review first appeared in June‚Äôs Album Digest.)

1. Art Angels by Grimes

Things that haven‚Äôt changed since Grimes‚Äô last album:

  • A scary near-severed alien head on the cover
  • Big chunky pop songs that make you glad to be alive
  • A smattering of references to old dance records that aren‚Äôt cool but are fun
  • Titles that are too weird for the pop charts (but do those really exist or matter anymore?)
  • Huge choruses (‚ÄúREALiTi‚Äù) that are sometimes unintelligible (‚ÄúKill V. Maim‚Äù)

Things that are new:

  • Ooooh guitars, all over the place
  • Whether it gets noticed or acknowledged by the wider world or not, it is clear that Grimes is a unique talent capable of dictating the cultural zeitgeist (Who do you think is responsible for all that pastel hair dye?)
  • A collaboration with Taiwanese rapper Aristophanes (yes, really) that seems to imply that the Taiwanese for ‚Äúmotherfucker‚Äù is‚Ä¶ ‚Äúmotherfucker‚Äù
  • A collaboration with Janelle Mon√°e that shows that Grimes is one of those artists who simultaneously improves and is improved by her collaborators
  • Absolute genuine pop bangers: ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äù, ‚ÄúButterfly‚Äù, ‚ÄúFlesh Without Blood‚Äù, ‚ÄúArtangels‚Äù

I suppose there isn‚Äôt much more to say than that. Grimes is the real deal and ‚ÄúArt Angels‚Äù shows that. I read a post that she put on her Tumblr about a year ago where she wrote about her battles with Tinnitus and her fears that she might have to stop making music. ‚ÄúArt Angels‚Äù shows what a tragedy it would be if she had to.

entry.title: The Long Post
entry.content:
I am writing a long post that I will either publish as one long post (about five or six thousand words) or as about seven smaller ones each closer to the average post length of about eight hundred words. I have to get it out-of-the-way soon as my mind needs to focus on my health economics essay.

It is hard to write short posts to a timetable, let alone churn out long posts on a regular basis. As a result, this longer post is not likely to become the norm. It‚Äôs an idea I had that bloomed into something ever bigger and this time I decided to have a crack at it.

My WordPress dashboard includes a post that I wrote over two months ago in my ‚Äúrecent‚Äù posts. The swanky new WordPress.com app has an insights tab in its stats section that shows a heat map of posts by month and mine are looking rather sparse. Hence this little post to keep things going.

I‚Äôve been rather busy. I‚Äôm an MSc student again, this time doing an MSc in Health Economics at the University of Surrey part-time. This involves a lot of time on the train and though this involves plenty of staring out of the window, it‚Äôs caused me to mull over this long post rather than generate lots of ideas for lots of little ones. Nevertheless I feel that the experience of going to lectures, of learning new things and meeting new people, is very satisfying indeed. It is keeping my mind ticking over.

It‚Äôs hard work and at this time of year when you don‚Äôt see much daylight it can be a bit tiring. The trains in this part of the world don‚Äôt help either. They are never on time and I think it‚Äôs getting beyond parody now, they‚Äôre that bad. On the other hand, it has been unusually warm this winter. Last year, I was huddled in my flat cursing the broken down boiler. This year I‚Äôm still sleeping above my covers like I do in the summer. Anyway, it‚Äôs hard work but it‚Äôs getting me good marks so I‚Äôm happy.

So keep your eyes peeled for a big post in the next week or two.

(2020 UPDATE: Oops, looks like that never happened. Which is a shame, given that the subject matter was pretty predictive of many events that would follow in the next four or five years.)

entry.title: Underworld, Second Toughest in the Infants (Superdeluxe edition)
entry.content:
Last week Underworld reissued their excellent second album ‚ÄúSecond Toughest In The Infants‚Äù in various formats including a four disc super deluxe edition. I wrote about this album in my understated classics series and I want to share some thoughts on the reissue. I love this album so I was excited to hear the remaster and the additional material.

I can‚Äôt comment on the physical version of the release as I can‚Äôt afford it at the moment. I also had to wait to buy the gorgeous yellow reissue of ‚ÄúDubnobasswithmyheadman‚Äù but the ‚ÄúSecond Toughest In The Infants‚Äù box is on the list. Underworld do a really good job on the boxes with interesting artwork to accompany the large volume of material. If the ‚ÄúDubnobasswithmyheadman‚Äù box is anything to go by, the new one will be pretty hefty on the coffee table.

The super deluxe edition comes as four discs. The first disc is the original album remastered. The second collects B-sides and remixes. The third disc comprises unreleased tracks and demos. The fourth disc is devoted to collecting demos and live performances of ‚ÄúBorn Slippy (NUXX)‚Äù. The idea is to demonstrate how the track evolved from demo to finished track. Since ‚ÄúBorn Slippy (NUXX)‚Äù is Underworld‚Äôs best known track, this makes sense.

‚ÄúDubnobasswithmyheadman‚Äù sounded cleaner and clearer after its audio polish. But the remaster doesn‚Äôt seem to change ‚ÄúSecond Toughest In The Infants‚Äù quite so much. I think this is because it was recorded in a better studio with better gear. Identifying the effect of remastering on electronic music is difficult anyway. How do you improve sounds that only exist on hard drives and optical discs? I‚Äôm no audiophile, but the album does seem a little brighter. I noticed more detail in the end section of ‚ÄúSappy‚Äôs Curry‚Äù. The competing keyboard lines are more distinct from one another, creating a dizzying effect. Elsewhere the remaster reminded me how much guitar there is on this album, which I‚Äôd not noticed before.

I own the ‚ÄúPearl‚Äôs Girl‚Äù single so I know its four B-sides like the back of my hand. They sound good remastered, in particular ‚ÄúOich Oich‚Äù. It‚Äôs exciting to hear one of my favourite Underworld songs so improved. Also included are the original instrumental version of ‚ÄúBorn Slippy‚Äù and the ‚ÄúNUXX deep pan‚Äù version. I‚Äôll talk about those when discussing disc four. Rounding out disc two are the B-sides and alternate mixes from the reissued version of ‚ÄúPearl‚Äôs Girl‚Äù. It is disappointing that these reissues include so few third-party remixes: for example, the Alex Reece version of ‚ÄúBanstyle‚Äù from the NUXX singles is missing. It is a shame that there is no room for the ‚Äúcarp dreams‚Ä¶ koi‚Äù mix of ‚ÄúPearl‚Äôs Girl‚Äù which is also a personal favourite of mine. There is a lot of good material for people who haven‚Äôt collected this stuff over the years.

The third disc is of most interest to fans and collectors. The great thing about the ‚ÄúDubnobasswithmyheadman‚Äù remaster was how it made you privy to the different versions and directions that various songs took. There were demos of abandoned songs. There were versions of classic tracks like ‚ÄúDirty‚Äù and ‚ÄúMMM Skyscraper I Love You‚Äù that demonstrated how the different components of those songs were cast into their final versions. Unfortunately there is less of that sort of material here. Although a few of the tracks have the same name as they do on the album, you will recognise most of them as components of tracks that made the final cut. There are only a few blind alleys and offcuts to enjoy here.

One is ‚ÄúBug‚Äù which is an abandoned track that sounds like ‚ÄúRiver of Bass‚Äù. I guess it was discarded because it didn‚Äôt fit on to the album and ‚ÄúStagger‚Äù is a far superior song. Very little of the material on these CDs is this mellow so it makes for a nice addition to ‚ÄúSappy‚Äôs Curry‚Äù, ‚ÄúStagger‚Äù and ‚ÄúDeep Arch‚Äù. ‚ÄúD‚ÄôArbly Street‚Äù is the instrumental sketch of ‚ÄúStagger‚Äù and serves to show just how much Karl‚Äôs vocals take that song into a completely different place. This is my main problem, there‚Äôs just not enough of Karl, and without him the demos and sketches just seem perfunctory. ‚ÄúRowla A1806‚Äù is the most interesting demo here, it has vocals that were dropped and the venom of the instrumental version is absent. ‚ÄúPearls (Version 2)‚Äù is an intense hardcore version of the original that is very enjoyable.

‚ÄúBloody 1‚Äù is a sixteen minute outline of what would become ‚ÄúJuanita: Kiteless: To Dream Of Love‚Äù. It features very little of what I‚Äôd recognise of ‚ÄúJuanita‚Äù (very frustrating that none of these demos do) but it‚Äôs immense. At the start it feels like the ‚ÄúDark Train‚Äù mix of ‚ÄúDark & Long‚Äù and it features lyrics from ‚ÄúTo Dream Of Love‚Äù that are clearer than the album version. When you listen to it you realise that they must have had the great idea of a great big long intro track pretty early on. You also get an impression of just how much work they did to make ‚ÄúJuanita: Kiteless: To Dream Of Love‚Äù so awesome.

On to the fourth disc of NUXX demos. The first thing that struck me is just how well-formed ‚ÄúNuxx‚Äù was in the first demo presented here (‚ÄúNuxx A1796‚Äù). Most of the lyric is ready and most of that fantastic drumbeat is there too. What‚Äôs missing are the amazing drops and some of the performance of the vocal. At this stage they aren‚Äôt really sure about the vocal as some sections get smothered in unnecessary reverb including a line or two reciting a fried breakfast order. ‚ÄúNuxx A2221‚Äù is very weird and they‚Äôre looking for a killer sound to couple with that drum beat. For the first few minutes they try the synth sound from ‚ÄúTexas Cowboys‚Äù by The Grid. However this version is 12 minutes long and by the end they have figured out the strange helicopter-like noises that made it on to the final version.

‚ÄúNuxx A4712‚Äù is where they hit on that choral bit that makes the slow bits of ‚ÄúBorn Slippy‚Äù so hair-raising. Unfortunately they‚Äôre also still playing that ‚ÄúTexas Cowboys‚Äù riff as well. ‚ÄúNuxx A4733‚Äù is ‚ÄúNuxx‚Äù done in the same vein as ‚ÄúDark Train‚Äù with a propulsive riff underpinning the track but the vocal suffers as it can no longer keep up with backing. The ‚ÄúLager lager lager‚Äù line sounds particularly unconvincing. ‚ÄúNuxx A2254‚Äù returns to the drums, postponing the ‚ÄúDark Train‚Äù-style bits to the end with an interesting riff around the nine minute mark. ‚ÄúNuxx A1825‚Äù has the vocal and the down tempo choral bits nailed but it veers off close to drum‚Äôn‚Äôbass territory at points: whenever they use the original drum line it sounds magnificent. Then to cap it off, you get the original and it is a testament to the track that even after six other versions you can still listen to it all the way through.

To conclude, this remaster is not quite as good as the ‚ÄúDubnobasswithmyheadman‚Äù one but only because ‚ÄúSecond Toughest In The Infants‚Äù is a better album and there isn‚Äôt the abundance of rare material to stuff the extra discs with. The incremental versions of ‚ÄúBorn Slippy (NUXX)‚Äù are interesting though with the limited replay value. Let‚Äôs just hope they manage to find more material for the ‚ÄúBeaucoup Fish‚Äù reissue next year.

entry.title: Satin Island by Tom McCarthy: Review
entry.content:
As much as I wanted it to, Satin Island by Tom McCarthy did not win the Booker Prize. Having read it all I realise it was a long shot. However it is an interesting book that deserved consideration, even if it does have some flaws.

Normally I promise that there will be no spoilers. Not this time. There are some spoilers here. Because it took me so long to work out what I thought Satin Island was actually about, I want to use this post to explore those ideas. I promise to keep the amount of plot exposed to a minimum. Given that at first glance the novel appears plotless, I shouldn‚Äôt have too much trouble. However, please read the novel before you read this review, unless you don‚Äôt intend to read it.

If you search for Satin Island on Amazon, the first six books you find are it and its five co-nominees for the Booker. Satin Island even comes sixth on the list! Its rating of two and a half stars out of five is poor compared to the four out of five given to most of the other nominees. (I note that Sunjeev Sahota‚Äôs The Year of the Runaways has four and a half out of five, making it the most popular Booker nominee on Amazon. Perhaps that‚Äôs the book I should read next‚Ä¶)

The point is ‚ÄúSatin Island‚Äù does not have universal appeal. It is pretty hard to ‚Äúget‚Äù. Some of this is down to its rarefied subject matter: it‚Äôs a first person narrative by a ‚Äúcorporate anthropologist‚Äù who refers to himself as ‚ÄúU.‚Äù. As in ‚Äúcall me U.‚Äù - one of the novels many feints and tricks.

He - and it was a fair way through before I was certain that U. is a man - works for a shadowy consultancy on a top-secret project called ‚ÄúKoob-Sassen‚Äù that involves multiple agencies, including the government. The project seems to echo the work of Carter-Ruck for Trafigura, which culminated in the Guardian revealing the existence of super-injunctions in 2009. McCarthy structures the novel in numbered sections like a legal document (1.1, 1.2, etc) or like a philosophical treatise √† la Wittgenstein‚Äôs ‚ÄúTractatus‚Äù with its propositions and sublevels thereof. While this structure is not particularly welcoming when you flick through the book in the bookshop, it is a useful device for driving you through the book once it draws in.

It is worth mentioning what a super-injunction is. It is a legal document that not only prevents named individuals from talking about an ongoing legal case but also prevents them from talking about the fact they cannot talk about it. That such documents exist, things that are almost guaranteed to exist because the fact that no one can talk about them, seem to me to put the world out of kilter. The nature of U‚Äôs philosophical and ethnographical peregrinations hint at similar constraints.

‚ÄúU.‚Äù has to somehow sum up the Koob-Sassen project for his masters. He has to come up with an idea that names ‚Äúthe spirit of the age‚Äù. His boss Peyman pops up from time to time to issue mots justes that border on self-satire. Somehow, despite almost never being directly included in the action, Peyman manages to ooze the same menace as an antagonist from a Ballard novel.

U‚Äôs task mostly ends up with him musing on the issues of the day (an oil spill, an aeroplane incident that leaves him stranded at Turin airport, the death of a parachutist, a football match betwen Barcelona and Bayern Munich, and so on‚Ä¶) and surfing the internet. This is woven between interactions with his girlfriend Madison and the death of his friend Petr from cancer. These personal events are narrated in a detached fashion. Discussion of sex is dispatched in short perfunctory sentences such as ‚Äúwe made love‚Äù. As U. relates his conversations with his dying friend to the reader, he also describes simultaneous thought processes, showing how his mind is always working away to make connections between things - no matter the situation. He comes across as detached and the writing has a similar quality to Nicola Barker‚Äôs ‚ÄúDarkmans‚Äù (as I mentioned last time I wrote about ‚ÄúSatin Island‚Äù), wherein the narrator decides to hop from one thing to another in the search for a plot.

That is pretty much the entirety of the novel.

So what does it all mean? I came to the conclusion that one interpretation of the novel is that it could be a meditation on suicide. First of all, the Satin Island of the title is a reference to a parachute. U. muses for a long time on the case of the parachutist who has the cords of his chute cut. He comes to the conclusion that it was a bizarre form of thrill-seeking Russian roulette amongst the victim‚Äôs parachute club. He finds out that this would be impossible. Eventually he comes to realise that the only person who could have cut the cords is the dead parachutist himself. This is confirmed when he starts to see similar stories of other parachutes around the world.

U. also describes an anthropological ritual involving falling that he remembers learning about an re-enacting as a child. Along with U‚Äôs detachment from the world, perhaps the obsession with parachute deaths is his ideation for how he will kill himself.

In the final chapter U. visits the terminal for the Staten Island ferry in New York. He thrills at the arrangement of broken letters that from one angle appear to spell SATN ISLND. However he doesn‚Äôt board the ferry and visit the island, knowing already that there is little there for him to see. He observes the crowds and withdraws, against the grain. You could see this as U. rejecting life and refusing to reach his destination, but given the echoes of the river Styx in the narrative, it‚Äôs also possible to view it as U. rejecting the chance to accept death. He walks away from it instead.

This may not be the true meaning of Satin Island. It doesn‚Äôt really explain the bizarre tale related in chapter 13 by U.‚Äôs girlfriend Madison, among other things. I‚Äôm ok with that, because with such an open-ended tale you won‚Äôt find a theory to fit everything no matter how you try. It‚Äôs the author‚Äôs prerogative to know whether there‚Äôs a meaning and whether to disclose it. It is more like that the author‚Äôs intention is open-endedness and because Satin Island is a modern novel about modern people doing modern things and thinking in modern ways, ambiguity is always likely. It‚Äôs the reader‚Äôs prerogative to read attentively and discern meaning: at least it is in these times with every narrative fractured into a multiplicity of viewpoints.

Of course there is the problem of legitimacy: if Satin Island has a plot that exists only in the mind of the reader, is it good writing? Is it a good novel? I would say yes because throughout the writing is excellent. It is difficult for a writer to convey the thought processes of an invented character and I think McCarthy does this very well. But then again, as those Amazon reviews suggest, some people respond badly to this and have a very different idea of what a novel is. At the end of the day, this is what will determine whether you love or loathe Satin Island. Which is perhaps as it should be.

entry.title: Understated Classics #32: They Were Wrong So We Drowned by Liars
entry.content:
As it is Halloween, I‚Äôm writing about a spooky understated classic. Liars‚Äô second album ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù is a concept album about witches. It was the first of their albums that I owned having heard their name mentioned among those in the New York Post-punk revival scene at the start of the 00s.

I imagine that to most ears a first listen to ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù sounds dreadful. I certainly thought so. It‚Äôs a short album and if you plough through it there are one or two nuggets that would sound great on most albums - but a lot of it initially seems to be noise and chanting and screaming. If anyone wants to make the argument that Liars are not worth the trouble, not worth the effort to like or understand, then ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù is the album they will use as ammunition.

However, when I revisited ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù over the last month or so in preparation for this post (I do listen to the album I‚Äôm writing about), it surprised me just how much I enjoyed listening to it. I approached it with some trepidation, and I even thought that I should perhaps write about ‚ÄúDrum‚Äôs Not Dead‚Äù instead. However while I listened to it for the first time in years at night and on the train, I found it to be a revelation.

I think one of the reasons why I like ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù so much more than I did back in 2003 is because I‚Äôve listened to so much more music since then. I‚Äôve come to love music that exists at the margin of noise and melody. I‚Äôve discovered bands like CAN and Neu! who build tracks out of groove and texture. I‚Äôm much more appreciative of the effort it takes to bend songs out of typical lyrical constraints and out of conventional structure. I‚Äôve listened to hell of a lot more music by Tom Waits.

Moreover, ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù informs Liars‚Äô subsequent work: its financial flop forced them to hunker down and renovate the studio in which they‚Äôd record ‚ÄúDrum‚Äôs Not Dead‚Äù; its weirdness gave them something to react against on their eponymous album; its structure helped them to pull off a similar feat of (more approachable) story telling on ‚ÄúSisterworld‚Äù; and, of course, if you listen carefully, you can hear its influence on the simultaneously accessible and experimental aspects of last year‚Äôs seventh album ‚ÄúMess‚Äù.

When it comes to your eperience of ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù, the good news is that it‚Äôs going to take you about six minutes to work out whether you will like it. Those six minutes are the duration of the opening track ‚ÄúBroken Witch‚Äù. It begins with some dark slurps of synth that sound almost like alarms, interupted by a burst of rattling drums redolent of those witchy stick constructions that you find in the woods (hence the cover image of this post). As the vocal enters and strikes up a spell-chant, there‚Äôs a nice twisty Marc-Ribot-esque guitar line that underpins it. It all clatters along as though it will all fall to pieces at any second, held together merely by sheer force of will.

As it turns out, I imagine most people might turn off after about two and a half minutes when we get the word ‚Äúblood‚Äù chanted repetitively for about thirty seconds. Remember all those supposedly satanic albums that those concerned parents wrote about to the Daily Mail? Well this is one of those. If you can handle the subject matter, including some tongue in cheek stuff about wanting to be transformed into a horse (‚Äúmen have small hearts / I need a ‚Ä¶ tail / Tell me a tale‚Ä¶‚Äù), then it turns into a great rave-up.

‚ÄúSteam Rose From The Lifeless Cloak‚Äù is a transitional instrumental piece, one of the bits of the album that makes a lot more sense once you‚Äôve heard a few albums by CAN. Meanwhile ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs Always Room On The Broom‚Äù is the one song that could have been on their first album, a post-punk retelling of an episode of ‚ÄúSabrina The Teenage Witch‚Äù (no, not really). It‚Äôs great and I think back in 2003 I really wanted the album to be ‚ÄúBroken Witch‚Äù and nine clones of this song. It‚Äôs the only song on the whole album that‚Äôs direct enough to merit automatic inclusion on your Halloween playlist.

The next song ‚ÄúIf You‚Äôre A Wizard Then Why Do You Wear Glasses?‚Äù (Good diss of Harry Potter guys!) is another transitional piece: it‚Äôs mostly instrumental with some mumbling and some screams at the end. It‚Äôs connective tissue I guess. It leads into ‚ÄúWe Fenced Other Houses With The Bones Of Our Own‚Äù which skulks along on a beat that has all the infernal twitchiness of a steam powered ghost train. The lyrics are mostly about cauldrons and descend into more spell-like chanting. I think that what I understand now is that the entirety of ‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù is an ensemble and that individual tracks present different facets of the subject matter.

With ‚ÄúThey Don‚Äôt Want Your Corn, They Want Your Kids‚Äù the album suddenly takes a lurch into political territory with a song about how witch hunts are designed to distract the poor from the real issues that face them. It‚Äôs surprisingly accessible, perhaps helped by having about the second best arrangement on the record - a twitchy pulsating affair. It‚Äôs frustrating that its momentum then gets cut away with another instrumental interlude ‚ÄúRead The Book That Wrote Itself‚Äù, albeit one that features some superb and spooky drumming. If you fall asleep listening to this one, you will definitely end up dreaming of getting trapped in the woods.

Fortunately the political theme and the tempo return on ‚ÄúHold Hands and It Will Happen Anyway‚Äù. I‚Äôm not sure how I never noticed the fantastic guitar work on this song, it‚Äôs fantastic: horror movie surf guitar anyone? Like ‚Äú‚Ä¶Broom‚Äù it‚Äôs a shouty track and all the more enjoyable for being one of the more structured songs on the album. The last minute or so is compelling, descending into a chant of ‚Äúchoke/choke/the devil we invoke‚Äù.

‚ÄúThey Took It For The Rest Of Our Lives‚Äù maintains the tempo but returns to the clatter and clang of ‚ÄúBroken Witch‚Äù. Imagine CAN playing live at Dracula‚Äôs castle and you‚Äôve got the sound and the vibe.

‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù closes with ‚ÄúFlow My Tears The Spider Said‚Äù - a slow song based around a creepy organ and a lyric that recounts the themes of the album as a whole. It‚Äôs a theatrical end to the album that sums the whole thing up like a Shakespearean epilogue. The organ riff spookily shimmers into a haze of reverb and gets replaced with an eerie vocal line. After a while a clank of slow percussion begins that sounds like wind chimes or the slow progress of a clock mechanism. The last sounds you hear are bird song, almost as though the night is over and the sun is rising once more.

‚ÄúThey Were Wrong, So We Drowned‚Äù is not an easy album to like, let alone love. However it is completely infused with its subject matter. If it were an actor, it‚Äôd be method acting right to the end of the performance. It‚Äôs dark and scary. It never breaks character. It is an album whose pleasures are many but often hidden, revealed over a longer time scale than those of more conventional albums. Why not find a copy this halloween and crank it out loud? Even if you hate it, it‚Äôll probably scare off the trick-or-treaters!

entry.title: The Martian: A Short Review
entry.content:
In my review of the book I mentioned that a film adaptation of The Martian was on the way. I‚Äôm not sure why but it got released earlier than any of the dates that I‚Äôd seen and so on Saturday I found myself watching The Martian on the big screen. Could the film version deliver the same level of entertainment as the novel? Could Mark Watney (Matt Damon) get off Mars alive?

The short answers are (spoiler alert!) yes and yes. The Martian is at least as enjoyable as a film as it is a novel. The change in medium has both pros and cons, but overall it‚Äôs great fun whether you‚Äôve read the book already or not.

In my blog post about the novel, I wrote about what I perceived to be the filmic qualities of the writing about the Martian surface and the computer generated shots of the landscape are stunning. What‚Äôs more the film also looks fantastic at the ‚Äúsuit level‚Äù, there‚Äôs great attention to detail in the structure of the habitat module and the space suits. It‚Äôs almost a shame that this convincing detail almost gets overlooked by the need to propel the film along, I‚Äôd love to have luxuriated in the world building of the film. I bet there‚Äôll be a stack of extras with the Blu-ray in a few months time.

It‚Äôs a long film, not that a great deal of it feels extraneous or forced. One of the weaknesses of novel is that the story unfolding back on earth and on the Hermes ship felt a little forced and underwritten compared to the experiences of Mark Watney on Mars. I think that the film goes a little way to address these issues and that pads out the run time. There are some good supporting performances from Jeff Daniels, Sean Bean, Kirsten Whig, and Mackenzie Davis (it took me a good few hours for me to realise that I‚Äôd recognised her from the excellent TV show ‚ÄúHalt and Catch Fire‚Äù). As an ensemble piece, it‚Äôs solid rather than spectacular.

Matt Damon does a good job as Mark Watney, though I think the film presents Watney as more of an action hero than the book does. Plenty of the charm and wit comes through, with a large amount of the diary entries of the novel taken verbatim and presented in a video diary format. There are a few awkward moments where I noticed the camera work and found that it was breaking my belief that he was alone: in space no one can hear you scream except the camera crew.

Plot-wise plenty has been cut from the book but as I‚Äôve said, it‚Äôs actually a pretty long film and sticking to it slavishly would require a TV series. Because the novel was originally a serial there are a lot of twists and for the film a few had to be straightened out lest it go full Avatar (i.e. go on forever). What remains is still pretty twisty. I was disappointed that a great scene with a dust storm was omitted, but maybe it‚Äôs a deleted scene on the DVD or maybe there‚Äôs an extended cut. Maybe that extended cut should just be a quick re-read of the novel.

‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù is a good film with plenty to keep you entertained. The score and soundtrack are both excellent too, I think the former might be my ‚Äúslip off to sleep‚Äù soundtrack for a few months: with lots of gauzy drones and cute little piano loops, it seems indebted to Brian Eno‚Äôs ‚ÄúApollo: Atmospheres and Soundtracks‚Äù. The soundtrack is mostly disco (this is a plot point) and provides some uplifting and amusing moments throughout. Naturally the end credits roll to the sound of Gloria Gaynor‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù, which is a nice touch. Highly recommended.

entry.title: My Booker Prize Pick 2015
entry.content:
‚ÄúSatin Island‚Äù is my pick for the Man Booker prize, announced tomorrow. I‚Äôve not managed to read all of it yet. Also, I‚Äôve only glanced at the others on the shortlist.

My prediction record on selecting the winner of the Booker from the shortlist is pretty good, though all I‚Äôm ever doing is guess the outcome of a 1 in 6 chance, like the roll of a die. Often it‚Äôs a book that I really hope will win rather than one I know will (except ‚ÄúWolf Hall‚Äù and its sequel). I still think the world is a worse place for Nicola Barker‚Äôs ‚ÄúDarkmans‚Äù not winning the prize back in 2007. I was delighted when Kiran Desai‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Inheritance of Loss‚Äù won the previous year. That‚Äôs part of my affection for ‚ÄúSatin Island‚Äù, it‚Äôs a book that will make people go ‚Äúhuh?‚Äù if they‚Äôre driven to reading it via a prize win.

Obviously McCarthy has come to my attention before. ‚ÄúC‚Äù was nominated in 2010, the year that Howard Jacobson‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Finkler Question‚Äù won. I was determined to read ‚ÄúC‚Äù anyway but somehow never did: I‚Äôd been intrigued by its titular similarity to Pynchon‚Äôs ‚ÄúV‚Äù and the scribbly cover of its first edition (not the awful American cover on the wikipedia page for the novel). Generally when an author gets Booker nominated for two consecutive novels, it‚Äôs a sign that they are doing something right, hence my interest in ‚ÄúSatin Island‚Äù. This is with the usual caveats that prizes don‚Äôt detect good writing, you do, but they do tend to help.

From what I‚Äôve read so far, Satin Island is an interesting take on what the novel might become rather than a shining example of technique. What I mean is that - at least for now - Satin Island strikes me as a worthy winner for its imagination and innovation in taking the novel as a form forwards. In the chapters I‚Äôve read so far, it‚Äôs full of ideas and thoughts and hops between them consummately. However, I‚Äôll only know if it‚Äôs worth persisting with if I manage to persist with it.

It‚Äôs quite short (the shortest of the remaining nominations by a fair way) so I should get through it in the next week or so. Expect a short review around then - especially if it wins tomorrow!

entry.title: Ben Elton, Time and Time Again
entry.content:
Time and Time Again is a ridiculously stupid novel by Ben Elton. A shadowy sect (established by Isaac Newton no less!) recruits a soldier to go back in time and prevent Franz Ferdinand‚Äôs assassination in Sarajevo in August 1914. I wonder if it all goes to plan and everyone lives happily ever after with no weird timey-wimey after-effects?

Needless to say this novel makes me wish that time travel were a real thing so that I could travel back in time and slap myself in the face while in the queue to buy this tripe. I usually try to see the best in the books, albums and movies that I write about, but the most fun you can have with this novel is to rip it to shreds.

The main character Hugh ‚ÄúGuts‚Äù Stanton is a self-pitying sad-sack that Elton expects us to believe graduated from Cambridge. He is thoroughly unlikable: I spent most of the novel hoping that he‚Äôd meet some grizzly end rather than succeed in his goal. Apparently all it takes is a poorly written caricature of a sad-sack soldier for me to start siding with the Black Hand. I wanted world war one to start anyway, just to spite this guy.

Stanton is so thinly drawn, you might think Ben Elton used a template from one of those ‚ÄúHow to write your bestseller in 30 days‚Äù books. Poor characterisation could be excused if this were a novel that your crazy uncle wrote at his creative writing lessons: at least it got him out of the house for a bit. But this is a novel by Ben Elton, who wrote scripts for Blackadder. He‚Äôs supposed to be pretty good at this stuff. Blackadder Goes Forth and its poignant yet enormously funny treatment of the Great War is one of the biggest reasons why people will bother to pick up this book.

The sections featuring Isaac Newton read like extracts from the journal of someone who has had a particularly vivid cheese dream the night after binge watching Wolf Hall.

What about the affable Cambridge don who recruits Hugh to this hare-brained scheme? Well she‚Äôs probably the best thing in the book, a sort of cross between Stephen Fry and one of the two fat ladies. (Incidentally, as fun and frothy alternate history novels go, you‚Äôd be well advised to pick up Fry‚Äôs ‚ÄúMaking History‚Äù which covers similar territory with considerably more aplomb). However, Elton decides halfway through that‚Äôs she‚Äôs going to be evil and bumps her off just as her comic potential begins to dawn on the reader.

A gallumphing intellectual set loose on the past is more preferable to what actually ensues - a love interest who is (of course!) a suffragette and guess what?! She‚Äôs irish. Or rather ‚Äúoirish‚Äù as Elton insists on adding italicised potayto ta bee shure repetitions after every instance of her reported speech. In 2015! What the heck was Ben Elton thinking? Why the hell didn‚Äôt whoever was editing this say something? Was there even an editor? I‚Äôm almost certain that there wasn‚Äôt.

The unfortunate thing is that in a mirror to the plot of this book, the paths untaken and the ripples that travel out from those choices mean that it is possible to see a better story within the mess. The last five chapters are more interesting as Ben Elton‚Äôs construction of time travel is clever enough to include a mechanism for timelines to cross over, so we get to see the onward effects of time travel. However, those alternate time lines and their impact should have more emphasis in the plot. After all, isn‚Äôt that what you expect from a title like ‚ÄúTime and Time Again‚Äù?

To conclude, I‚Äôd advise that you do not buy this book. Instead, please invent a time machine and pinch my copy from me last Thursday. Thanks in advance.

entry.title: South America, Part 11
entry.content:
La Paz to Potosi

We left La Paz, this time ascending the rim of steep hills around the city in a slightly less clunky ‚ÄúDeath Bus‚Äù. Perhaps it was because we were travelling uphill or because it was daylight, but it didn‚Äôt seem so bad.

We set off to Potosi through strange towns with weird monuments (see the pictures) and Oruro where great festivals happen around Ash Wednesday each year that are famous throughout the continent.

We had lunch by the side of the road just after Oruro. We had a strange fruit from La Paz for dessert: I have a picture of the outside but I can no longer remember their names. Inside, the fruit had red flesh and quite a few pips. It didn‚Äôt taste particularly sweet, it was a bit tart but not too bad.

We got in to Potosi quite late. I made lots of attempts to snap the imposing countryside - including the Cerro de Potosi. This was the highest point of the tour. The advice is to avoid alcohol because it‚Äôs so high up but a few of us did and it just felt as though you were drinking while very tired. The altitude didn‚Äôt really affect any of us, unlike in Quito and on the Inca trail where some of us suffered a bit.

Potosi

The hotel was one of those built around a central atrium and it rained heavily during the night, a clattering sound on the glass roof. It was a pretty place, certainly one of the better places we stayed in Bolivia.

The next day, after breakfast in a strangely greenhouse-like dining room on top of the hotel, we took a trip to the mint museum. It tells the history of the town and story of the mining operation in the hills around it. As I alluded to in my post about Lake Titicaca, the natives for hundreds of miles around were swept up into the mines and worked to death for silver. At that time almost all Spain‚Äôs silver came out of the mines of one mountain - the Cerro de Potosi. The work was difficult and dangerous, and if they weren‚Äôt injured then silicosis would eventually kill them. The conditions were terrible. The average life expectancy was about six months.

The sad thing is that people are still mining the mountains in the area and conditions are barely better. Later that evening we watched a heartbreaking documentary at the hotel about children struggling to make a living from the near-depleted mines. And of course it‚Äôs not just Bolivia: almost everywhere that minerals are mined, children are exploited.

You can go on mine tours too. I opted not to as I already feeling a bit down (the week or two after the visit to Machu Picchu were a bit of a come-down really). A few people went and said that it was a depressing experience.

After insisting on a quick coffee and a lemon pie, we set out to find the famous flying saucer caf√© but got halted by rain and general difficulty in finding a good walking route to get there. It was probably closed, like almost everywhere else. Potosi is a bit depressing in the rain (where isn‚Äôt?) and because it was early in the new year, there weren‚Äôt a great number of places to eat that were open. We ended up in the same place for both evening meals but not for the lack of trying!

Uyuni and the salt flats

The next day we headed out for Uyuni and its salt flats. We made it in good time as the Bolivian government have invested in new roads for the area as it now hosts one of the legs of the Dakar rally. The trans-continental race was moved to South America a few years ago under the threat of terrorism and now thrives there. No longer intercontinental, it takes a different route each year through two or three different countries. The 2014 route was from Rosario to Salta (both in Argentina) to Valparaiso (in Chile). The section through Uyuni was only for bikes and quads, the participating cars and trucks had to make do with Salta (more on which in Part 12). Nevertheless the Dakar rally brand was everywhere in Uyuni, just one more bit of merchandise for the hawkers. (And apparently the reason for there being no internet, they were upgrading the cable ahead of the race‚Ä¶ apparently)

Uyuni is a military town and the hotel was right next to a military base. The first morning there I listened to a drill taking place while I was in the shower. The hotel was also partly a pizza restaurant apparently famed for being the best pizzeria in South America (Minuteman Pizza). I‚Äôm not sure this was the case, it was pretty good but I just used it as an excuse to have pizza for dinner two nights in a row.

On our full day in Uyuni we took a trip out in jeeps to visit the salt flats and the train graveyard. We had dinosaur props and all sorts ready to emulate the wacky false perspective pictures from the salt flats that adorn the walls of the Minuteman Pizza restaurant. Unfortunately due to recent storms, the flats were a little flooded but these made for some dramatic pictures too. We found some dry areas and arsed about a bit, I include some pictures below.

In the middle of the salt flats there is a hotel made of salt. It‚Äôs also the only place for miles around with toilets. I can remember going to the loo and looking through a hole in the wall (which was made of salt) to everyone milling around outside. It was rather surreal. So surreal that I took a photo! (Something that I had forgotten until I looked for pictures to accompany this post!)

In the morning the sun was shining and the sky was that deep blue that you get wherever there is a lot of white around (think of Greek Islands or Caribbean beaches) but by lunchtime another glowering storm was coming in.

After the salt flats we paid a visit to the train graveyard. By this time the rain was upon us - so instead of pictures of rusting industrial hulks set against a cerulean blue (very popular on Flickr), I have them all set against gun metal grey skies and rain instead.

That evening the storm really hit and the hotel had a power cut. We watched Doctor Who on dwindling laptop batteries and played cards by torchlight unable to hear much for the sound of rain and hail clattering on the roof.

entry.title: Eric Schlosser, Gods of Metal
entry.content:
Y-12 is the United States‚Äô most secure weapons-grade Uranium storage facility. It is known as the ‚ÄúFort Knox of Uranium‚Äù. In 2012 it was infiltrated by three elderly peace protesters, sparking a major scandal about the safety of US nuclear sites. ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù by Eric Schlosser tells the story of that break-in alongside a history of both the anti-nuclear movement (in particular the Plowshares movement) and nuclear security in the United States.

A revision of an article that originally appeared in the New Yorker as ‚ÄúBreak-In at Y-12‚Äù, ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù is a small short-form book (a ‚ÄúPenguin Special‚Äù) of about 120 pages that you can read in one or two sittings. It is also a companion to Schlosser‚Äôs most recent book ‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù, which is a history of nuclear safety in the United States.

The title ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù refers to the Plowshares movement‚Äôs belief that nuclear weapons are revered idolatrously in the blind faith that they keep us safe. I found ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù illuminating from three perspectives.

First, the issue of security surrounding nuclear material is paramount. This book is terrifying. The ease with which the group, including an 82 year old nun with a heart condition, gains access to Y-12 is frightening. As Schlosser explains, the danger is not the theft of weapons or bombs but of highly radioactive material. The thought of rogue states or terrorists acquiring such material is the stuff of nightmares. The thought of them doing so by walking into a supposedly secure facility unchallenged is even worse.

Of all mankind‚Äôs existential threats, nuclear weapons remain the second greatest after an asteroid strike. (Second greatest because, if we wanted to, human beings could eliminate the threat of nuclear weapons to their existence by adopting universal disarmament.) Although this book focusses mainly on the break-in at the Tennessee facility, Schlosser also draws attention to the frightening implications of current instabilities in Pakistan and Russia for the security of nuclear weapons stock in those countries. This year in the UK, a Royal Navy employee blew the whistle on lax security procedures at the Trident nuclear submarine base in Faslane, Scotland. It seems that while these weapons and the materials to build them exist, we will always have this sword of Damocles hanging over our head.

Second, this book makes a strong case against private sector involvement in the affairs of government. I‚Äôm aware that it‚Äôs a little different in the states because Federal government is one thing and State law is another, and there‚Äôs weirdness about how the two interact. Nevertheless a long list of failings is laid down at the door of private contractors and makes for stark reading for even the most ardent of neoliberals. It will be a source of some amusement to British readers that the corporation G4S is involved in this mesh of private contractors. G4S is the poster-child for the ill-effects of private-public partnerships. Their shadowy influence, malign incompetence, and dangerous cost-cutting reaches into all walks of life all over the world. And while it‚Äôs easy enough to single out G4S, we should be uneasy about all situations in which private companies are asked to provide a critical service of quality while under market pressures.

Third, it seems to me that protest movements are more important now than they have ever been. If an 82 year old nun breaking in to a site handling weapons-grade uranium unchallenged seems pretty surreal, that‚Äôs because it is. We may feel that the arguments over nuclear weapons are won. The cold war is over (kind of) and nuclear weapons played an important role in bringing that about. But if people like Sister Megan Rice did not continue to protest nuclear weapons then the first break-in to one of these bases would have been by terrorists. Who will take up this mantle when people like her are gone? What are we giving away when we allow legislation that erodes our right to protest? Moreover, Schlosser writes tenderly about the origins of the anti-nuclear protest movement, noting how it began within deeply religious Catholic communities and he takes care to emphasise the human stories at the centre of the break-ins he writes about. He humanises people that are often dismissed as nuts or crazies, and shows how their concerns should be the concern of all of us.

As I wrote at the start of this post, ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù is a thrilling read. Schlosser expertly weaves the narrative of the Y-12 interlopers into his potted history of nuclear weapons protests. It is taut, well-paced and informative.

I have had a copy of ‚ÄúCommand and Control‚Äù for a year but haven‚Äôt had time to read more than the first chapter: that too reads like a thriller. Naturally I‚Äôll write a review of that when I‚Äôm done reading it.

In the meantime ‚ÄúGods of Metal‚Äù is a perfect, if slightly chilling, read for your next train journey. At ¬£1.99, it‚Äôd be cheap at twice the price.

entry.title: Everything Everything, Get To Heaven
entry.content:
It‚Äôs difficult to write honestly about your feelings. It‚Äôs difficult to write about your feelings consistently, for a living on a regular basis. It‚Äôs difficult to write about your feelings when the world constantly intrudes with inanity, insanity and hatred. It‚Äôs difficult to write under those conditions without seeming frayed, without coming loose at the edges.

‚ÄúGet To Heaven‚Äù, the third album by Everything Everything, was forged under these stresses and pressures. For most of its running time it sounds like either a bomb ticking down to explode or like a clock inexorably counting up missed opportunities and stolen moments. It sounds for all the world as though it is trapped between fight and flight, paused between action and apathy.
