Yet it also subjects the listener to the yammerings of a culture that has driven itself mad. Depth and surface, glass and steel, truth and lies.

Everything Everything‚Äôs previous album ‚ÄúArc‚Äù found their songcraft in a similarly precarious state of affairs. Ideas about love and existence were crammed into miniature epics that twisted and thrashed around like a handcuffed escape artist suspended high above some watery peril. For the most part - as on singles ‚ÄúCough Cough‚Äù and ‚ÄúDuet‚Äù - the escapist act was not there to be seen: it was only the thrashing that mattered. A song of theirs would fishtail between subjects, between id and ego, between triumph and disaster. Only on ‚ÄúUndrowned‚Äù was the danger truly glimpsed (‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much to talk about / that we don‚Äôt talk about‚Äù). A glum lullaby set in ice, the modern media merry-go-round cast into the very depths of Dante‚Äôs inferno - the winter chill of traitors, no flames here. It was, in retrospect, the marker lain for future trails.

‚ÄúGet To Heaven‚Äù reveals the shark and its teeth rather than the plastic fin above the water. The stakes are raised and the danger is real. There‚Äôs no pretending that the world has not become darker and more dangerous in the years since ‚ÄúArc‚Äù - but of course there‚Äôs that title, the lurid neon colours of the artwork, the ravey chords underpinning ‚ÄúDistant Past‚Äù: there‚Äôs optimism to be had here. It‚Äôs the joy that comes from persisting in spite of it all, the calm that comes from setting yourself aside from the madness around you.

This must have been a difficult album to write. To take all that imagery of war and destruction, to take the ever-pervasive sense that those in power are screwing us all over, to take all the existential doubts that can exist within one person and how those doubts derail friendships and loves. To take it all and throw it into what initially sounds like the grimmest rave ever, and to shape it into something worth believing in. That must have been difficult.

I can‚Äôt say that ‚ÄúGet To Heaven‚Äù is the best album that I‚Äôve heard this year (not yet) but it‚Äôs certainly one of the more ambitious and interesting. Compared to how dull Foals have become (more on which soon) and just how much Everything Everything sounded like a second-rate Longpigs at points on ‚ÄúArc‚Äù, it‚Äôs amazing that they‚Äôve done this well. The production is sharp and bright, meaning that it contrasts with my go-to record for dark times - Radiohead‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmnesiac‚Äù - but then again it was always going to.

You‚Äôll notice that I‚Äôve not described many of the songs. I‚Äôm not sure that I can write about them effectively this close to hearing them for the first time, not when they‚Äôve affected me the way that they have. I urge you to check them out for yourself instead. As always, stay away from the bonus track version - nothing was ever gained by sticking six extra tracks that didn‚Äôt make the cut to your album playlist.

The subject matter is probably among the darkest that pop music ever deals with, and yet somehow it still flickers to life and makes you feel invigorated and alive. That‚Äôs a very peculiar trick. You can‚Äôt expect an album to explain why bad things happen, but you can expect one to get you dancing regardless and ‚ÄúGet To Heaven‚Äù does just that.

entry.title: Inherent Vice: A Short Review
entry.content:
Tonight I finally caught up with Inherent Vice, Paul Thomas Anderson‚Äôs adaptation of Thomas Pynchon‚Äôs novel. It stars Joaquin Phoenix as Larry ‚ÄòDoc‚Äô Sportello who‚Äôs put on to a case of possible kidnapping by his ‚Äúex-old lady‚Äù Shasta, played by Katherine Waterston.

There‚Äôs no point attempting to tell much more you of the plot of Inherent Vice: it‚Äôs rather convoluted and self-digesting. At least this means there‚Äôs very little chance of stumbling into inadvertent spoilers. However, most of the plot strands do fall into place by the end, much more than I‚Äôd imagined they would half way through.

Inherent Vice has a lot in common with other films that Paul Thomas Anderson has directed that I‚Äôve seen. In essence it‚Äôs about the failure of the American dream as much as There Will Be Blood is. Set in 1970, it plays out as the counterculture finds itself sold out, exploited and infiltrated by the very people that it set itself against. It‚Äôs as much about the difficulties in doing right by other human beings as Magnolia is. You get the impression that Doc is very much still in love with Shasta but that there are all manner of other complexities to his relationship. I imagine there are a fair few parallels with The Master and Boogie Nights too, but they‚Äôre both still on my To Watch list. I picked Inherent Vice because I fancied something a bit lighter to watch.

I thought it was the first Paul Thomas Anderson movie that I found very funny. I think this all comes through from the Pynchon source, his novels are incredibly funny. Even though you might be completely lost after a few pages, it‚Äôs almost a given that those pages will make you laugh somehow. In Inherent Vice almost every character is comic and almost every situation is farcical.

Not only is it funny, Inherent Vice is also a beautiful movie. I‚Äôm not one of those people who can spot those odd mistakes like the wrong lamp-posts in a particular shot, but I was fooled the whole way through. And there‚Äôs something about the way it‚Äôs shot that really appeals to me. Part of it is that when people are having a conversation, a lot of the time (except when the plot requires it) the underlying shot is that of two people talking to one another. A nice example of where this really works is a scene where Doc chats to his lawyer (Sauncho Smilax - played by Benicio del Toro - very much channeling Fear and Loathing five years on) in a diner - when the waitress comes over Doc abruptly hushes Smilax almost as she comes into frame, heightening the tension and mood.

I also really liked the soundtrack. If you‚Äôre going to play Can over the opening credits, then I‚Äôm always going to be a big fan. As with ‚ÄúThere Will Be Blood‚Äù the score is by Radiohead‚Äôs Jonny Greenwood but in fact the majority of the delights come from period pieces. There‚Äôs little doubt in my mind that the musical vignettes are also enhanced by the aforementioned superb cinematography.

Joaquin Phoenix is brilliant. I must admit he‚Äôs not how I‚Äôd imagined Doc when I read the novel but his mannerisms and speech are pretty much perfect. It‚Äôs a perfectly timed comic performance that really gets to heart of someone who knows everyone but knows nothing about what they‚Äôre doing. He does turn out to be a good detective and he does the right thing by the end. I think his performance is so good that I‚Äôll probably get more out of re-reading the novel because of it.

Apart from Joaquin Phoenix, there are also great performances from Owen Wilson as Coy Harlingen and from Josh Brolin as the police inspector ‚ÄòBigfoot‚Äô Bjornsen. The latter is great as a scenery chewing ‚Äòstraight‚Äô cop with a weird home life. I also really enjoyed seeing Joanna Newsom as Sortil√®ge, the sort of proto-narrator who also appears as a character. She gives a lovely sing-song cadence to her lines (understandable given that she‚Äôs a singer) and she does all the important work of pulling the movie together. (As in common with Pynchon, her name is a pun - Sortilege is the act of divination by lots, though her narration is mostly given in the form of astrological mumbo jumbo‚Ä¶ another of Pynchon‚Äôs wonderful feints.)

It‚Äôs not an easy movie to understand but its pleasures are many, provided you can sit down and really watch it. I started while eating my dinner but ending up pausing it until I‚Äôd finished because it is hard at points to hear what the characters are saying, and with a plot this loopy it can problem if you miss something. That said I think the film is more lucid than the book, if only because it drives through the plot in its two hours twenty minutes. Sometimes a book, which takes longer to read, can unravel irrevocably given the chance - Anderson‚Äôs adaptation is quite disciplined and does not allow the plot too many opportunities to get away from the viewer. With the novel, lots of Pynchon‚Äôs asides and in-jokes draw attention away from the matter in hand - and some of them are visual, so they‚Äôre better served by the film.

As ever, read the book the first. If you enjoyed the book, you‚Äôll love this. And even if you didn‚Äôt, you might still like this if you love Magnolia (a little less harebrained) or There Will Be Blood (though this is mostly lighter). Failing that, go dig out the soundtrack - you‚Äôll thank me for that at least.

Previous appearances:

  • Thomas Pynchon
  • CAN

Trivia: Inherent Vice is a legal term for something contains its own source of destruction, like eggs breaking. It‚Äôs used particularly in situations of high risk, often something cannot be insured because of it.

entry.title: Understated Classics #31: The White Room by The KLF
entry.content:
This little masterpiece was released in 1991. I got my copy on cassette for Christmas that year, but by May in 1992 they‚Äôd already ‚Äúretired‚Äù and split up.

The KLF were a band in the right place at the right time with the right idea. Taking advantage of synthesizers and the idea of fusing rock and pop music with the emerging sound of house music, they laid the ground for many of the most successful electronic acts that followed them. They were also master showmen, taking a whole host of crazy conspiracy theories and smooshing them together in one stadium-sized package.

‚ÄúThe White Room‚Äù will be a quarter of a century old in 2016. It is a sort of Stonehenge of modern dance music: mysterious, totemic, and completely unique to the minds that conceived it. There are nine tracks and the whole thing‚Äôs over and done in forty-five minutes, yet there‚Äôs plenty of space and groove with two tracks making it past your standard 12‚Äù running time.

This is Radio Freedom

The album begins with ‚ÄúWhat Time Is Love?‚Äù - the perfect example of their singles formula - a burbling synth line and just the right samples. At first I though the ‚Äúmu mu‚Äù line (more on its meaning later) was ‚Äúroll roll‚Äù. Of course it‚Äôs the ‚ÄúI wanna make you sweat‚Äù line made it an essential addition to early classics like Lil‚Äô Louis‚Äôs ‚ÄúFrench Kiss‚Äù (a record that I cued up seven times in a row on a jukebox when I was 12) and the like.

After that, ‚ÄúMake It Rain‚Äù is probably the great lost KLF single - it‚Äôs rumoured that this is what they were working on when they started to lose faith in the project - a laid back groove and a cool sax line that may or may not actually be a synth. As a teenager I was convinced that I could actually make it rain by singing fragments of this song (yes I was rather odd when I was younger).

‚Äú3AM Eternal‚Äù and ‚ÄúLast Train To Trancentral‚Äù show the other great idea that The KLF hit upon in 1990 and 1991: to take rap and hip-hop music and insert it into that dance-pop hybrid. This inspired all sorts of nonsense, like 2 Unlimited and such, but let‚Äôs not worry about that. Listening to it now, it‚Äôs much clearer how much of a debt that ‚Äú3AM Eternal‚Äù owes to tracks like ‚ÄúPlanet Rock‚Äù by Afrika Bambaataa.

The album version of ‚ÄúLast Train To Trancentral‚Äù is longer and mellower than the single version, with the american version of the album preferring this version. Though The KLF‚Äôs back catalogue was deleted in 1992, the US version of the album is still available. It‚Äôs a much weaker version as it has no crowd noise samples - on the UK version the whole of side A plays out like a concert with cheering and PA announcements between songs - and the shorter version of ‚ÄúLast Train‚Äù, while energetic, is rather abrupt.

Step Into The White Room

The weird brilliance of ‚ÄúThe White Room‚Äù as an album is that it actually feels like a single. You have that continuous twenty minutes of music on side A with three UK Top 10 singles (and a number one) sequenced like the best concert ever and the side B plays out like a cooler mellower shadow of that first half.

‚ÄúBuild A Fire‚Äù is a sleepy travelogue song built on crickets, synths and pedal steel that channels their other album ‚ÄúChill Out‚Äù. It also indulges Bill Drummond‚Äôs songwriting skills and his Scottish accent comes as a bit of a surprise at this point in the album. It may not have the machine guns of ‚Äú3AM Eternal‚Äù or the grind of ‚ÄúWhat Time Is Love?‚Äù but as a song ‚ÄúBuild A Fire‚Äù is as much part of the KLF legend as the more lauded ones. (Rumour has it that a radically reworked version would also have appeared on that lost ‚ÄúMake It Rain‚Äù single.)

The title track of ‚ÄúThe White Room‚Äù is genuinely odd - scat singing over a proto-drum‚Äôn‚Äôbass beat with female backing vocals and a spoken word lyric from Drummond. It‚Äôs also got that synthy-sounding sax from ‚ÄúMake It Rain‚Äù again. It has the feel of a track that‚Äôs an experiment and it‚Äôs pretty successful, proof that they probably had plenty left in the tank when they called it quits.

The last two tracks develop the mythology of Drummond and Cauty‚Äôs shadowy alter-band The Justified Ancients Of Mu Mu. ‚ÄúNo More Tears‚Äù stretches out long and lazy over nine and a half minutes. To the twelve-year-old me this song felt like lazy filler but over the years I‚Äôve grown to appreciate all the little elements within it - there‚Äôs even a bit of melodica and a dub feel to some of it. Mostly though it is the track that speaks loudest to The KLF‚Äôs plan to create a movie of ‚ÄúThe White Room‚Äù to accompany the album. By all accounts it was to be a road movie and I imagine ‚ÄúNo More Tears‚Äù would sound great soundtracking a long stretch of movie where nothing much happens - it certainly did when I listened to it on the truck one day on the way down to Patagonia!

‚ÄúJustified and Ancient‚Äù was famously re-tooled into a weird techno-country single featuring Tammy Wynette - another of those moments where Drummond and Cauty found that the best way to make things happen was simply to do it. This attitude was first espoused in their book ‚ÄúThe Manual: How To Have A Number One The Easy Way‚Äù, a tome that has been consulted by many artists since. It may have incurred the wrath of ABBA (The first Justified Ancients of Mu Mu album had to be deleted and all copies destroyed because of uncleared samples of ‚ÄúDancing Queen‚Äù) but here it created another top 5 single for ‚ÄúThe White Room‚Äù and went a long way to earning them their Brit Award for Best Group in 1992.

The White Room version (the B-side to the single) is much mellower and ends with desolate winds - appropriate for a side of music that begins with the chirp of crickets. Black Steel‚Äôs delivery of the lyrics (the closest to an outlining of The KLF philosophy in one of their songs) is suitably wistful, though it could never match the Tammy Wynette version.

What They Did Next

  • As The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu, they released a single called ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Grim Up North‚Äù that listed northern towns and included samples of 808 State‚Äôs ‚ÄúCubik‚Äù and recordings of ‚ÄúJerusalem‚Äù. The song even caused questions to be raised in the House of Commons.
  • They returned to ‚ÄúWhat Time Is Love?‚Äù with a hair metal version called ‚ÄúAmerica: What Time Is Love?‚Äù that put forth theory that it was in fact the Justified Ancients of Mu Mu who discovered America a thousand years before Columbus. It‚Äôs amazing, especially the 12‚Äù version. It has an operatic middle 8.
  • Meanwhile, even better is the B-side ‚ÄúAmerica No More‚Äù, which compares the then nascent First Gulf War to the Vietnam War by mixing up samples from both time frames alongside bagpipes. Like all the best moments from their back catalogue, it shouldn‚Äôt work but somehow it just does.
  • At the Brit Awards the band collaborated with death metal band Extreme Noise Terror to perform a thrash metal version of ‚Äú3AM Eternal‚Äù before firing blanks from a machine gun. The performance shocked the audience (and me watching at home) with the announcer declaring ‚ÄúThe KLF have left the music industry‚Äù. And they had.
  • They burnt a million quid.
  • They haven‚Äôt reformed. Not properly. Not yet.
  • UPDATE 2017: They might have reformed!

entry.title: Untitled 2
entry.content:
A few months ago I wrote about an idea for a novel that I‚Äôd abandoned. I mentioned in that post that I‚Äôd abandoned it because there was another idea that I wanted to pursue. The working title for it is ‚ÄúUntitled 2‚Äù. (It isn‚Äôt really, I have an actual working title that would give things away or would at least make me feel like the idea was out in the world.)

In recent days I‚Äôve mulled over various post ideas and one idea was to write a big reveal of my vision for ‚ÄúUntitled 2‚Äù. I could set out what the novel would be about, the ideas it would grapple with, and when and where it would be set. Stuff like that.

But I realised that just as with Jackson X and the Summer of the Space Whale, this would mean letting go of the project entirely - because if I let the cat out of the bag, I won‚Äôt be able to write the novel I dream about.

At the same time, I realised that I wanted to write this post in order to try to set out the idea. It‚Äôs hard enough to write a blog regularly as the long gaps between posts here are testament too. I don‚Äôt think I could hammer out eight hundred words a day as well. (Though I guess I won‚Äôt know unless I try.) And it‚Äôs not as if that‚Äôs the only difficulty, at least with a blog I can flit from one topic to another. With a novel I‚Äôd have to shape it and make it coherent. Lots of editing would be involved. Ugh.

However, I do need to work through the principal ideas and see whether they‚Äôre worth focussing on. I can see the benefits of at least trying to flesh out the ideas. There are aspects of the novel that I don‚Äôt feel confident that I can write. As a result it might be useful to resist my urge to tell you what it‚Äôs about and focus instead on producing posts to experiment and maybe develop that confidence.

After all, ‚ÄúUntitled 2‚Äù doesn‚Äôt have to be a fantastic novel, it just has to be mine. At least now I can sketch out the shape of the piece and try to set myself those confidence boosting tasks.

Finally, there was a day recently where I did sit and turn ‚ÄúThe Summer of the Space Whale‚Äù into a more full-blown treatment. It ended up pretty complex. This pleased me because I did worry that it was an over-simple idea and that it couldn‚Äôt be written into a ‚Äúproper novel‚Äù. That‚Äôs something that‚Äôs also been a worry for me when I‚Äôve though about ‚ÄúUntitled 2‚Äù but hopefully it will be similarly amenable.

entry.title: First Light, Last Light
entry.content:
I often ponder whether the joys of waking up early are greater than those of staying up late. Empirical evidence seems to bear this out: all those people who get to work before you do, super-eager to get everything done. But then all the people walking under your windows late at night, drunk and laughing, they sound like they‚Äôre having a whale of a time too.

I oscillate between the two extremes, though I tend to sleep better if I stay up late. My natural sleep hours are 1am to 8am, though I am usually human if I can get up just after 7. Whenever I try to stick to getting up early, to do masochistic things like running or being organised, I often find it harder to get to sleep or I wake up at 3 rather than 6. I end up second guessing my alarm clock.

I now structure my life in a routine without routine, where I try to stick to both approaches at once. Because my early bedtime is 10 and my late bedtime is three hours later (gasps from the balcony!), I now plan my evenings to do something different after 10 o‚Äôclock. I stop watching TV or playing Civ, and start drafting a post or tinkering with existing ones. (As much as I love writing new posts, I do like to smarten up old posts as well‚Ä¶)

A lot of the time I don‚Äôt make it till one, which is ok because you can leave things like reading and blogging until the next day if need be. I always sleep better if I end up with the book I‚Äôm reading tapping me on the nose. There‚Äôs also no better remedy for insomnia than to finish a piece of writing, particularly if it‚Äôs about something you‚Äôve had on your mind all day. I‚Äôm also far less of a night owl outside the house, I need to be somewhere I can micronap even if I‚Äôve burning the midnight oil: loud places and alcohol bore me, they‚Äôre often effective sedatives.

Either way, I don‚Äôt like the middle ground. A crisp cool early morning run with no one around is a delight. That slowness of the night as it drags the departing day into dreams that drift across the silence of suburban streets, that has its own majesty. Each is preferable to the miserable clamour of the day itself.

In the end, it doesn‚Äôt matter which way you go. You have to split the difference between the virtuous hard-worker who gets up with the larks and the creative soul who likes to wring every last tick and tock from the day‚Äôs long clock. You might even settle for what I cannot: the median. The roles and stereotypes about when you rise and fall are cultural, which mean that they are merely methods for persons uncaring and unknown to take power over your choices, your life. Don‚Äôt let them. Stay up awhile. Bed yourself down right now to be up with the dawn. Whichever choice it is, make it the one that you want.

entry.title: Minions: A Short Review
entry.content:
The Minions got their own movie, just as I predicted in my review of Despicable Me 2. I went to see it this week and I enjoyed it a lot. Here‚Äôs a short review. Don‚Äôt worry, there are no spoilers here that aren‚Äôt in the trailer.

It‚Äôs very funny. Right from the opening credits you get the minions and their anarchic fun-loving slapstick humour. There‚Äôs always been something delightful about they way in which they innocently bumble around. Their penchant for evil bosses is inexplicable but incredibly amusing.

There‚Äôs nothing deeply philosophical about a minion. They just enjoy being part of the herd and live joyously in the moment. I guess we should all try to be like them, at least from the happiness point of view.

The plot is serviceable enough. Like the trailer, the film is narrated throughout which helps to shape things. I love the fact that for large sections the minions just babble away in their own language (a sort of bowdlerised French to my ears) and you‚Äôre effectively watching a foreign film without the subtitles.

There are no big twists just hilarious moments of deus ex machina that are heavily signposted, often to comic effect. This is fine for a fairly silly film that slips in outrageous ideas at every opportunity. I think I gasped with laughter at a couple of bits just because it was so silly.

Unfortunately Minions can‚Äôt quite keep up with itself. Very few of the non-minion characters stand out, which is understandable but also a little disappointing. I think the Despicable Me films are better than Minions because there are other strong characters like Gru and the girls. All minions all the time does seem to be too much of a good thing.

Another problem is that slapstick cannot sustain an entire movie so there are moments when Minions has to slow down just to let something else happen on-screen. Yet there are also other moments where there isn‚Äôt enough slapstick, that the movie plays it too safe. I won‚Äôt tell you what those are, as spoilers would be involved.

It really strains against its U certificate. In the trailer you see the minions working for Dracula and in the cinema I heard a young child ask his parents ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs that?‚Äù How do you explain who Count Dracula is to a four-year old?

There are chase sequences that go to extraordinary lengths to avoid the level of violence you‚Äôd probably see in ‚Äúnormal‚Äù movies. They end up funnier as result, but there are also moments that gloss over extreme violence involving guns, axes, knives and explosions.

I was also uncomfortable with a scene involving a torture chamber, in particular a noose. Call me a prude if you like but I don‚Äôt think a gallows has any place in a U certificate movie. A PG certificate would hardly be a disaster anyway, it‚Äôs a nice minion-friendly yellow. The BBFC judgement states ‚ÄúThere is a comic scene in which a man threatens to torture the minions in his medieval style torture chamber. The minions are stretched on a rack and hung on a noose but neither of these things harm the minions at all.‚Äù Well that‚Äôs alright then‚Ä¶

I could be wrong though. After all, I didn‚Äôt mind that I‚Äôd spotted an Alien reference in Despicable Me 2.

To conclude, I enjoyed Minions a lot but I think I liked Despicable Me 2 a bit more. I might benefit from seeing it again (I did miss the scene after the end of the credits after all). The good news is that there is going to be a third Despicable Me movie and I expect that the minions will make it into a few other movies too.

entry.title: An Initial Comparison of Apple Music and Spotify
entry.content:
My previous post about Apple Music was more a response to how it was presented at the WWDC Keynote rather than to the idea of Apple Music itself. I should have known better than to use that clickbait title. I knew I wasn‚Äôt writing about the product, more the flatness of its introduction (despite the names on show).

After a few days of living with it I thought I‚Äôd write about it and Spotify, so that it‚Äôs not just my snarky comments about the keynote that are on record here.

I signed up for the three-month trial. (I also made sure to cancel auto-renewal.) I‚Äôve not cancelled my Spotify subscription because I feel it‚Äôs better to evaluate them both side by side. I figure one way to tell whether the new service is better is to note whether I reach for Apple Music over Spotify more often as the trial continues.

These are some brief observations so far:

  1. Apple Music playlists are pretty good. Both Apple and Spotify provide what I call situational playlists - sequences of songs suited to the time of day - though Apple‚Äôs are more vague. Also the ‚ÄúFor You‚Äù tab on Apple Music (roughly equivalent to Spotify‚Äôs ‚ÄúNow‚Äù tab) is presented more as a feed that updates over time. At the moment I can still scroll down to the very first batch of suggestions Apple gave me. Meanwhile Spotify will work out what part of my day it is (i.e. commute, lunchtime, bedtime etc) and suggest appropriate playlists. I love the bedtime ones that feature jungle noises and rain! Apple‚Äôs big plus in terms of playlists are the genre and artist centred ones. These are very good, especially the artist ones, built as they are on iTunes long neglected (but actually pretty good) Genius feature.
  2. Spotify indicates which songs and albums you have saved to your device more clearly than Apple Music. This is important to me because I don‚Äôt always have a very consistent signal as I walk through town. I will test this more.
  3. One of the main draws of Apple Music for me is AirPlay integration. However this is better in Spotify than it used to be. With Spotify it‚Äôs even possible to play control music playing on my PS3 from my mac, which is nice for combining gaming and music.
  4. I‚Äôve never been much in love with Spotify‚Äôs UI but their iOS app has improved a lot in recent weeks and Apple Music on iPhone seems a bit fiddly by comparison (perhaps it‚Äôs better with a 6+ than a 5S). On the Mac though the integration of Apple Music into iTunes makes a lot of sense to me and is pretty fun to use. I enjoy Apple Music much more on the Mac than on the phone.
  5. My gut feeling is that Spotify makes it easier to discover new music, while Apple Music seems to me to have a good grasp of the music I already like.
  6. Everything I listen to on Spotify scrobbles. With Apple Music only the music I listen to on the laptop scrobbles. There is an iOS app from last.fm called iScrobbler but it seems to be so far behind the times that I don‚Äôt think it would work any more, certainly not with the streamed stuff. I like the idea of having a record of what I listen to and have used Last.fm for many years, so it‚Äôd be a shame to let it go.
  7. I think the radio station is ok though I‚Äôve only listened to it for a little while out of idle curiosity. I imagine radio, with its occasional interruptions from the presenter and its meander through genres to please all tastes, is a good way to humanise the playlists. Apple claims its playlists are picked by humans but even so a playlist is a fixed set of particular songs. Radio is another way to surface music for people in a dynamic fashion. To my ears Beats One is so scattershot (Reviews back this up too) that it could also address the issue of how Apple Music gets me to listen to new stuff.
  8. I switched off Connect as soon as I could, it doesn‚Äôt appeal to me at all. Neither did MySpace back in the day. You can replace the tab with one that features your own playlists, a nice touch as iCloud playlist syncing is one of the best features of iTunes Match.
  9. Neither Spotify nor Apple Music can play my vinyl. However Apple Music does let me stream two of the three bonus tracks on the recent Orb album.

Overall, Apple Music has impressed me - it was always going to be a case of using it rather than believing the hype - but there are things for Apple to iron out and Spotify does have significant mind share with me. I will write another update in September shortly before the trial ends.

entry.title: Album Digest, June 2015
entry.content:
To reboot this series, Album Digest June 2015 features five fantastic albums from Hot Chip, Jamie xx, Blanck Mass, Holly Herndon, and The Orb. I could pick loads more as I‚Äôve listened to a lot of albums since February but I decided to focus on the more electronic material. This means that I have no excuses for not continuing next month with a rockier theme.

Hot Chip ‚ÄúWhy Make Sense?‚Äù

Hot Chip seem to be settling in to a pattern with their album releases, alternating between messy experimental affairs and then a state of the art correction. Witness how ‚ÄúThe Warning‚Äù smartened up the all-over-the-place ‚ÄúComing On Strong‚Äù and how ‚ÄúOne Life Stand‚Äù moulded and matured the lovestruck meandering of ‚ÄúMade In The Dark‚Äù into a lithe ten song set. ‚ÄúWhy Make Sense?‚Äù takes the earnest song-based approach of ‚ÄúIn Our Heads‚Äù and casts it into a funky fun-filled fifty minutes. It‚Äôs as concise as they‚Äôve been since ‚ÄúOne Life Stand‚Äù.

As usual there are bangers, songs that would happily sit on any of their albums. ‚ÄúHuarache Lights‚Äù is a pean to machine intelligence, the line ‚Äúreplace us with the things that do the job better‚Äù repeated by a vocoder that gradually melts into an incomprehensible babble. ‚ÄúLove Is The Future‚Äù is a sweet love song that takes on the tweeness of ‚ÄúLook At Where We Are‚Äù and re-tools into a bouncy pop song.

I think ‚ÄúEasy To Get‚Äù is probably as coy and sexy as Hot Chip have been since ‚ÄúMade In The Dark‚Äù. It‚Äôs pretty direct about playing easy to get: ‚ÄúYou need a coat, something to take off‚Äù. Meanwhile there‚Äôs a lovely little synth line that filigrees the chorus that makes it feel like a song you‚Äôve known for years. It‚Äôs lovely.

Other tracks like ‚ÄúNeed You Now‚Äù and the title track aim squarely for the dance floor. The former is built around a lovely sample of an old school house vocal (sorry, I‚Äôm not knowledgeable enough to say what it is), giving it a ready-made classic feel. It also features the much underused vocal talents of Al Doyle. The title track has provided some consolation since the disastrous result of the election with its killer line: ‚ÄúBe what you are / at the mercy of your rulers.‚Äù

Hot Chip are UK dance music‚Äôs Radiohead. They get on with the job without too much fuss and constantly turn out excellent albums. I wonder what their ‚ÄúKid A‚Äù would sound like?

Jamie xx ‚ÄúIn Colour‚Äù

I want to like The XX much more than I do. I love their remixes but their original albums not so much. I admire their spare approach to arrangements and their monochrome artwork, but over the course of a whole album their music tends to leave me cold. Songs that are amazing in isolation, like ‚ÄúVCR‚Äù or ‚ÄúAngels‚Äù, just don‚Äôt come together well at anything over EP length.

‚ÄúIn Colour‚Äù is very much the remedy to that, the colour wheels of the artwork seem very apt. Like anyone trapped in a corner by a restrictive aesthetic, Jamie xx has done the sensible thing and started all over again. This is album is a colourful (there I said it) explosion feel good nostalgic dance music. Stand out tracks include ‚ÄúGosh‚Äù, ‚ÄúSeesaw‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Rest Is Noise‚Äù.

‚ÄúGosh‚Äù takes the rattling brittle rhythms of UK drum‚Äôn‚Äôbass and moulds it into a warm vibrant opening track. It‚Äôs all homage and you can feel the love seeping out your speakers.

‚ÄúSeesaw‚Äù shows that with more emphasis on beats and less on introspection, The Xx could be a phenomenal band - in fact this plays more like a remix of one of their songs than a song proper. Remy‚Äôs detached vocal works well as a vague snippet, while a more extended contribution later on (‚ÄúLoud Places‚Äù) gives the album a much-needed breather and its emotional heart (‚ÄúI go to loud places / to find someone to be quiet with‚Äù). Another collaboration with Oliver, the other member of The XX, is less successful but at least it is short.

I have no idea whether ‚ÄúThe Rest Is Noise‚Äù is inspired by Alex Ross‚Äôs excellent book of the same name. I think I‚Äôd expect more neo-classical wonkiness over the album as a whole if it were. The track itself begins with a minimal beat that initially sounds like it is sticking but eventually emerges into an emotional heartbeat. It is beautifully affecting instrumental music, the sort of thing you‚Äôd like to watch the sun come up to. It pulls a lovely feint with a deep bass line toward the end too.

As a whole, ‚ÄúIn Colour‚Äù reminds me a lot of Four Tet‚Äôs ‚ÄúBeautiful Rewind‚Äù album, which took a similar nostalgic approach and produced a kinetic album that emphatically endorsed an older form of dance music whilst still sounding fresh and new. I wonder if this more expansive approach could also be applied to music by The XX.

Blanck Mass ‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù

Blanck Mass is the pseudonym of Benjamin John Power, one half of minimalist noiseniks Fuck Buttons. ‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù is his second album under this alias.

If ‚ÄúIn Colour‚Äù is a euphoric celebration of dance music past, then ‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù could be thought of as a darker trip into its future. Not that this album is entirely ascetic, it also has a knack for hitting the savvy music fan‚Äôs pleasure points. Take the opener ‚ÄúLoam‚Äù which slurs into your headphones with distorted voice samples but ends up becoming a frenetic gated jam by the end of its four minutes.

‚ÄúDumb Flesh‚Äù is front loaded with possibly the best dance tune of the year, ‚ÄúDead Format‚Äù. It‚Äôs a glowering colossus, a banger that does all that button pushing I mentioned. There‚Äôs a proper build in it and the main riff is a distorted female vocal that‚Äôs pulled from pillar to post (or more accurately, around and through your ears like some sort of brain floss). It certainly demonstrates a novel way of getting around sample clearance: mangle your vocals beyond recognition.

After that things are more subdued. The ten minutes of ‚ÄúNo Lite‚Äù sound like a softer Fuck Buttons track - which isn‚Äôt to say it isn‚Äôt relentless and minimal, just that the average Fuck Buttons track is pretty heavy. There are also more elements at play here than on a typical Fuck Buttons tune.

‚ÄúCruel Sport‚Äù almost has a chorus. About three-quarters of the way through it sounds like a sampler has gained sentience and is trying to rap, all over a beat that‚Äôs about twice the size of your house. It‚Äôs epic, almost as good as ‚ÄúDead Format‚Äù. There won‚Äôt be many albums out this year with two tracks as good as ‚ÄúDead Format‚Äù and ‚ÄúCruel Sport‚Äù.

The rest of the album is good but doesn‚Äôt quite match up to the highlights. It‚Äôs a perfectly serviceable listen but I get the impression that I‚Äôll end up putting those two great tracks on a playlist and then forgetting about the rest.

Holly Herndon ‚ÄúPlatform‚Äù

This is an album that could teach robots to love. It‚Äôs excellent. It features pretty much every element I love about dance music and presents it to your with fresh ears. If you bother to listen to just one of my recommendations this month, make it this one.

Holly is a musician and sound artist, and her compositions on ‚ÄúPlatform‚Äù skip along that boundary between recognisable music and something other, something we might instead choose to call art.

At points it makes me think of Laurie Spiegel‚Äôs experiments in how to create electronic music in the first place, the experiments of Glass, Reich, and others in making a modern classical music, and then the simple visceral pleasures of techno‚Äôs throbs and thuds.

Elsewhere there are tracks that make me think of Prince, James Blake, Grimes, and Laurie Andersen. Most of it though just sounds utterly unique: all those comparisons are just me clutching at straws.

Take ‚ÄúChorus‚Äù, it‚Äôs propelled along by a throbbing beat and yet dominated by sampled voices. It‚Äôs so precise and full of so many small detailed elements that it is impossible to describe in its totality. Of course its idiosyncrasy and defiance of description does not detract one iota from the very real pleasure of listening to it.

And the thing is things just get weirder and weirder from there. ‚ÄúUnequal‚Äù takes what sounds a bit like a medieval plainsong and then wraps it around a barely there beat, before folding in the sounds of running water, bird wings, and samples of poetry. For some people it‚Äôs not going to make any sense at all but for the open-minded it is genuinely mind expanding.

‚ÄúMorning Sun‚Äù uses a similar formula and is perhaps the most recognisable pop song on the record. It also has a cool video of her walking around on Mars alone, evoking ‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù. And again, it‚Äôs not just the fact that it sounds so incredible as a whole (and like a pop song despite of everything that‚Äôs in there) but that there is so much internal detail. Not only that, but that it can sound logical despite all the tangents and interruptions.

My favourite though is ‚ÄúLocker Leak‚Äù, which is part sung, part spoken, and all crazy. It‚Äôs full of tongue twisters, puns, and advertising slogans. There‚Äôs also a killer beat underpinning it all. I think it says a lot about the crazy mixed up world we live in: a maelstr√∂m of small snippets that make sense on their own but sound surreal (and a little frightening) when all whipped together.

Seriously. Even if you end up hating it, you need to check out this album at least once on your preferred streaming service. (It might be better if you give it more than one try, it does take some getting used to but it‚Äôs definitely worth the effort.)

The Orb ‚ÄúMoonbuilding 2703 AD‚Äù

‚ÄúMoonbuilding 2703 AD‚Äù is the tenth Orb album since the future (i.e. the year 2000) arrived, though it feels like the first true Orb album since Orblivion. Despite ‚ÄúHistory of the Future 2‚Äù doing a great job of rehabilitating their more recent material (in my mind at least), it is a genuine relief to hear a classic sounding Orb album again.

I think the familiar sound of the album comes from two things. First, it‚Äôs just Alex and Thom, which means it‚Äôs two-thirds of the classic line-up responsible for most of ‚ÄúU.F.Orb‚Äù and ‚ÄúOrbus Terrarum‚Äù. Second, the tracks are about thirteen minutes long on average - something we‚Äôve not seen on an Orb album for quite a while. It‚Äôs just a shame that there are only four tracks - though this does make for an easier review.

The expansive run times of the tracks and the spacey material makes for a genuinely relaxing album. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a crime for ambient music to lull you into a sleepy state, that‚Äôs pretty much what I listen to it for.

‚ÄúGod‚Äôs Mirrorball‚Äù marries the sound of the last Alex and Thom only collaboration ‚ÄúOkie Dokie It‚Äôs The Orb On Kompakt‚Äù - this album is released on Germany‚Äôs Kompakt records too - with the gently undulating rhythms of classic tracks like ‚ÄúBlue Room‚Äù and ‚ÄúValley‚Äù. There‚Äôs also something really quite modern about the sound of it too, something that I can‚Äôt quite put my finger on.

‚ÄúMoon Scapes 2703 BC‚Äù has a nice cavernous beat and is more reminiscent of ‚ÄúBaghdad Batteries‚Äùstyle material, but also the harder tracks on ‚ÄúU.F.Orb‚Äù like ‚ÄúClose Encounter‚Äù. In fact, by about halfway it‚Äôs splitting the difference between those long mixes of ‚ÄúAssassin‚Äù, ‚ÄúMajestic‚Äù, and the trippy alternate takes of ‚ÄúPlateau‚Äù you find floating about on various rarity compilations.

‚ÄúLunar Caves‚Äù is the shortest track. It‚Äôs quite dark and it doesn‚Äôt really manage to come together into anything in particular. In the context of the four tracks here, it‚Äôs fine - the long meandering line between B and D on the track listing. (Actually it reminds me a lot of the really long mixes of tracks from ‚ÄúOrblivion‚Äù that were included with the reissue - I think that‚Äôs the last time we got tracks this length from The Orb.)

Finally the title track is uncharacteristically funky, which isn‚Äôt to say it isn‚Äôt welcome: it‚Äôs certainly nice to hear a new take on their sound alongside all the nostalgia. It has a kind of hip-hop vibe. This might not seem to make much sense but given how successful The Orb were at taking house music into space, why not have another go with another genre. It would certainly be interesting to hear some rapping over this - though maybe not all fourteen minutes!

I think this is a solid addition to their later discography, it certainly bodes well for ‚ÄúHistory of the Future 3‚Äù. The sad thing though is that in their heyday, The Orb would have released this much material in one of their singles. For example, the combined length of the ‚ÄúAssassin‚Äù EP can‚Äôt be much shorter than ‚ÄúMoonbuilding 2703 AD‚Äù and the diversity of the mixes was not dissimilar to the variations between the tracks here. Ah, the passage of time.

PS: I have the triple vinyl and there are three bonus tracks that I have not been able to listen to yet. I will report on these later once I have a turntable.

entry.title: Time Is Time and That Is That
entry.content:
A brief rant about Facebook: I hate the fact that the news feed defaults to ‚ÄúTop Stories‚Äù even though I change it back to ‚ÄúMost Recent‚Äù every time I log in. It‚Äôs a horrible pattern of user abuse that needs to stop. Time is time and that is that.

So why does Facebook feel the need to jiggle things about into a random order? Well most of you have that mobile phone app of theirs that sucks your battery and your data allowance like crazy (mainly by auto-playing videos like a dick). They know you‚Äôre checking your Facebook on the loo at work and that that limits your interaction time. During this precious interlude they want you to see the stuff that they think interests you and the things that other people paid for you to see. You‚Äôre going to see some hick‚Äôs new tattoo, at least one photo of someone else‚Äôs child and an advert telling you to vote Conservative - whether you like it or not.

This behaviour is spreading. Twitter is trying it too. They‚Äôve introduced a ‚Äúwhile you were away‚Äù doodad that completely undermines the point of Twitter. Twitter exists to disseminate short, disposable, time-sensitive information in public. The ‚Äúwhile you were away‚Äù feature is a bit like watching week old episodes of the ten o‚Äôclock news on iPlayer.

Imagine if newspapers suppressed recent events in order to tell you who to vote for and distract you with idle gossip about celebrities that history will wash away like sandcastles on a beach. Oh they already exist and they‚Äôre all of them.

Imagine if your mobile provider decided to send your texts to you in the wrong order for reasons that suited their business model. You get a message from your spouse asking you to pick them up from work ten hours late: No wonder they‚Äôre sitting in bed next to you silently fuming and won‚Äôt talk to you.

(Obviously some mobile phone networks - like, for instance, Three in Chichester - are running an experimental version of this kind of service. I doubt that it will catch on, despite its evident value in avoiding calls from recruiters.)

There are real-time messaging apps that can‚Äôt mess around with the chronology of events. Facebook has one - and owns the other one that most people use. Meanwhile Facebook also owns Instagram which, for the time being, doesn‚Äôt muck around with user timelines.

The rise of video streaming apps like Twitch (for video games) and Periscope or Meerkat (for showing people the inside of your fridge) might help to set things right. You can‚Äôt disrupt a live stream without annoying the viewer, you‚Äôd have to do what YouTube is doing more often and that‚Äôs showing ads ahead of videos. Mind you, that‚Äôs annoying enough as it is. Time marches forward, it‚Äôs too precious to spend changing news feed setting and watching damned adverts.

entry.title: Learn X in Y Minutes
entry.content: I found ‚ÄúLearn X in Y minutes‚Äù (www.learnxinyminutes.com) while researching the programming languages needed for a new project. The site aims to help people who know at least one programming language to learn others by proving a quick run through of the main language features. It‚Äôs not quite enough to get you up and running. After all, having sample code doesn‚Äôt get you the compiler. However, it‚Äôs a nice start that shows you how similar (and different) language X is compared to the one(s) you already know.

entry.title: Jim's Conservatory
entry.content:
Let‚Äôs assume that Jim has just had a sudden unexpected expenditure: a neighbour released a bull into his back garden and it destroyed his conservatory. Let‚Äôs assume that the conservatory is essential to Jim‚Äôs wellbeing, so it has to be fixed immediately. As a result Jim‚Äôs debts, which were previously small and well-managed, have now increased somewhat.

Obviously Jim can‚Äôt keep that debt hanging over him forever. What does he do?

Fortunately for Jim, the circumstances of his borrowing aren‚Äôt so different before and after the event. Interest rates are low and are predicted to stay low, and the terms of his credit haven‚Äôt changed a great deal despite his increased borrowing.

In fact Jim is lucky enough that his creditors won‚Äôt be too panicked even if he borrows twice as much as he is now. (If you think this unrealistic, think of it as the bank betting that the more Jim borrows the more likely he is to have a balance that they can charge him interest on when interest rates do rise.)

Jim has an income that was comfortably managing to pay his debts but now his debt payments are taking up a greater fraction of his income - to the point where his agreed repayments and essential costs combine to generate more debt. First, Jim can make some savings to account for this. However, he can‚Äôt eliminate all his spending or else he spoils his income (for example: he cannot earn if starving and will not be paid if he does not take the train to be present at work).

Naturally we assume that Jim can‚Äôt simply default.

We‚Äôll assume that Jim is already in an optimal and legal tax situation, that he can‚Äôt earn more simply by withholding it from others who are due - after all, this is little more than default by another name.

Jim‚Äôs best chance at paying off the debt is to increase his income. He‚Äôd better do it sooner rather than later, as he has little idea of which way the economy will turn. He has some options for quick wins - he considers withdrawing from his pension scheme until the debt is paid. He could also cancel his home insurance (at least for a little while). He can ask for a raise but not for too much or he‚Äôll simply be out on his ear and earning nothing.

The best thing Jim can do is to develop his current skills and adapt to new job opportunities in the hope of securing a better income. If he does this then chances are he will be in a stronger position after the debts are paid, he‚Äôll be able to live comfortably, and start to build up a fund against future emergencies.

Jim is looking at a few years of not being able to get the latest iPad, cover himself in ridiculously ugly tattoos, or go out on the lash with his mates. He thinks this might not be a bad thing. His experiences of researching the evidence base for the most effective ways to sustainably increase his income has left him way of short term fixes to long term problems.

This post was inspired by this article by Paul Krugman: The Triumph of Unthinking.

entry.title: Like a Rhino Voting for Poaching
entry.content:
There‚Äôs a reason I cannot and will not vote Conservative, and like most people‚Äôs apparent motive for voting tory it is also a selfish one. As someone employed in the public sector, working to ensure the greater good, I‚Äôm a member of an increasingly endangered species.

Ah Matthew, I hear you say, you‚Äôre trotting out the old ‚Äúthe turkeys have voted for Christmas‚Äù line. Well no, like I said, this is purely selfish. When you mark that X in the box, you tend to think about yourself only. Never mind the turkeys (for now).

The rhino analogy is apt, you see. The conservatives are not shy about their ideological pursuit of a small state. They want as little paid for by taxpayers as possible, the functions of our community solidarity provided by unaccountable private companies. They are the poachers.

To a poacher, the hunting of a rhino has a logic that cannot be seen by the outsider. There‚Äôs a value to the kill that blinkers the poacher, makes them unable to see the wider ramifications of their blood lust.

They are big game hunters. After the last election the Conservative-led coalition published a list of every public servant paid over ¬£100,000 - their list of the trophies they were going after. Several people working in the organisation I worked for at the time were on that list. I didn‚Äôt begrudge them their salaries. I thought they were by-and-large worth it. It made me aspirational; after all, that‚Äôs what big salaries in the private sector are supposed to do aren‚Äôt they?

But instead the Tories made an argument not dissimilar to that made by the most deluded of poachers - something along the line that by keeping the number of rhinos down, poaching somehow benefits the rhinos.

The conservatives argue that a talented worker in the public sector should have no trouble finding work in the private sector. There are captive rhinos too. Traded between zoos (private companies) with their reproduction rate kept low so as to preserve their value. The poachers might point to these rhinos and say ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the problem, it‚Äôs not as if they‚Äôre extinct?‚Äù

Yet.

And so that‚Äôs my ‚Äúselfish‚Äù, slightly egocentric reason for why I couldn‚Äôt vote Conservative. I like being a rhino. I‚Äôm a pretty good rhino. I‚Äôm aware that as an analogy it contains its own ideology. I think that ideology needs to be communicated, debated, and refined, perhaps in a future post.

I know that I may be worrying about nothing, that my job might be safe. But there are plenty of people out there whose jobs are not safe now, or who have jobs that will get more stressful, or less secure. I feel their worries as though they are my own.

I‚Äôm also aware that there are other reasons for voting and plenty of room for discussion about what the alternative to the conservatives should be. As you can imagine, I‚Äôve thought about that a lot in recent weeks. It‚Äôs just a matter of getting it all down so that it makes sense.

entry.title: Understated Classics #30: Our Aim Is to Satisfy by Red Snapper
entry.content:
The thirtieth understated classic is by a band named after a fish. There isn‚Äôt a great deal for me to say about ‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy‚Äù1 apart from the usual insistence that it is quite good. There‚Äôs no overarching theme to write about, and no deep personal story attached. It was bound to happen eventually.

‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy‚Äù is one of those albums spawned in the late nineties and early naughties at the height of the Electronica boom: dance music that you didn‚Äôt necessarily have to dance to. It‚Äôs not quite chill out music but nor is it song-based (for the most part) - it‚Äôs mainly instrumental electronic music.

What set Red Snapper apart was an insistence on live percussion. This must have made them quite a compelling proposition live, which must be why the ended up supporting The Prodigy during their tours of ‚ÄúThe Fat of The Land‚Äù. On record I‚Äôm not sure that it translates the same way - many of the drum tracks and bass lines are chopped up, messed up, and mucked around with, so I‚Äôm not sure how to interpret their ‚Äúliveness‚Äù. Perhaps it explains why ‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy‚Äù is so darn funky.

I‚Äôm not going to trawl through the track list the way I usually do. As I said, there‚Äôs no central theme - ‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy‚Äù is just a bunch of tracks really. Some of it sags in the middle and some of it misfires altogether in fact, but the good stuff is very good - and that carries the day.

The opener ‚ÄúKeeping Pigs Together‚Äù is a tense and atmospheric opener - as good as anything on DJ Shadow‚Äôs ‚ÄúEndtroducing‚Äù. Here it‚Äôs not just the live drumming that intrigues, it‚Äôs the texture of the track - it pops and crackles, seemingly caught between nostalgia and propulsion toward the future.

Third track ‚ÄúShellback‚Äù is built around both a cooing vocal line (which I‚Äôve always thought is about a cat) and a snippet of studio dialogue. Studio banter doesn‚Äôt always make for great records - there are a million hip-hop skits that prove this - but it works here. The reason might be the way that it cuts through the pretence that vocals are anything other than another instrument. Meanwhile the backing track is awesome, a plangent stomper - more texture. The watchword on ‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy‚Äù is texture.

I love the way that ‚ÄúThe Rake‚Äù opens with a rap that sounds like it‚Äôs being performed by a smurf with bronchitis. It doesn‚Äôt mean anything and it shifts the attention to the sprightly live percussion (OK when you pay attention the difference is obvious). I also really like the needle in the similarly smurf-like sample that demands ‚ÄúCome on! What‚Äôs the name?!‚Äù over and over throughout.

Built on a similar idea, but less successfully, is ‚ÄúThe Rough and The Quick‚Äù. It sets a frenetic backing to a vocal about various ‚Äútop shelf‚Äù fantasies - I don‚Äôt think it works at all. To my mind, the repetition and harshness of the drum loops doesn‚Äôt come over sexy enough - and the lyrics are just a little too gauche for me.

‚ÄúBussing‚Äù and ‚ÄúI Stole Your Car‚Äù are pretty anonymous, though the latter is still better than most of the tracks on Massive Attack‚Äôs recent ‚ÄúHeligoland‚Äù. The last three tracks are amazing, and are the ones that really do it for me. A downtempo suite of breathtaking beauty, they culminate in ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre Hanging Me Tonight‚Äù - a track that I often include in my playlists - I particularly like the dying feedback and fake CD skips towards the end (or was that in the mp3s from my CD copy? - they don‚Äôt seem to be there on Spotify‚Ä¶).

Red Snapper aim to satisfy and they generally do on this album, which grafts live instruments and electronics in impressive fashion. Largely enjoyable and easy to get immersed in, it has me coming back to it time and time again. Be sure to check it out.

  1. A note on the name of the album, some sources refer to is as ‚ÄúOur Aim Is To Satisfy Red Snapper‚Äù. Personally I think this is ridiculous.¬†↩

entry.title: Consider the Donut
entry.content:
Or, From There to Here With the Simpsons

Old episodes of The Simpsons are great. The other night ‚ÄúBart After Dark‚Äù was on and I really enjoyed seeing it again. It‚Äôs from season eight, the one where Bart ends up working in the Maison Derri√©re. I thought it was older; mind you, this makes it nineteen years old. When I thought about the episode later on that evening, I realised how the story anarchically set out in multiple directions before settling into its main storyline. This still happens in newer Simpsons episodes, though the show is rarely as joyfully chaotic now as it was back then.

It made me realise that my life has followed this same pattern. Settling in to a particular state of affairs after a period of anarchic abandon, with diminishing returns as the years go by. I don‚Äôt believe, as some people seem to, that The Simpsons isn‚Äôt funny anymore. It just can‚Äôt use the same techniques to make its way as it used to, it just got older. I feel the same myself: I used to get by making it up as I went along until something stuck, but nowadays I feel less convinced in my ability to do so.

In the very next episode (Yes! Two consecutive episodes on two consecutive nights! Finally!), ‚ÄúA Milhouse Divided‚Äù, Homer consoles Marge with the following advice: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt keep blaming yourself. Just blame yourself once, and move on.‚Äù There‚Äôs a lot to be said for the wisdom of Homer Simpson - even it is of the broken clock variety. There is a wonderful sense of non-attachment in both that quote from Homer and the scattershot opening to the ‚ÄúBart After Dark‚Äù episode (which, in case you‚Äôve forgotten, veers from V-chip to crashed oil tankers to satirising celebrity charity work to garbage angels to North by North West to caterpillars - before even reaching the burlesque house).

Marge: Homer, is this how you pictured married life?

Homer: Yeah, pretty much, except we drove around in a van solving mysteries.

So even though the episode (s) made me think about the cyclical nature of life, they‚Äôve also reminded me of how important it is to embrace life‚Äôs events in the moment. I too can rock and roll from one situation to another and be confident that it‚Äôll all make sense in the end. And yeah, things may go around and repeat themselves but that‚Äôs a cause for celebration. To repeat the words of Homer: ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt keep blaming yourself. Just blame yourself once, and move on.‚Äù

entry.title: Andy Weir, The Martian
entry.content:
I received a copy of The Martian by Andy Weir for Christmas. This week during some annual leave I managed to finish it. It‚Äôs one of those novels that just flies by once it gets going. I‚Äôve stayed up incredibly late to read it as it is full of those ‚Äújust one more page‚Äù moments. It‚Äôs a readable and enjoyable story of an astronaut trapped on Mars.

Mark Watney is believed to be dead following an accident during an emergency evacuation in a dust storm. With his life support readings at zero and unable to locate his body to be certain, his crew reluctantly abandon him on the red planet.

Mark survives but knows that he does not have enough food or water to survive long enough to be rescued. In the novel missions to Mars operate by sending an ascent vehicle in advance of a future mission - that‚Äôs the rocket that his colleagues escape in on page one. However there‚Äôs another mission, which means that there is another ascent vehicle. If he can work out how to get there and somehow produce some food so he can survive long enough, there is a chance that the next mission can collect him.

Meanwhile NASA discovers that Watney is still alive and makes plans to help him. This is where Weir‚Äôs writing lets him down a little. The characterisation of the secondary characters is weak and some of these sections contain very clunky dialogue. The voice that Weir gives to Mark is unusual and plays against our stereotypes of what we might expect of an astronaut, perhaps even to the point of stretching credibility. This makes all the sections that feature his point of view very entertaining. It‚Äôs a shame that the other bits around those sections feel like clich√©.

I did like the shifting point of view though, it‚Äôs a competent patchwork of styles with Mark‚Äôs journal as the main fabric and various forms of third person narration filling in the gaps. Especially effective are the sections that slow the action down and present Mark at the scale of the empty planet around him. These sections are almost like a film: I imagine huge pull back shots to point where he is a tiny speck on the screen.

I think another writer might have used a more consistent structure. Sometimes it felt like each new development in the plot had to be introduced in a new style or with a new trick. This is a minor quibble, it certainly didn‚Äôt put me off reading to the end. However The Martian is, stylistically at least, almost as ramshackle in places as the protagonist‚Äôs modifications of his gear.

What ultimately saves The Martian and elevates it above a mere Boy‚Äôs Own tale of being lost in space is the forensic attention to detail. The characters may feel a little rusty and the writing a little showy, but the effort put into creating a vivid and believable scenario shines through. It‚Äôs the attention to detail that makes Mark into a credible character that we fight alongside and identify with. I learned a lot about oxygen, hydrogen, water, and carbon dioxide from this novel!

The Martian has an interesting pedigree that puts it alongside books like Fifty Shades of Grey and Hugh Howey‚Äôs Wool in that it was self-published online first, became a big hit in print and is now headed for your movie screen. As soon as the 27th November this year in fact, starring Matt Damon and Jessica Chastain. The film version is directed by Ridley Scott whose sci-fi pedigree includes Alien (making this the second post in a row to hint that I will write about this film soon) and Blade Runner.

The film intrigues me. Obviously I‚Äôm excited to see how The Martian looks on screen but so much of the fun of the novel is communicated in those first person logs and the vivid description of the technical details. It‚Äôll be interesting to see how that works out. I recommend the film on the basis of the novel, though as with any other adaptation I also think you‚Äôll better off enjoying the book first. It‚Äôs a cracking story and the film may address some of the novel‚Äôs flaws, but it‚Äôs harder to see how the intimacy of the first person narrative will come across. It‚Äôs not impossible though, it‚Äôs a trick that Moon managed to pull off. Also Mars movies are generally a disaster at the box office so it will be interesting to see whether The Martian can buck that trend.

To conclude, The Martian by Andy Weir is funny, gritty, exciting, and believable. It‚Äôs good for getting away from it all (it‚Äôs out of this world!) and it‚Äôs good for revisiting school chemistry lessons. Best of all, it makes a strong case for horticultural experiments on manned space missions to include more than just potatoes.

entry.title: Jodorowsky's Dune
entry.content:
Jodorowsky‚Äôs Dune is a documentary about outlandish Chilean director Alejandro Jodorosky‚Äôs attempt at a film adaptation of Frank Herbert‚Äôs Dune in the 1970s. As a big fan of the novel and of science fiction in general, I was very interested in this film. It does not disappoint. It gives a great insight into the mind of a little known (if slightly batty) director and shows even an artistic failure can lead to shock waves that can be felt in later work by others.

Alejandro Jodorowsky had made two internationally acclaimed films prior to his recruitment to develop the film version of ‚ÄúDune‚Äù. ‚ÄúEl Topo‚Äù is often described as an ‚Äúacid western‚Äù - I‚Äôve not seen it but the trailer looks disturbing and bloody. I‚Äôm too scared to embed it here.

Meanwhile ‚ÄúThe Holy Mountain‚Äù is a surrealistic satire of religious belief. You can (for now) watch the entire film on YouTube. Be warned as it is not safe for work and it is not suitable for people who are offended by religious or disturbing imagery. I‚Äôve only watched twenty minutes so far (at the time of writing) but I will make time to watch the rest; it‚Äôs bizarre but compelling viewing.

Jodorowsky‚Äôs Dune allows Alejandro the chance to talk about his vision for Dune - and it‚Äôs a vision that brought together some incredibly talented people. Had he made the film with the actors and musicians who he says agreed to work on it, it truly would have been a cultural reference point that we would all be aware of - for better or worse.

First off, Jodorowsky recruited French bons dessins artist M≈ìbius to sketch out a story board based on Jodorowsky‚Äôs vision for Dune. This resulted in a book the size of a telephone directory that Alejandro regularly hoists on to a coffee table throughout the documentary - a tombstone to mark an unmade film.

Later there are interviews with Chris Foss (who I now realise drew the covers of some of my favourite sci-fi novels - like the Asimov robot novels), Dan O‚ÄôBannon, and HR Giger. These last two would collaborate later on Alien - to terrifying and ground breaking effect (More on Alien to come‚Ä¶). Some of the music was to be performed by Pink Floyd. However, it‚Äôs telling that no evidence of their contributions is offered - not even so much as interview with Dave Gilmour or Roger Waters. All we can know is that it would have been better than Toto‚Äôs dreck for the 1984 film (more on which later). The documentary is full of Moebius, Foss, and Giger‚Äôs creative contributions to the pre-production design, but it appears that the sound design was never entered into, at least not by Pink Floyd.

Jodorowsky also claims to have recruited Orson Welles, Mick Jagger, and Salvador Dali (!) to various roles. Orson Welles is dead so can‚Äôt comment and Jagger is conspicuously absent, so I guess we have to take Alejandro‚Äôs word for it. Meanwhile the tale of Dali‚Äôs recruitment to play the Emporer of the Universe is so bizarre it must be true. It is also confirmed by Dali‚Äôs muse of the time, who was also offered a role (it was one of Dali‚Äôs conditions - along with being paid more than any other actor ever at the time, something that Jodorowsky got around by restricting Dali‚Äôs screen time to three minutes).

I think Jodorowsky‚Äôs Dune offers a tantalising glimpse at what could have been a great film. The conceptual art looks great even today - the success that O‚ÄôBannon and Giger had with Alien goes a long way to upholding this and speaks volumes to how Jodorowsky‚Äôs treatment for Dune has influenced the science fiction aesthetic that prevails to this day.

The version of Dune that did get made also influences the documentary. It‚Äôs objectively terrible - to the point that some cuts are credited to Alan Smithee rather than the usually competent David Lynch. One of the best moments of Jodorowsky‚Äôs Dune is where Alejandro describes being dragged to a screening of the Lynch version: ‚ÄúI was really happy when I saw it‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt want to see it‚Ä¶ but IT WAS TERRIBLE!‚Äù. His laughter quickly becomes rueful, the Schadenfreude of someone who knows that they are right.

This documentary is a great little film, particularly if you like Dune or are interested in how films are made. The introduction to Jodorowsky himself is a bonus. His wit and enthusiasm throughout show that if you dream big, you can‚Äôt really ever fail.

entry.title: How Fireworks Work
entry.content:
Last night an impromptu firework display occurred. I watched it from my bathroom window. Very pretty and somewhat extravagant, given that there‚Äôs no reason for one on the calendar. I could have filmed it on meerkat but it would have diminished the spectacle. However, it did at least motivate me to write this piece that I have put off for a while (since about November I guess?). One where I find out (i.e. look up on Wikipedia) how fireworks work.

Fireworks are essentially showy explosions, so the way they ‚Äúwork‚Äù from a practical point of view is the same as how gunpowder works. Light the fuse, and an exothermic reaction emits lots of energy in the form of light, heat, and a big bang.

The Chinese introduced the aesthetic element in the 7th Century (CE) and fireworks developed into a major part of Chinese culture. In Britain, fireworks have supplanted the more traditional burning of the Guy on ‚Äúbonfire night‚Äù. It is likely that this transition occurred once China opened up to trade in the 1800s.

There are lots of ways to classify fireworks: ground-based versus aerial, noise-focussed (make as big a bang as possible) versus aesthetics focussed (ooh pretty), and so on. I suppose I should focus on aerial fireworks as they were the ones that I could see from my window. And they were pretty, so let‚Äôs look at why.

We can split prettiness further in to colours and patterns. For the aerial side of things, we will also consider how this can be used to make patterns.

When it comes to colours, it‚Äôs a matter of chemistry. You will no doubt be familiar with the bright white light emitted by burning magnesium, it‚Äôs one of the only experiments I remember from school chemistry lessons. (I also remember one with Bromine which really turned me off Chemistry. Achievement unlocked: make a joke about Bromine that no one will get.) Different metals glow different colours when they burn, so that‚Äôs basically that. It‚Äôs quite difficult to do precisely, which is why you tend to notice a ‚Äúnew‚Äù colour or why particular colours appear rarely. Last night I noticed a lot of magenta, so maybe that‚Äôs easier to produce now.

For patterns you have to think meta. You have a serious of explosions occurring at different times in different areas of space. You can control the time of ignition with the length of the fuse and you can control the trajectory of launch by orienting your sub-fireworks in a particular fashion around the bit that explodes. It‚Äôs quite an exciting problem in physics and optimisation to create particular patterns and time them together. Obviously sometimes you fire multiple rockets because that‚Äôs easier, you just time it so looks like that the second bursts of stars erupted from where the first ones died back.

In many ways, fireworks are a physical form of generative art. Now there‚Äôs something to think about - how could you apply the techniques of generative art to produce even better OMG firework displays? Competitive firework displays, now that‚Äôs something I could get into!

entry.title: A Little Bit Intimidating Really
entry.content:
There is so much good writing out there. All you have to do is fire up the guardian website, or download the medium app to your smartphone, or visit my friend Barrie‚Äôs site, or Lee‚Äôs, and so on and so on.

When it comes to my little whisper into this great choir, it‚Äôs easy to feel a bit intimidated. How do I add my voice? How do I feel distinct? How do I do it as well as all these other wonderful writers?

You might think that after nearly four years and over five hundred posts, I might be less timorous. I can assure you that I still feel nervous about every single post. Almost every time I write a post I get hung up on a detail that prevents me writing. I find the biggest source of writer‚Äôs block is worrying about whether any of it matters.

And does any of it matter? Not particularly, not in the grand scheme of things. One thing I appreciate more after four years is that you do have to let things go. You can accept that you won‚Äôt win on the first try.

As with most good things in life, it is more gratifying to succeed after a struggle. I don‚Äôt believe that simply turning up again and again entitles you to succeed. However, I believe that when you do, you accept the challenge of learning and adapting.

The beauty of life is that as you get better at something, you find new aspects to improve upon and new things that make you worry. Even with this self-awareness you will struggle and get stuck, sometimes you can improve too much in one go and leave yourself open to regression to the mean. It‚Äôs like training for a run, at any given time you can only put in a sustainable effort - if you try too hard too soon you might injure yourself.

I may well find it intimidating that there is so much other good writing out there but I also know that it is there for me to enjoy, that it communicates to me in a special way. The last few years made me realise that I am in the world, that the world is beautiful, and I am very happy to take my place in it.

My name is Matthew and I‚Äôd like to say hello.

entry.title: Ned Beauman, Glow
entry.content:
Glow is about a guy called Raf, a Londoner whose life is going nowhere in particular; a state of affairs not helped by ‚ÄúNon-24 Hour Sleep/Wake Syndrome‚Äù. One night while experimenting with a new ecstacy-like drug that‚Äôs apparently derived from a social anxiety medication for dogs, Raf meets a beautiful girl and then loses her to the crowd in a blink-and-you-miss-it moment. From there a conspiracy evolves involving the titular dog-medication-derived drug, Burmese dissidents, corporate espionage, pirate radio stations, and urban foxes.

Here are the opening lines:

When he first sees her, Raf is sitting on a washing machine about to swallow an eighth of a gram of what is apparently a mixture of speed, monosodium glutamate, and an experimental social anxiety disorder medicine for dogs.

You can tell from this that the tone is irreverent from the outset. This helps when the plot unravels toward the end: it peters out when it could have gone further. Instead you get a shaggy dog story with some sparkling comic writing thrown in, the jokes come thick and fast and had me laughing aloud. The quirky descriptions of modern life in London and the folksy homages to neuroscience (or perhaps, ‚Äúnear‚Äù-o-science) keep proceedings belting along at a good pace even if the plot fails to serve up the thriller-like tension you might expect from the same story in the hands of a genre writer.

It reminds me of Thomas Pynchon‚Äôs Inherent Vice, another superbly written tranche of comic set pieces trawling through a conspiracy theory all served up in a druggy haze. Beauman‚Äôs writing sometimes seems a little too arch and self-conscious compared to Pynchon. Pynchon always holds his nerve, even with silly character names and when dispensing with any sort of plot altogether.

The other thing that linka Glow to Inherent Vice is its strong evocation of a particular time and place. Inherent Vice is set at the end of the sixties, just as people are starting to realise that flower power is no kind of power at all. There‚Äôs a strong sense of the hippy dream beginning to sour. Glow is set in 2010 and most of the novel occurs within two weeks, save for two codas. Perhaps we will look back on this time as another when dreams turned sour. This time maybe the idea that our smart phones and the internet have freed us to pursue pleasure. Or perhaps even the notion that scientists would imminently solve the puzzle of the brain.

Glow is chock full of social media and postmodern ideas but conspicuously free of what you might call ‚Äúproper politics‚Äù, dealing instead with nebulous ideas about corporations, surveillance, and personal freedom - there are no Syrians or North Koreans or the like. No one runs amok on these streets. While Inherent Vice‚Äôs take on the past feels like ‚Äútelling it like it is‚Äù, Glow feels a little short in this sense.

At the end of the day Glow is a well-written boy meets girl story with a bit of silly drug stuff wrapped around it. I enjoyed it and read it quickly, a voracious rush of giddy excitement followed by a slight comedown afterwards. A bit like the mythical glow. I will check out Ned‚Äôs other novels (Glow is his third) and I look forward to reading what he tries in the future.

Notes

  1. The featured image is Benjamin McMahon‚Äôs fox motif from the cover remixed. I actually produced some more bizarre versions but decided on this variant to keep things simple.
  2. Talking of Inherent Vice, I haven‚Äôt seen the film yet. I just missed it at the cinema, so I eagerly await the DVD.
  3. The next book on my pile is Andy Weir‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Martian‚Äù.

entry.title: You Can‚Äôt Just Switch Off Free
entry.content:
Ministry of Sound boss Lohan Presencer does the cry baby act in today‚Äôs Guardian, complaining that Spotify‚Äôs freemium model doesn‚Äôt allow him to bathe in a Scrooge McDuck style swimming pool of golden coins any more. The cat is out of the bag for streaming music now, and no matter how much music companies cry foul they can‚Äôt stop Spotify and their ilk, and there wouldn‚Äôt be pots of gold waiting for them even if they could.

Presencer goes on to say that he fears for artist development in this post-streaming world. Personally I think he‚Äôs more worried about whether he can sell any more shitty themed compilations that aren‚Äôt dance music but nonetheless trade on Ministry of Sound‚Äôs credentials. But let‚Äôs take him at face value and explore this point. Will allowing people to stream some of the music that they like for free affect artist development?

It Used to Be Called Radio

Well I grew up listening to the radio and I never paid a penny for it. Most stations, were - like Spotify is now - supported by advertising revenue, a proportion of which goes to the artists and the supporting industry of talentless leeches like Presencer. Apparently radio stations still exist and have existed throughout the history of recorded music, during which time the number of new artists and genres has increased over and over.

(Unfortunately most radio stations in the UK are now part of a soulless megacorp designed to do nothing but sell advertising. The group is called Global radio and I had a job interview with them last year. It was pretty close to my own personal hell - and the pay would have been shit too.)

Home Taping Didn‚Äôt Kill Music, and Neither Will Piracy or Streaming

Moreover, there have always been pirate stations broadcasting up and coming music from hidden transmitters for no reason other than enthusiasm for the music itself. Artists have never received royalties from these stations but the exposure has been priceless for countless artists.

Music piracy seems like a starker threat to business model of record companies and to the commercial prospects of artists. I am convinced piracy has hit artists hard, though many have thrived by adapting to rather than pouting against illegal downloads.

For an artist, piracy at least means there is someone out there listening to your music. If your music is good, an emotional connection can be forged with your listeners. They will seek you out and support you. Even if only a fraction do, it should be possible to convert that to sales of things that cannot be pirated: merchandise, live experiences, the chance of genuine connection.

Before the invention of the radio, an artist would only ever be heard by the people who he performed to.
