It‚Äôs annoying that there is no clear way that the names of the distributions become the stem at the heart of those d-, p-, q-, and r- functions. Is it the first four letters? No, it‚Äôs the first three letters for the exponential distribution and (not the first) five letters for the negative binomial distribution. (And the whole name when you start looking at things like the Weibull distribution.) Obviously you learn the names after you use them for a while. And to repeat, it is also strange that you can‚Äôt pass the name of a distribution (or your own pdf) to a more generic function. Mind you, such generic functions would have to handle the gamut of idiosyncrasies of different probability distributions. Maybe it is better this way.

I will add more distributions later. It will also be useful to work out how to generate samples from my own pdfs. I will add instructions for this later. There are also tests to checking hypotheses that data follow a particular distribution and I will add instructions for this in another post.

Generating random numbers for change of state

Often this is simply a case of generating uniform random numbers in [0,1]. You can use runif(1) because 0.0 and 1.0 are the default values for min and max for runif. The seed changes each time you start R. If you need to use the same seed to repeat previous work, you can use the set.seed function before using runic. Check out the R man page for Random Number Generation for more detail. This always feels like something that I should know more thoroughly, yet every time I come to random number generation I skim the literature to convince myself it works and then I leave it at that. Generally I tend to stick to the state of the art in what happens to ‚Äòjust work‚Äô and then hammer that.

I‚Äôll add other techniques that use other distributions later. I think particularly of the negative binomial distribution but I want to write a separate post about that a later date. When I write that post I‚Äôll add the relevant R code to this post (and the Java to the Java post, and so on).

Generating your lottery numbers

The lottery is a mug‚Äôs game, but you definitely won‚Äôt win if you never play. (Technically if you don‚Äôt play you can‚Äôt lose, and lotteries set you up to lose: the clue is in the name.) Nevertheless, for special occasions when you might want to quickly generate lottery numbers, or N integers in some other range, you should use sample(6,1:49) for your lucky ticket, or sample(numSamples,low:high) for the more general case.

Other notes

It also goes without saying that it‚Äôs a great idea to use the amazing help in R.

entry.title: Evie Wyld, All The Birds, Singing
entry.content:
I recently finished reading All The Birds, Singing, the second novel by Evie Wyld. It‚Äôs about a woman called Jake who lives alone on a farm with a dog called Dog on an island somewhere off the coast of Britain. She has sheep to look after but something keeps coming in the middle of the night to kill them.

Meanwhile, as the narrative on the island moves forward in the present, a second narrative peels off backwards to explain her past. This takes place in Australia. Jake is still working with sheep but there is a confrontation with a fellow farmhand who threatens to expose a secret from her past. As this second strand unfurls, we begin to see why Jake is jumpy and convinced that the deaths of her sheep represent ill-portent. However, because this second story rolls backwards in jumps, we have to wait until the end for the terrible events that set her on this path.

Wyld uses the two narratives to drive the plot and it does a good job at keeping you reading. The structure is one I‚Äôve encountered before in Iain M. Banks‚Äô Use of Weapons where it is used to devastating effect. The secret at the heart of ‚ÄúAll The Birds, Singing‚Äù does not quite have the same impact as a chair made of bone, but this protects the plot from being overwhelmed by the device and appearing contrived.

The voyage into Jake‚Äôs past is dark one, though it is brightened by comic episodes and the strong character of Jake who you are always rooting for. Meanwhile the action in the present grinds a little at first, but picks up pace in later chapters so that past to present and back again happens in a blur of pages. The story of what is happening to Jake‚Äôs sheep is a red herring, there‚Äôs no reason for it given within the pages of the novel (sorry for the minor spoiler) and for some readers this might be a disappointment. However, because of how the novel is constructed, the payoff for the reader is finding out what happened in her past.

Good novels tend to have a big idea at their core. In All The Birds, Singing the big idea at play is how our memories become crystallised in our past and protected by us, to be endlessly revisited and protected from others who might challenge them. Jake is shown in the present time line to be phoning her family but is never able to say anything. You get the impression that she seeks forgiveness but at the same time denies it to herself. The fact that the time line in the present is unresolved by the end of the novel and that it is so sketchy points to how we need time to process and develop our memories. We are so often defined by things that occur in the heat of a moment, and it takes a long time for the wounds to heal and for scars to form. Eventually we live with our wounds and scars because there is no other option and All The Birds, Singing is an excellent description of that process.

Links to other reviews of All The Birds, Singing

  1. Tim Lewis for The Observer.
  2. Jeff Vendermeer on Ecstatic Days.

entry.title: Album Digest, August 2014
entry.content:
The album digest returns with five albums by four artists.

  1. Karl Hyde & Brian Eno Someday World & HIGH-LIFE
  2. Lone Reality Testing
  3. FKA twigs LP1
  4. Mogwai Come On Die Young: Appendix

Karl Hyde & Brian Eno Someday World & HIGH-LIFE

I‚Äôm a big fan of both Karl Hyde‚Äôs work with Underworld and of Brian Eno‚Äôs stuff so Someday World seemed like a dream collaboration to me when it was released last May. I was a bit underwhelmed by it, to the point of overlooking it for May‚Äôs album digest. Last month they released a follow-up called High-Life, which includes some of the more experimental tracks they‚Äôd worked on. Together the two albums are greater than the some of their parts, so I‚Äôm writing about both of them together this month.

Someday World is improved with the hindsight that High-Life offers but it was a pretty decent album to begin with. It is song-based and so I assume that Brian Eno‚Äôs influence is more hidden in the details and it is these that emerge in High-Life, which is looser and more jam-based. Anyway there are some cracking songs on Someday World, it just runs out of steam toward the end. ‚ÄúThe Satellites‚Äù would have graced any of the last four Underworld albums, ‚ÄúDaddy‚Äôs Car‚Äù is a sweet bit of summery nostalgia, and ‚ÄúWitness‚Äù demonstrates that all those spoken word sequences on Underworld records weren‚Äôt entirely down to Rick Smith after all.

High-Life offers longer tracks and just one full-blown song, ‚ÄúCells & Bells‚Äù, which closes the album. Instead there‚Äôs the upbeat and funky ‚ÄúDBF‚Äù with its sinuous guitar riff that‚Äôs ripe for a remix by someone like Daphni and the gorgeous nine minute stretch of ‚ÄúLilac‚Äù, which is one of those gorgeous open-ended pieces that Underworld used to be so fond of making before they went all pop on Barking.

So this is a good pair of albums that complement each other - after listening to High-Life you can appreciate the more technical aspects of Someday World that are hidden by the more conventional songwriting. Meanwhile Someday World helps invest the more abstract moments of High-Life with emotional meaning. They aren‚Äôt quite complementary but each certainly enhances the other. Could they be compressed into a single album? Probably not. By releasing two, Karl Hyde and Brian Eno have given us the best of both worlds without making too many artistic compromises.

Lone Reality Testing

I really like Lone‚Äôs music but I have no idea how to write about it so this may be a rather short review. I had the same problem with his last album ‚ÄúGalaxy Garden‚Äù in 2012, I loved it and listened to it loads but despite plans to write about it, I never managed to find the way to write about it in an album digest.

I would describe the music on ‚ÄúReality Testing‚Äù as being a bit like a Mondrian painting - Lone abstracts dance music into something so structured and polished that you can‚Äôt help but admire it, much in a way that Mondrian‚Äôs compositions turn painting into something algebraic and modern. Nevertheless it‚Äôs very hard to explain what a Mondrian painting is and expresses, and I find the same to be true of Lone‚Äôs music.

Everything sounds like a million dollars. There are huge diving synth sweeps, housy piano licks, muscular hip-hop beats, even the tropes of drum‚Äôn‚Äôbass. It‚Äôs all glossy and warm, like something that should soundtrack footage of a trendy holiday destination. I always see Lisbon or San Francisco‚Äôs trams when I listen to tracks like ‚ÄúRestless City‚Äù.

There are plenty of easy references to spot, like the Future Sound Of London on ‚ÄúAurora Northern Quarter‚Äù, and The Go Team on ‚Äú2 is 8‚Äù. The centrepiece ‚ÄúAirglow Fires‚Äù is as smart and sensible a piece of dance music as you could wish for, aimed square at the dance floor and good times like a slightly less frenetic Disclosure track.

So yes, I like this, it‚Äôs so perfect and well-made, but it‚Äôs hard to actually describe the emotion involved. Perhaps eventually I‚Äôll grok it better, perhaps no one is meant to. Perhaps it is just enough to enjoy it and why not, ‚ÄúReality Testing‚Äù certainly is an enjoyable album.

FKA twigs LP1

After a month or so I am still not sure about twigs‚Äô d√©but album LP1. I am convinced it‚Äôs a unique sounding album and it has to be commended for its daring approach. The way she flits from dirty talk on ‚ÄúTwo Weeks‚Äù to cooing sweetly on ‚ÄúPendulum‚Äù demonstrates that she has a lot of ground she can cover. Nonetheless it‚Äôs also uneven, perhaps by design, and at first all the trapdoor beats and pitch-shifted vocals make it hard to settle in close to the songs and enjoy them.

Listening to LP1 made me think about how my relationship to new music has changed in recent years. This album has come along much hyped and I found it quite disappointing at first: I thought of it as a mere re-tread of Tricky‚Äôs Maxinequaye nearly twenty years on but without any of the eccentricities that made Tricky‚Äôs debut seem so new and dangerous. But what if it seemed that way because I was young and na√Øve? Perhaps I am too old for this sort of thing. Her tunes are postmodern and deconstructed, all shiny and new, and that has always been a young person‚Äôs game. However the ideas underpinning the songs are pretty standard: they‚Äôre about sex, fame, and ennui. Saying what‚Äôs been said before but with sleeker, trendier, beats doesn‚Äôt automatically make something interesting or valuable.

In fact when she swings closer to existing records and doesn‚Äôt try so hard she has more success. ‚ÄúNumbers‚Äù is a fantastic song that sounds like early Portishead and as it progresses she starts to break down all its elements. With a decent tune and a reference point, it‚Äôs easier to understand her experiments with the beats and the voices.

The songs crammed with crazier ideas are worth persevering with. ‚ÄúTwo Weeks‚Äù throws everything at you as though twigs has everything to prove: think of an X Factor audition performed with music production software rather than vocal histrionics. When she duets with a chipmunked version of herself on ‚ÄúCloser‚Äù it makes no sense in terms of the song but it does sound really cool. ‚ÄúKicks‚Äù introduces more chipmunks while also incorporating mutant samples of her voice into the backing track, this is probably what Bj√∂rk was going for with Medulla.

As I said, I am not sure about this album. It‚Äôs possible that in a year‚Äôs time I will completely understand all these songs and know them inside and out but it will obviously take a while for them all to bed down. I think it‚Äôs worth sticking with. I do believe in twigs as an artist and I don‚Äôt think I would have bothered to mention Tricky, Portishead, and Bj√∂rk if I didn‚Äôt. I predict that LP2 will be better than LP1 and once she‚Äôs pinned down her sound, I think she will write fantastic songs.

Mogwai Come On Die Young: Appendix

My beautiful vinyl box set of the Come On Die Young remaster finally arrived and, as promised, here are some notes on the bonus material, or ‚Äúappendix‚Äù as the box would have it.

I really like the two songs that I‚Äôd not heard before ‚ÄúNick Drake‚Äù and ‚ÄúHugh Dallas‚Äù. I think they‚Äôve been released before but I‚Äôd not heard them. ‚ÄúNick Drake‚Äù sounds a lot like other tracks on CODY, perhaps a little more chilled, I think it was dropped from the track list quite late. It opens the appendix album and I think this makes me think of it fitting well near the start of CODY, perhaps nestled in between the title track and ‚ÄúHelps Both Ways‚Äù. ‚ÄúHugh Dallas‚Äù is longer and more open-ended, certainly more subtle than any of the longer tracks on the album proper, it has a soft vocal and I think it‚Äôs even better than ‚Äúcody‚Äù.

The demo of ‚ÄúHelps Both Ways‚Äù is included and features its original American Football sample that didn‚Äôt get cleared for the album, it includes the line ‚Äúhe helps both ways‚Äù and explains the title. Personally I prefer the album version for all the reasons I gave in my understated classics post. Elsewhere the other demos for tracks that later appeared on CODY are almost all more muted than the finished versions and demonstrate the fantastic job the band did with Dave Friedman on opening up the tracks and making them more expansive - the demos feel flatter and without as much space. Sometimes they are more melodic, as with the version of ‚ÄúEx-Cowboy‚Äù in which the quiet-loud dynamics of the finished track barely appear.

It‚Äôs also good to have the tracks from the ‚ÄúTravels In Constants EP‚Äù again as I lost my copy a while back, I think it was a loan made permanent somewhere. ‚ÄúArundel‚Äù is creepy and stately, all piano and effects pedal.

Overall the material in the appendix is far better than I was expected it to be and makes for almost as good a listen as its parent album. You get so many reissues where the bonus material is an afterthought but here it‚Äôs a delight to listen to. I‚Äôm really glad that I invested in the box set.

Album Digest August 2014 - Digested

Here‚Äôs a playlist of this month‚Äôs albums so that you can listen along at home. It sounds pretty good shuffled; the Mogwai tracks stand out a bit but they are older than the others (and demos at that).

Next month will definitely feature an album called ‚ÄúPunish, Honey‚Äù by Vessel. I‚Äôve heard a track from it called ‚ÄúRed Sex‚Äù and it is amazing. I will probably write about ‚ÄúLOSE‚Äù by Cymbals Eat Guitars too because there is a dearth of quality guitar rock at the moment and ‚ÄúLOSE‚Äù sounds pretty good.

entry.title: Haruki Murakami, Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki And His Years Of Pilgrimage
entry.content:
Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki And His Years Of Pilgrimage is the latest novel by Haruki Murakami. It comes with free stickers. Perhaps that tells you everything you need to know about this book, which is slimmer than Murakami‚Äôs recent efforts. The plot begins with an intriguing premise. Tsukuru is part of a group of close friends and is one day expelled from the group for no reason. Unfortunately, the development of the plot is uncontrolled and by the end of novel too many holes have developed for it all to hold together.

It is a pleasant read but a familiar one. You can play Murakami bingo with Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki. Will there be Jazz or classical music? (Or, potential spoiler, both?) Will the character at the centre of the action make pasta? Or drink Cutty Sark whisky? Will they have an infatuation from childhood that will haunt their adult life? Will a strange dream-like world enter into our reality at some point? Will the books that Murakami‚Äôs been reading all-too-obviously force their way in to the narrative at some point? Will there be an endearing cat simile?

If you‚Äôve read a lot of Murakami novels, you won‚Äôt need to re-read it when you are done, and if you haven‚Äôt, well I can suggest at least three better books with similar plots that you will probably enjoy more than Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki.

Murakami‚Äôs last novel ‚Äú1Q84‚Äù was so huge that it had to be split into three books. It too was a shaggy dog story that became a love story at the end. It even had a happy ending. It also had a variant of almost all the Murakami bingo elements. For example, a chapter called ‚ÄúThe town of the cats‚Äù manages to hit peak cat. As I mentioned above because ‚Äú1Q84‚Äù was longer, there was enough space to resolve most of the plot points. In Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki there are plot points that are completely unresolved by the end of the novel. In some ways this mirrors the unresolution of the whole novel but it feels lazy and cynical, unless there is the possibility of a sequel.

If you believe that Murakami should be cut some slack for the ingeniously blank prose that is able to endow the slightest deviation from normality with a shivery strangeness, then there is a little more for you here than for the rest of us. Even so, it still doesn‚Äôt come close to the utterly bonkers ‚ÄúDance Dance Dance‚Äù or the slow strange unfolding of his masterpiece ‚ÄúThe Wind-up Bird Chronicle‚Äù. In many ways the whole thing feels like two novellas fighting it out to be a novel: one a realistic story about friendship, time, and memory; the other a surreal concoction about spirit colours, demonic jazz pianists, soul murder and how the world connects to the realm of dreams. In my favourite Murakami novel ‚ÄúHard-boiled Wonderland and The End Of The World‚Äù he has the same problem and solves it simply by presenting the two stories completely separated from one another and in parallel. ‚Äú1Q84‚Äù just about managed to pull off a fusion of these two styles, but in a tighter framework Murakami just can‚Äôt do it this time around.

entry.title: Useful Ulysses
entry.content:
What it is

Ulysses is a markdown editor for the Mac. It has a simple drafting model that makes it easy to organise ideas and move between them. Pieces of writing are represented as sheets that can be tagged and grouped together - the grouping can be made manually or using filters. There are no files, the sheets are entries in a single database that is synced with iCloud. Because everything is plain text it won‚Äôt eat up your storage space. Individual sheets can be archived for use with Mac Os X‚Äôs versions feature.

You can get a companion app for iOS called Daedalus Touch that will also sync to iCloud, but I have not tried that yet.

Ulysses is full of useful features: when a word count is set a simple indicator tells you whether you have met the target yet. Images can be attached to sheets but I find it easier to deal with images in the WordPress post editor so I have not used this feature a lot. You can easily export to HTML, RTF, PDF, and ePub formats - with the option to preview beforehand. The HTML preview can be copied to the clipboard, which is great for blog posts.

Why it helps

I now use Ulysses III to write nearly all of my posts. I use it to start writing anything long form, even if I have to transfer it to another format later (as is the case with blog posts). Because of the grouping features I can keep blog stuff away from other works in progress. Within particular projects Ulysses encourages structure, which is something that I like a lot.

I like to brainstorm lots of ideas for posts. I set up multiple sheets in a group and type out the titles, while sketching out notes and details as markdown comments. Because my ideas are arranged into groups (by theme, whether research is required, etc), I can make sure my posts are varied1 in terms of subject and depth.

The word count targets make sure that I write enough for each post (and help me to identify quick wins in posts that are nearly finished). The export feature introduces another chance to edit into the writing process, so I feel like my writing is getting checked more often.

Because almost every feature can be accessed from the keyboard, time spent in the app is mostly spent with your hands down typing not rooting for some buried feature in the menu system or tapping some icon.

Any drawbacks?

Ulysses III doesn‚Äôt implement Mac OS X‚Äôs system-wide autocorrect and the spell check doesn‚Äôt show mistakes as you type. This might not be the worst drawback because you can still check through words at the end, besides there‚Äôs nothing more frustrating than when OS X decides to change a word that you are typing when you are still halfway through it.

I think that it is a shame that you can‚Äôt export comments to HTML. Most of the time you don‚Äôt need outline comments in finished code but it would be useful if I could export various metadata to WordPress in the form of comments. I have asked the developers whether they might consider a toggle in the settings and they responded quickly to say that they‚Äôd consider it.

All my other minor problems are ones of how to better manage moving what I write from Ulysses over to WordPress but even so I think the process is already as frictionless as it can be.

It would be amazing if someone were to write a Ulysses-style LaTeX editor.

I got it half price and that was about the right price for its usefulness. This means that at the moment it is about twice the price that it really should be. By anyone‚Äôs definition that makes it expensive.

Is this an ad?

Not really, I am just sharing the tools that I use for creating things. I also wanted to share what I like about software that I use regularly, so that I am more aware of those things in future. I‚Äôve deliberately not used any of their logos in the hero image, which is ULYSSES by Fedor √ò, (cc-by-nc-sa-2.0).

  1. Forget that crap about finding your niche! I say write ALL THE THINGS!¬†↩

entry.title: Understated Classics #27: A Ghost Is Born by Wilco
entry.content:
I have already given some of the personal background to why I love this album and now it‚Äôs time to give a bit of love to the music itself so I‚Äôll stick to giving a track by track account of ‚ÄúA Ghost Is Born‚Äù.

If you are familiar with Wilco‚Äôs first few albums, you‚Äôll know that A Ghost Is Born is on the line of best fit through Being There, Summerteeth, and Yankee Hotel Foxtrot. It continues its predecessor‚Äôs experimentation, but also gets reined in a little. Great songs - some of my favourite Wilco songs - were left off Yankee Hotel Foxtrot (‚ÄúVenus Stopped The Train‚Äù, ‚ÄúA Magazine Called Sunset‚Äù) so the follow-up could easily have been more of the same and everyone would have gone home happy.

It is to Wilco‚Äôs credit then that they set out push the envelope again. It is not quite the shock to the system that Yankee Hotel Foxtrot was, but nor is it the hangover that early reviews first implied. If Yankee‚Ä¶ demonstrated that a modern Wilco was possible, then for the most part A Ghost Is Born takes the baton and runs with it.

Your purple-black eye

The opener ‚ÄúAt Least That‚Äôs What You Said‚Äù pulls no punches, there‚Äôs no slurred wordplay as with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Trying To Break Your Heart‚Äù ‚Äî here the damage has already been done, the heart already is broken, the narrator nurses a black eye, and both the people in the song need some time alone.

Musically it‚Äôs beautifully reserved, a minimal backing holding back until two minutes in when a squall of guitars come through1 and lay the real emotional trauma at the heart of the song bare before your ears. It is one of those beautiful songs (like ‚ÄúDance Yourself Clean‚Äù by LCD Soundsystem) that tricks you into turning it up because it starts so quietly, and then BAM BAM BAM the guitar solo gets you.

‚ÄúHell is Chrome‚Äù ‚Äî the song that indirectly gave this blog its name, as you are no doubt tired of hearing by now ‚Äî is a more sedate affair. It tells of the devil coming to the song‚Äôs narrator and not being red, but chrome, and offering the world‚Äôs clean surfaces as a special kind of hell. Again the guitar solos scrape across the song midway through to take the place of a chorus but it doesn‚Äôt happen again throughout the record so we‚Äôll forgive them.

It‚Äôs good to be alone

I was genuinely shocked the first time I ever heard ‚ÄúSpiders (kidsmoke)‚Äù, it is such a departure compared to their previous work. As for when they played it live, that totally blew me away. It‚Äôs a ten minute piece of motorik riffing that would sound more in place on a Neu! or a CAN record. It was very strange to hear it played within twenty minutes of ‚ÄúCalifornia Stars‚Äù. I think the best thing about it is that they‚Äôve never revisited that sound (perhaps ‚ÄúArt of Almost‚Äù on ‚ÄúThe Whole Love‚Äù comes close) so it always sounds new and strange, and the weird lyrics about ‚Äúall these telescopic poems‚Äù, ‚Äúspiders‚Ä¶ filling out tax returns‚Ä¶ on a private beach in Michigan‚Äù and ‚ÄúI just do what I am told‚Äù just make it all the better.

By comparison the gentle sweep of ‚ÄúMuzzle of bees‚Äù zips by in a blur, something like a gentler and less consequential ‚ÄúJesus, etc‚Äù, so that I often hardly notice it (but I always enjoy it when I do). ‚ÄúHummingbird‚Äù shows of Jeff Tweedy‚Äôs affection for White Album era McCartney songs, it‚Äôs pretty much ‚ÄúMartha My Dear‚Äù recast as Americana with some proper lyrics that McCartney couldn‚Äôt be bothered to put into the original2.

I was chewing gum as something to do

‚ÄúHandshake Drugs‚Äù completes the section of ‚Äústraight‚Äù songs that make up the middle of A Ghost Is Born. Unlike the very earnest songs of Yankee‚Ä¶ (‚ÄúI‚Äôm the Man Who Loves You‚Äù, ‚ÄúKamera‚Äù), these are very downcast and understated, none more so than ‚ÄúHandshake Drugs‚Äù which puts a blank smile on the face of a song about prescription drug abuse.

The album‚Äôs beautiful ambient core is ‚ÄúWishful Thinking‚Äù, a straight-up ode to the beauty of knowledge that tinkles the ivories and gently coos. There‚Äôs some lovely lines in there, I particularly like ‚ÄúThe turntable sizzles / Casting the spells‚Äù and I adore how it mixes up sadness, thirst for knowledge, and romance all in to one beautiful song. Looking closer at the lyrics I understand now why ‚ÄúPanthers‚Äù was not included on the album and later issued as a bonus track - it overlaps lyrically with ‚ÄúWishful Thinking‚Äù.

‚ÄúCompany In My Back‚Äù is a great little song, one of many Wilco songs that take a quirky lyrical idea and glues it to a quirky riff. It‚Äôs going around my head as I think of it now and of course the lyric ‚ÄúI will always die so you can remember me‚Äù fits in very well with the album‚Äôs title.

I‚Äôll lay it down, a ghost is born

‚ÄúI‚Äôm A Wheel‚Äù is a pallette-cleansing bit of punky noise, a song that dislodged the similar sounding ‚ÄúKicking Television‚Äù from the track list. Both tracks are pretty inconsequential and I wonder if ‚ÄúKicking Television‚Äù didn‚Äôt come along too late to be on the album (it was played for the first time at the Portsmouth gig) because I think it‚Äôs the better song.

Then along comes ‚ÄúTheologians‚Äù with all its anti-religious bluster ‚ÄúTheologians‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt know nothing about my soul‚Äù and the repeated chorus of ‚Äúa ghost is born‚Äù. The end refrain of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a cherry ghost‚Äù lends a surreal aspect to the song and yet somehow makes complete sense.

Fill up your mind with all it can know

The next track ‚ÄúLess Than You Think‚Äù lasts for fifteen minutes. It begins with the line ‚ÄúYour mind‚Äôs a machine, deadly and dull‚Ä¶‚Äù and continues to relate a metaphor about migraines, before it collapses into a drone just after three minutes in. Conceptually that is very interesting but it makes for a rather dull listen once you‚Äôve got the idea sorted in your head. I ripped about four minutes from the CD and that was enough for me.

The album ends with ‚ÄúThe Late Greats‚Äù, a great song that was apparently added to the track listing at the last minute. It has a wonderful throwaway sound to it and it‚Äôs very straightforward, yet somehow it would not sit as perfectly as it does on any other Wilco album. It‚Äôs a beautiful chiming song about the ephemeral nature of pop music: ‚ÄúThe best songs never get sung / the best laugh never leaves your lungs / it‚Äôs so good you will never know / they never even played a show‚Äù (a bit like all my ‚Äúbands‚Äù).

I love this album: its sentiments, its confusion and most of all some cracking guitar solos. As I said when I wrote about that hat, I first encountered this album while in a foggy state in my life and its feints and dead ends, its heart and head, all served to draw me in. The ghost in the machine, the soul in the body. The long-lasting light.

Hero image is a Wilco Easter Egg based on the cover of ‚ÄúA Ghost is Born‚Äù, creative commons license.

  1. Yes, another squall. Just like number 27. And I note the fact that I‚Äôm following up a review of ‚ÄúCome On Die Young‚Äù with one of ‚ÄúA Ghost Is Born‚Äù. I don‚Äôt plan it like this, honest.¬†↩

  2. No wonder Lennon and McCartney fell out: John takes a load of drugs and explores the life of the mind, Paul stays at home to learn musique concrete and write songs about a shaggy Old English Sheepdog.¬†↩

entry.title: South America, Part 10
entry.content:
Picking up where I left off at Machu Picchu, we headed down into Aguas Calientes (trans. ‚Äúhot waters‚Äù) by coach and by the time we got there it was torrenting down with rain. So much for exploration. We waited out the downpour in a pizza place and deliberated over whether to buy souvenier snaps from the tour guides. Ironically for a town named after hot waters, it was bitterly cold. One of those places where the sound of running water follows you wherever you go, the best thing about it was the huge trains that ran down the middle of street - big clanking hulks pulling huge passenger trains.

We took one of those trains back to Cusco, though darkness fell about 30 minutes in. Enough time to see the rain‚Äôs effect on the Urubamba river, now a raging torrent filled with peculiar eddies and whorls. I fell asleep to the sound of my mp3 player despite the piped in Peruvian music and the coach being as bright as day. We transferred back to Cuzco in a stuffy coach that smelled of feet. I can‚Äôt even remember going out to dinner once we got back: I‚Äôm not certain that I did. All I remember is washing about a week‚Äôs worth of dirt off me in the shower.

The next morning we were up and off to Puno. This involved a transfer complete with Men At Work‚Äôs ‚ÄúDown Under‚Äù blaring out, a stern talk about drugs from our new driver, and another trip through the delights of Juliaca.

Puno doesn‚Äôt look like much, save for the fact that Lake Titicaca is so huge you‚Äôd be forgiven for thinking that it was a seaside town. Another transfer and we were in another reasonable hotel. I dropped in some laundry and we went to the markets to buy fruit for the families we were due to stay with on the Uros Islands in the middle of the lake. Despite not being that pretty, Puno is nevertheless an interesting place. Perhaps because it is ‚Äúclose‚Äù to the border with Bolivia, there are loads of electronics shops. There is a real mania for massive speakers. And then, on the way to the markets, a huge procession of chaps in bowler hats comes marching by.

Because it is close to Lake Titicaca, Puno does at least have some nice restaurants and we settled in for a nice dinner. I headed back to the hotel early because I was tired and the next day I felt the same so I signed off the tour with the intention of resting for the day and heading out to the reed islands the following day. Two fellow travellers Maz and Luke did the same because Maz was sick. The three of us booked a boat trip for the following day and had dinner together before we snuggled up to watch the recent Doctor Who specials on their laptop. Never underestimate the power of a day of doing nothing that culminates in watching the Doctor.

The next day I felt much better and Luke and I (unfortunately Maz was still unwell) took our trip out to the reed islands. We‚Äôd had the opportunity to go out to more islands and be back by six but had instead opted for a shorter trip that meant we would be back before lunch. As it happened this turned out to be a pretty good idea. More on that later.

It was a fine sunny day and we headed out to the islands to meet the locals who explained the construction of the reed islands. These were not people who had always lived this way, the reed islands are very much a post-colonial invention by people seeking to escape the genocidal Spanish1. Nowadays families still live on floating islands on the lake and make most of their living from tourism. The islands have to be constantly regenerated with new reeds and you can certainly smell them rotting. Nevertheless thanks to solar panels it is at least possible to watch TV!

We returned to Puno with no sign that the weather was about to change. We checked in on Maz, collected laundry, bought a birthday present for Jerry, went to lunch and had pizza. All this before the remainder of the group got back from their homestay. Almost as soon as they had, a great storm came in with great buckets of hail. And several power cuts. We sat in the candlelit lobby and drank chamomile tea. The hotel was on an incline, so we could see the streets flooding into streams and then hail began floating past too.

We were told that Puno was our last chance to eat cuy (guinea pig) as it would no longer be served once we reached Bolivia. I declined the chance - I‚Äôd arrived as people received theirs and to be honest it did just look like a greasy dead rat on a plate, so I opted for chicken milanese instead.

The next day we headed off for La Paz via Tiwanaku. The border crossing was very easy, lots of form filling but very little drama. Between the border and La Paz, lake Titicaca seemed to stretch all the way, a vast inland sea.

We stopped off at Tiwanaku, a vast pre-Colombian pre-Incan archeological site that we had to tour in a hurry due to being a little behind schedule. This was another place I‚Äôd seen in the ‚ÄúLost Kingdoms of South America‚Äù TV show that had inspired me to take the trip in the first place. (Here‚Äôs a clip about Tiwanaku on the BBC website.) It was very strange and yet somehow because we were rushed, I didn‚Äôt feel like I got as much out of seeing it as I did Ingapirca or Chan Chan. One to go back to I think.

Back on the truck we arrived in La Paz shortly before dark. We saw figures hanging from the lampposts, it was rather sinister but they are in fact tokens that are set on fire at midnight on New Year‚Äôs Eve to burn away the bad things that have happened in the previous year. No more weird than Guy Fawkes dolls but rather creepy when you see them without knowing what they are. We actually got a bit lost and drove through a market teeming with people selling all manner of goods, it was great to see everyone‚Äôs reaction to the truck. I especially liked how young children got incredibly excited and would wave.

We transferred to the hotel in La Paz on what we affectionately referred to as the ‚Äúdeath bus‚Äù (theme tune remarkably similar to batman). Our hotel room had been the site of a recent 50th birthday celebration and had been, shall we say, lightly cleaned in the interim. Nevertheless we headed out to a dutch cafe called Sol y Luna to hear a presentation about cycling down the death road. I decided that it was not for me - at least not with another four months or so to go, I didn‚Äôt really want to break any limbs until I was almost due to fly home! I had an amazing ghoulash for dinner, probably the best thing I‚Äôd eaten since Heidi‚Äôs in Cuzco.

On Saturday (New Year‚Äôs Eve), I explored La Paz with several people from the truck who had not gone on the death road bike ride. This included wandering through the witches‚Äô market with the weird dessicated animal embryos hanging in the roof (people bury them under houses to bring luck) and bizarre boxes of alleged powders and potions (the majority of which were concerned with endowing sexual prowess).

La Paz is pretty much crammed with market stalls all along the streets. As with most South American capitals, the old jostles with the new, the rich with the poor. We had been warned that La Paz was dangerous but I saw little that worried me. I also went with Jerry to the contemporary art museum, which was fun, though the art seemed to be more surreal than contemporary. That said, there were some tempting pieces for sale and had I been on sabbatical I probably would have bought one. Again, something to do next time around.

For new year‚Äôs eve, we returned to Sol y Luna and partied with the Dutch until well past midnight. I had a good old dance (one of only a few times that I did on the whole tour, to my shame) and really enjoyed myself. I got up too late for the hotel breakfast (as did everybody else) and so we went looking for food elsewhere. It took a while to find a place that was actually open (so much so we ended up back at the same place for dinner later on in the day) and we settled in for various sandwiches and in my case a virtuous bowl of meusli and fruit yoghurt2.

It was wonderful to be somewhere different for New Year‚Äôs Day, and with four months of the tour ahead of me I didn‚Äôt feel like I had to make any resolutions. I felt good in La Paz, like I was finally getting to grips with the adventure. Not that there was actually much adventure to be had that day: La Paz on the 1st of January was totally dead. The bustling jostling market stalls of the day before were practically empty save for a few DVD hawkers. It was even difficult trying to find somewhere to have a coffee. Not that we minded, most of the afternoon we sat in the hotel lobby and watched the Bond movie ‚ÄúQuantum of Solace‚Äù, which is partly set in Bolivia (though it was shot in Chile, much to local chagrin).

After our peregrinations and feeling the effects of the night before, we went to bed early ready for an early transfer back to the truck. The next stop on the tour would be a high point, literally: the high altitude mining town of Potos√≠.

  1. Note that the Spanish would not overtly kill the natives but ‚Äòrecruit‚Äô them for almost certain death in the silver mines around Potosi, more on that in part 11.¬†↩

  2. Not too virtuous, you can just about make out the enormous cup of coffee in the background!¬†↩

entry.title: What IS That Noise?
entry.content:
I recently spruced up a post I wrote four years ago about Biosphere‚Äôs wonderful album Substrata. I added the following footnote about the difference between voice samples and found sound:

I suppose I am distinguishing between found sound and vocal samples here. Perhaps there is very little difference, or that one is the other? When is a vocal snippet something more than found sound? Is it the fact that one has meaning? Isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúmeaningless‚Äù sample - like the ones here in Russian that I can‚Äôt understand - little more than found sound anyway?

These are rhetorical questions and they have gone unanswered. That‚Äôs a shame but I appreciate that the passing traffic for that particular post is quite low, let alone the footnotes. Perhaps we could address them here?

And wait! I have more. These are some other similar questions that sprung to mind at the same time:

  • Do all human utterances have intention and therefore meaning, even if you haven‚Äôt understood it?
  • Does all noise have a physical explanation? (Sound is just atoms vibrating after all?)
  • Does experiencing the recreation of a physical noise represents a repetition of the event that created the noise, even if it is just an abstract reification1 of that event?
  • If all experience and knowledge is subjective, would that mean that even meaningless ‚Äúnoise‚Äù or ‚Äúfound sound‚Äù can have intention, meaning, and purpose?

Note that for the second question a possible ‚Äúnon-physical noise‚Äù might be the memory of one. For example, a song going around in your head2 has no physical basis ‚Äî ‚Äúhearing‚Äù it does not come from your brain interpreting signals generated in your auditory nerve in response to your eardrum vibrating, though of course neurons are firing3 and this does have a physical basis.

I am thinking about these ideas for two reasons: one is the ongoing growth of my beautiful niece who continues to develop every time I see her, particularly cognitively. She‚Äôs at that wonderful stage where she is talking without any meaning, just that burbling baby-talk that young children use to work out the intonations of speech. The best thing is she can tell the difference between my imitation of her baby-talk (which delights her) and my invention of totally different baby-talk (which confuses her).

The second reason is Daniel Dennett‚Äôs great book ‚ÄúIntuition Pumps‚Äù, one of about twenty books that I seem to be about a third of the way through at the moment. (I wonder how many of my questions here he might dismiss as mere ‚Äúdeepities‚Äù?) He writes at length about viewing systems from the intentional, design, and physical standpoints. These are shorthand for how systems can be condensed so that they considered in an effective manner. If we return to the found sound versus vocal samples debate as an example, we can say that the difference between the two sound sources is that we have to interpret vocal samples from an intentional stance and found sound from a physical stance.

To come to some sort of conclusion and kind of answer my initial question, I think that found sound and vocal samples are genuinely different instruments on the Substrata album4 because your brain is interpreting them through these different stances. As to what happens when the language of the vocal sample is foreign to the listener, I don‚Äôt think you shift to a different stance but I do think it has a different effect, one that uses the cognitive dissonance between knowing something has meaning without knowing the actual meaning.

  1. Reification is the act of realising an idea - such as a building a chair after thinking of something to sit on. Hence ‚Äúabstract reification‚Äù is something of an oxymoron, but one that works in this instance. It‚Äôs a fault in my vocabulary for sure: if only there were an adjective for the Proustian recollection of past events ÓêÇ.¬†↩

  2. SOPHIE‚Äôs Lemonade perhaps?¬†↩

  3. Even Beliebers are not brain-dead. Probably.¬†↩

  4. Other ambient albums are available.¬†↩

entry.title: Clarice Lispector, Hour of the Star
entry.content:
Hour of the Star is a short novel by Clarice Lispector, a Ukrainian-born Brazilian author with an interesting life story. This is her last novel and is a remarkable book: inventive, funny, and sad, all at once. I found it in a special selection at the local library dedicated to Brazil because of the World Cup.

First some biography. Born Chaya Lispector in Chechelnyk, Ukraine, in 1920, her family escaped the pogroms and emigrated to Brazil in 1922. She was given the new name Clarice as the family settled in Macei√≥ in north-eastern Brazil. Later she and her family moved to Rio de Janeiro1 and she started law school there in 1937. Her first published short story appeared around 5 years later.

She later married a diplomat and travelled the world as he conducted various foreign missions. Up until her death at the age of 57, she wrote nine novels. Eight were published in her lifetime and Hour of the Star is the eighth of these. It was published shortly before her death and is the most popular of her novels.

Hour of the Star is a slip of a book, coming to a total of barely 70 pages. In fact, the edition I borrowed from the library was padded out with a long introduction (which is the same as this article from the Guardian in February) and a translator‚Äôs note at the end.

The novel tells the story of Macab√©a, a poor woman from the northeast who has had a difficult life and moves to Rio. It would be quite a simple story but the narrator also becomes a character in the story. He keeps interjecting and talking about what is happening, and how useless she is as a character and how much he hates her. Yet somehow by the end of the novel he has lost control of his creation (because she is not his creation but Lispector‚Äôs) and all he can do is ponder the nature of existence.

Hour of the Star is a very strange read, an almost intoxicating maelstrom of ideas churning forth on every page. Despite its tiny size, you have to read quickly to get the full effect. It reminded me a lot of a late novel2 by Jack Kerouac called ‚ÄúVanity of Duluoz‚Äù but also of the album ‚ÄúIn The Aeroplane Over The Sea‚Äù by Neutral Milk Hotel in the sense that in those songs there is a similar tension between the narrator and the subject.

But what sets Hour of the Star apart is that despite the apparent artificiality of how it is written, it manages to be very successful as writing about poverty, which is the true subject of the novel. The narrator represensts the tendency of those who talk about poverty to create examples of poverty rather than to engage sympathetically with actual instances of poverty. The whole novel is permeated with the narrator‚Äôs misguided belief that as a poor, tragic girl Macab√©a must somehow want more than she has. The delight of this book is that Lispector manages to show its readers their complicity in the delusions of its narrator.

I think it is a fantastic book and the end-pieces are interesting too. I look forward to reading more of her work if I can. Of particular interest to me is The Passion According to G.H. because the synopsis suggests a wry take on organised religion. I will also read Clarice Lispector‚Äôs biography Why This World if I can get it at/via the library.

  1. I‚Äôve been there, it‚Äôs great, you should totally go too.¬†↩

  2. I should definitely return to this at some point: I wrote a whole ‚Äúalbum‚Äù of song lyrics based on one page of this novel. I think it was page 63, though of course editions change. I‚Äôve lost those lyrics now but it might be fun to find the passage and write some more.¬†↩

entry.title: Guardians of the Galaxy: A Short Review
entry.content:
Finally saw Guardians of the Galaxy today. Here are fifteen observations about the film that may or may not constitute a short review.

  1. At least two Oscars for Best Use Of Body Paint (Green) and Best Use Of Body Paint (Blue) are sewn up.
  2. Chris Pratt basically plays Star Lord as ‚ÄúAndy Dwyer in space‚Äù and this is fine by me.
  3. Best movie to feature a talking raccoon in a long time.
  4. Watching the entirety of the end credits of Thor 2 paid off!
  5. ‚ÄúWE are Groot‚Äù ‚Äî aren‚Äôt we just?! All of the feels.
  6. It features a dance off as a major event, something that it shares with the Step Up movies. Guardians of the Galaxy is a waaaay better movie.
  7. The first words of the credits are ‚ÄúThe Guardians of the Galaxy will return‚Äù. It is in fact a movie that reviews itself.
  8. The 3D version might have been pretty good. I watched the 2D version but the scenes with lots of action might be improved with a bit of depth.
  9. A great soundtrack, but there is a cheesy ‚Äúsmooth rock wins chicks‚Äù bit that‚Äôs a little icky half way through.
  10. That said, the description of the legend of Footloose is hilarious. Especially the callback toward the end of the movie.
  11. I especially enjoyed the scene with the Collector.
  12. Karen Gillen is wasted as Nebula, but hopefully she will be back. Karen‚Äôs also in what may well be one of the most ill-conceived TV shows of all time later this autumn.
  13. I thought it was Bruce Willis playing Drax the Destroyer (I‚Äôm useless at this guess the actor game). I loved his taking things literally: ‚ÄúNothing goes over my head. My reflexes are too fast, I would catch it.‚Äù
  14. If you text me at any point in the next month, I will probably reply with ‚ÄúI am Groot‚Äù.
  15. No Raccoons or tree creatures were harmed during the making of this film.

entry.title: My Amazing Subversive Revolutionary Adolescence
entry.content:
Or at least its subversive soundtrack‚Ä¶

I listened to The Orb‚Äôs amazing live album ‚ÄúLive ‚Äô93‚Äù the other day (after discovering the insipid ‚ÄúHistory Of The Future‚Äù collection on Spotify) and I was amazed at how countercultural and subversive it was. I was listening to this stuff at the age of 14 and now that I‚Äôm old enough to be a parent, that makes me a bit uncomfortable. Actually it does nothing of the sort, because it‚Äôs frigging awesome.

The Orb were pretty anarchic on record but at their live gigs they went the extra mile, dropping in all the stuff that legal teams can‚Äôt clear sample-wise (A mash-up of ‚ÄúThe Real Slim Shady‚Äù and ‚ÄúToxygene‚Äù when I saw them later on in 2005) and just generally made the tunes baggier and looser. When writing about their second album ‚ÄúU.F.Orb‚Äù as part of my understated classic series, I tried to review as many versions of each track as I could, because for The Orb a track is more like a bundle of ideas to extrapolate and explore. Today‚Äôs bands don‚Äôt do this enough in my opinion. Perhaps the decline of physical formats contributes to this, you just don‚Äôt get runs of 200 twelve inches anymore.

Consider the version of ‚ÄúSpanish Castles In Space‚Äù on ‚ÄúLive ‚Äô93‚Äù. The sedate and stately album version sounds like they recorded it in an aquarium. It ends with KLF-esque bleating sheep etc. And the live version barely differs, except for adding a long sample of a news report about a ‚ÄúMarijuana Bomb‚Äù. A huge bale of weed tossed out by smugglers lands on someone‚Äôs caravan one morning. A huge cheer erupts in the crowd as this sample plays. Later there‚Äôs a languid repeated chant of ‚ÄúMarijuana, Marijuana, who wants it?‚Äù. It‚Äôs a pretty mild celebration of drug use, but it‚Äôs a fun reference that I was listening to before I could legally buy cigarettes.

Other subversion abounds (in particular the ‚Äúmorphine drip inside his stomach‚Äù sample that darkens those ‚ÄúLittle Fluffy Clouds‚Äù) and I think it‚Äôs telling that ‚ÄúLive ‚Äô93‚Äù has never been reissued in the way that all the other albums have. In fact it‚Äôs so crammed full of samples that it‚Äôs a wonder that it ever got released in the first place. There‚Äôs a spoken word version of Pink Floyd‚Äôs ‚ÄúAnother Brick In The Wall Part 2‚Äù all over ‚ÄúPlateau‚Äù. Samples from other Orb tracks are all over the nineteen minute version of ‚ÄúA Huge Ever Growing Pulsating Brain‚Ä¶ (Loving U)‚Äù turning it into a sort of weird megamix. And what about the Koranic chants sampled on ‚ÄúOutlands‚Äù together with Martin Luther King‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Have A Dream‚Äù speech? (Spoiler alert: it is the ABSOLUTE BEST version of ‚ÄúOutlands‚Äù that you will ever hear.)

But drugs and sampling and religious mysticism? So what? I think the actual subversion of The Orb (and a very small select collection of their peers) was to say ‚Äúlook, come and sit in the garden with us, have a cup of tea, and contemplate the life of the mind‚Äù. Look at everything else that‚Äôs supposedly rebellious, it‚Äôs all just bullshit mind control: drink loads of beer (now all the festivals and music venues are sponsored by drinks companies), have loads of sex (create more minions for the capitalist machine to send off on their pointless tabloid wars), smash stuff up (so we can withdraw from the public good and say that no one can have nice things), etc rinse and repeat.

I was changed by ‚ÄúLive ‚Äô93‚Äù (it was the first full length Orb album that I owned) but it didn‚Äôt make me take a sack load of drugs, it just gradually evolved me into the sort of person who knows that inward thought and self-reflection are natural and not somehow counter to the spirit of capitalist endeavour. It taught be to be suspicious of humourlessness and ownership. The fast pace of modern life regards things like ‚Äúhard work‚Äù, spontaneity, and branding as innate and inescapable. It requires the sensationalism that I satirised in this post‚Äôs title and shies away from the riotous anarchy of the past: what makes me really uncomfortable is whether fourteen-year-olds me can receive these messages today.

entry.title: Understated Classics #26: Come On Die Young by Mogwai
entry.content:
I‚Äôll tell you about punk rock: punk rock is a word used by dilettantes and ah‚Ä¶ and ah‚Ä¶ heartless manipulators about music that takes up the energies and the bodies and the hearts and the souls and the time and the minds of young men who give what they have to it and give everything they have to it and it‚Äôs a‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a term that‚Äôs based on contempt, it‚Äôs a term that‚Äôs based on fashion, style, elitism, satanism and everything that‚Äôs rotten about rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll. I don‚Äôt know Johnny Rotten but I‚Äôm sure‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sure he puts as much blood and sweat into what he does as Sigmund Freud did. You see, what sounds to you like a big load of trashy old noise is in fact the brilliant music of a genius, myself . And that music is so powerful that it‚Äôs quite beyond my control and ah‚Ä¶ when I‚Äôm in the grips of it I don‚Äôt feel pleasure and I don‚Äôt feel pain, either physically or emotionally. Do you understand what I‚Äôm talking about? Have you ever felt like that? When you just couldn‚Äôt feel anything and you didn‚Äôt want to either. You know? Like that? Do you understand what I‚Äôm saying sir? (Iggy Pop, Canadian TV, March 11th 1977.)

And so it begins: this sample of Iggy Pop sets ‚ÄúCome On Die Young‚Äù ‚Äì the second album by Mogwai ‚Äì in motion. It received a lukewarm reception on its release 15 years ago but to me, it‚Äôs a classic. The sentiment of its title, the mellowness, and the stacks of noise that punctuate throughout all combine to make a record that I am fiercely loyal to. It is beautiful and dark and has got better and better with age.

‚ÄúCome On Die Young‚Äù is consumed with what happens within the empty spaces in our lives. Even the title is an exhortation to remove the dead space from our lives, to live a life with a similar meaning to those who die young. It‚Äôs actually the name of a Glasgow street gang, the album‚Äôs title coming from the same milleu as their debut ‚ÄúYoung Team‚Äù.

That intro ‚ÄúPunk Rock:‚Äù, the title track ‚Äúcody‚Äù, and ‚ÄúHelps Both Ways‚Äù ‚Äì a moody instrumental that feels like the interior of a haunted house, an atmosphere enhanced by the sound of american football commentary ‚Äì open the album in a slow and stately manner. This tryptych and that jet black cover with the wrong-looking face leering out at you evoke a melancholy fit for rainy days.

Things surge to life with ‚ÄúYear 2000 Non-Compliant Cardia‚Äù, a noisy swinging lilt with the cymbals mixed high and some magnificent effects pedal abuse. It‚Äôs pretty and meanacing at the same time. Every time I listen to this album I‚Äôm always amazed at how good the drums sound on this album. Next track ‚ÄúKappa‚Äù broods and threatens to erupt but it never does: the odd squall of noise aside, I always think it sounds a bit like a bizarro cover of Pink Floyd‚Äôs ‚ÄúShine On You Crazy Diamond‚Äù.

The whole album explores interstitial spaces: that empty room with the tv on, the rhetoric of the punk rocker echoing out to defend his art to chat show viewers in suburban living rooms, and the tunes that never quite settle in to a rhythm like ‚ÄúKappa‚Äù and ‚ÄúWaltz for Aidan‚Äù. It‚Äôs all beautifully executed, even if it did non-plus the people enthused by the power and fury of ‚ÄúYoung Team‚Äù.

The second half of the album is more noisy, based around four longer pieces (‚ÄúMay Nothing But Happiness Come Through Your Door‚Äù, ‚ÄúEx-Cowboy‚Äù, ‚ÄúChocky‚Äù and ‚ÄúChristas Steps‚Äù) and two two-minute interludes. ‚ÄúMay Nothing But Happiness Come Through Your Door‚Äù is nothing short of a masterpiece, it picks up every element of the album to that point and then runs with it while adding one more crucial element: a heartbreaking melody. It is truly the most beautiful piece of post-rock you will ever hear and I own all the Fridge albums, so I should know. There is also a truly bizzare cymbal sound at points, miked up so every third one is this sort of alien ‚Äúthwock‚Äù and proof, if any were ever needed, that production is as essential to great records as the music itself. Meanwhile we revisit our interstitial spaces: on 6:00 a sample of ‚Äúplease hold the line‚Äù begins to repeat as the track gently begins to disappear, until it is the last thing that remains.

‚ÄúOh! How the Dogs Stack Up‚Äù throws in an interlude of distorted piano and vinyl effects before ‚ÄúEx-Cowboy‚Äù begins the final half hour of ‚ÄúCome On Die Young‚Äù: the descent into deep darkness that had been threatened throughout. It‚Äôs a track that builds into sheets of noise from the calmest of lulls and then fades back again, several times. This side to the music pushes a button inside me though, or it used to, and the noisier elements used to ratchet up my anger. It‚Äôs not always a nice feeling. Over the years though I‚Äôve come to appreciate the structure and I don‚Äôt feel quite so tense listening to it. This is just as well because the section of noise that begins around six minutes in sounds like the sound barrier being broken (by guitars!) over and over again. But just like pain and anger, the noisier parts are only temporary.

‚ÄúChocky‚Äù begins with a roiling torrent of noise mixed very low beneath a slow piano line, sounding like two records played at once and combining the quiet and loud together. Eventually disembodied voices enter and the noise dominates for a while, before the piano line returns even stronger and the rest of the band enters too. You can still pick out that foam of noise underneath and you‚Äôre always held there tense, waiting for it to surge back and take over. However, in a great act of restraint it never does and merely remains there, a quiet whisper of raging feedback that only rises to engulf your headphones and speakers at the very end.

Finally ‚ÄúChristmas Steps‚Äù all but closes the album (‚ÄúPunk rock/Puff daddy/Antichrist‚Äù flips the Iggy Pop sample backwards and deflates into the weary trumpets and noise for a fitting finale) with another beautiful and heartbreaking riff. Around 4:00 a monstrous bass riff takes over, getting quicker and quicker (sounding like Metallica on ketamine - much like the actual Metallica did at Glastonbury a few weeks back) before a real raging guitar cuts in. They save the power and the darkness for right at the end, yet there‚Äôs real melody in there too ‚Äì you can hum the riff that shreiks across over the Ketametallica noise ‚Äì and they also manage to cut back and forth between that intensity and the slower sections (augmented by violin lines of great beauty). Something that‚Äôs all rage one moment is a thing of beauty the next, it‚Äôs the whole album in miniature.

This was an important album to me. It was one I would I put on if I were upset, but nowadays I see so much beauty under the noise I wonder whether it was much more of a comfort than I realised.

‚ÄúCome On Die Young‚Äù was reissued as a deluxe vinyl box set earlier this year. I bought a copy (despite being skint) but shipping was delayed because of a fault with the pressing. However I‚Äôm hoping that it will arrive this week. There‚Äôs a stack of additional material attached to the re-release and once I have ploughed through that, I will write up an addendum to this post with more info on those tracks (and whether the remaster affects the original album in any way).

Thanks to Amy Dupcak for having the text of the Iggy Pop quote on her blog.

entry.title: Whatever Happened To That Hat?
entry.content:
The hat in question is a Wilco baseball cap that I bought at a gig of theirs in 2004, the night that Germany got eliminated from Euro 2004. I‚Äôd love to show you a picture of it but I can‚Äôt, there isn‚Äôt even a picture of it from a Wilco merch site: at least not one that Google or Bing images can see anyway. I did manage to find a side-on picture of it in my bedroom in 2005 and zoom right in on it like they do in CSI.

But to start we have to go back a bit further to Easter in 2004, with everyone away from the flat where I lived. I must have been up at 5 AM to listen to a copy of Wilco‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Ghost is Born‚Äù that I‚Äôd downloaded off the net - damn I can‚Äôt even remember the name of the software but this one guy had so many cool albums - and AGIB just blew me away. A heady mix of great music and sleep deprivation no doubt.

Fast forward a few months and I‚Äôm back in my home town enthusing to two guys from Wilco‚Äôs hometown in the street outside of a kebab shop after the gig. I‚Äôm eating kebab shop chips and am filled with the zeal of someone who‚Äôs had their artistic nipple tweaked and is talking to strangers and is wearing this totally sweet hat.

That hat, or rather the gig where I got it from, is where mattischrome was born ‚Äî the new name of my alter ego ‚Äî the name of my entire online identity (including this blog thanks to the nation of Montenegro) stems from the username I invented for a Wilco message board: one that I joined so that I could download pictures of that gig (and most importantly the set list). ‚ÄúHell is Chrome‚Äù is the second track on ‚ÄúA Ghost is Born‚Äù and it‚Äôs ace. ‚ÄúMatt is Chrome‚Äù, given my early greying hair, seemed like a witty and sensible appropriation. Of course, it now makes everyone think that I am a Swedish guy named Mattis who really likes Google‚Äôs browser (which did not exist at this time, nor did Gmail strangely enough which is why the first mattischrome account is a Hotmail).

The next day England lost to Portugal on penalties in Lisbon. Within a year (three months come to think of it) I‚Äôd be in love with a Portuguese woman and in love with her culture and nation too. It feels like the majority of my life has been lived since then. Back then I couldn‚Äôt speak Portuguese which just feels weird somehow.

So whatever happened to that hat? Well it was always around, usually hanging from a tall lamp in the corner of my bedroom until the day I moved away from St Albans. That day my friend Albert helped me move out. He swiped the hat and looked better wearing it than I ever did, so I let him keep it. Perhaps he still has it.

entry.title: Album Digest, June 2014
entry.content:
Watter are a ‚Äúsupergroup‚Äù composed from various members of Grails, Slint, and other bands. I did not know anything about Hundred Waters before this month: ‚ÄúThe Moon Rang Like A Bell‚Äù is their second album. In fact second albums by bands I know nothing about are a something of theme because ‚ÄúSunbathing Animal‚Äù is Parquet Courts‚Äô sophomore effort and I don‚Äôt know anything about them either. Meanwhile, I‚Äôve meant to write about ‚ÄúThe Four Seasons Recomposed‚Äù since April.

Watter ‚ÄúThis World‚Äù

The fingerprints of Grails are all over this album, a collaboration between Zak Riles (of Grails) and a few other musicians I‚Äôve not heard of: Tyler Trotter; Britt Walford of Slint; and Rachel Grimes. On the opener ‚ÄúRustic Fog‚Äù it‚Äôs the slippery slide guitars that give the game away, though the gentle heartbeat and the woozy windswept synths add a level of detail that you wouldn‚Äôt find on [Deep Politics](album-digest-march-2012 or The Black Tar Prophecies. In fact ‚ÄúRustic Fog‚Äù most resembles one of the longer tracks from either of the Lilacs & Champagne albums (note that Zak isn‚Äôt in L&C though); it bubbles rather than boils and the lack of vocal samples gives the music room enough to build and to glower, unlike tracks like ‚ÄúLe Grand‚Äù from Grails‚Äô hyperactive hip-hop side project.

The second track ‚ÄúLord I Want More‚Äù is more folky with finger-picked acoustic guitars and sensitive piano playing replacing the murky synths until about half way through when it melts into a weird starry synth lullaby, collapsing in on itself like a dream does when you wake up. The end of ‚ÄúLord I Want More‚Äù sets up the intro to <‚ÄùSmall Business‚Äù, one of two much longer tracks (‚ÄúSmall Business‚Äù is 13:32 and ‚ÄúSeawater‚Äù is 12:51) that fill out the majority of the run time. ‚ÄúSmall Business‚Äù begins like a less subtle Grails track, built on strong guitars and strident drums. It‚Äôs a bit too mellow for it‚Äôs own good but there is plenty of space and structure for the chiming guitars to move around in. It feels like a relief when the fireworks really kick in on the five and a half minute mark and the track really takes off. With just over four minutes left ‚ÄúSmall Business‚Äù becomes a gentle trancey piece again with a riff that sounds like stones skipping across the water, completely with splashing sounds and some nifty work with the pedals. It‚Äôs got a nice Philip Glass feel to it.

Following this is a shorter track ‚ÄúBloody Monday‚Äù which includes a vocal sample, more finger picking, and a country violin. It‚Äôs a beautiful wordless song that seems to be a million miles from its title. The sound is so clear and crisp, it really feels like a break from the fog that hangs over Grails records: perhaps this is what ‚ÄúAlmost Grew My Hair‚Äù could have been in a perfect world.

The other long piece ‚ÄúSeawater‚Äù is even better than ‚ÄúSmall Business‚Äù. The first few minutes build off a nagging riff and droning synth: these are the creepiest moments on the album. Then a strong drumbeat kicks in and finger-picked acoustic guitar builds a riff around that instead, before an electric guitar also takes up the riff. In the background the synths still spiral around producing a sound fog to get lost in. As with ‚ÄúLord I Want More‚Äù and ‚ÄúBloody Monday‚Äù, the riff is folky when it finally emerges and soars above all everything else. The rest of the track is a guitar playing master class and there‚Äôs one bit of riffing counterpoint around 8:30 that‚Äôs so amazing that I can‚Äôt really explain why it excites me so much. It‚Äôs noisy and it‚Äôs mellow, the aural equivalent of salty and sweet.

The final track is the title track, a beautiful sound envelope that‚Äôs basically virtual reality realised as music. Put ‚ÄúThis World‚Äù on and imagine the most perfect place you could be, this is music that will transport you there. Expect to hear it soundtracking a quiet moment of transcendent beauty in a movie near you some time soon. More finger picked guitar lines dance over insistent piano motifs gliding forward in time like a figure skater on ice. It‚Äôs serenely and divinely beautiful.

The iTunes version of the album has a bonus track ‚ÄúDigital Camo‚Äù that is also interesting. It doesn‚Äôt feel as well rounded as the rest of the material here but it‚Äôs very upbeat and is just a few good lyrics short of being a decent rock song. Unlike the rest of the tracks here, you get the feeling that the band peeled this one off very quickly. Overall ‚ÄúThis World‚Äù is a fine instrumental album and one that further adds to my belief that Grails are awesome. It‚Äôs hard to know whether Watter are a permanent proposition or a one-off project: I guess it all depends on whether Grails are in fact in the process of amicably breaking up. Both Lilacs & Champagne and now Watter prove that while we will lose a lot if they are, we will also gain much much more.

Hundred Waters ‚ÄúThe Moon Rang Like A Bell‚Äù

I suppose the best way to get started on writing about ‚ÄúThe Moon Rang Like A Bell‚Äù is to provide a list of albums it reminds me of: ‚ÄúWithin And Without‚Äù by Washed Out, ‚ÄúVisions‚Äù by Grimes, ‚ÄúQuarantine‚Äù by Laurel Halo, ‚ÄúJames Blake‚Äù and ‚ÄúOvergrown‚Äù by James Blake, ‚ÄúIf You Wait‚Äù by London Grammar, and one of my mum‚Äôs old Enya albums. That‚Äôs not to say that they sound exactly like the exact average of those albums (imagine that?!), it‚Äôs just a starting point from which we can begin.

Another starting point might be to relate some things that I have learned about the band. They are a four piece from Florida who have supported Alt+J and The xx in the past. This is their second album and the first to receive major attention. They have a nice Instagram. I also find it interesting that one of the band was a programmer for streaming music service Grooveshark.

They follow the xx/Chvrches/London Grammar template of having a breathy female singer (Nicole Miglis) backed up with a few guys (Trayer Tryon, Paul Giese, Zach Tetreault). What makes them different is that they try to square the difference between perky Chvrches and languid London Grammar. There‚Äôs lots of quirky production and variation in pace, things that I thought were lacking from London Grammar‚Äôs ‚ÄúIf You Wait‚Äù. So while a lot of the tracks, like ‚ÄúBroken Blue‚Äù and ‚ÄúChambers [Passing Train]‚Äù, depend as much on space as sound, there are also songs like the fantastic ‚ÄúDown From The Rafters‚Äù that pick up the pace a bit.

The interesting production ideas are what draw the comparison to Grimes and James Blake, while the laid back bits definitely recall Washed Out and The xx. It‚Äôs a bit unfocussed in places but that‚Äôs not a bad thing, albums like ‚ÄúQuarantine‚Äù and ‚ÄúVisions‚Äù are great precisely because the roughness around the edges rewards repeat listening. If you‚Äôre looking for an album to sunbathe to, try this one.

Parquet Courts ‚ÄúSunbathing Animal‚Äù

I‚Äôd not heard of Parquet Courts at all until a few weeks ago but ‚ÄúSunbathing Animal‚Äù is their second album (or is it?!). They‚Äôre from New York and they live up to the hype and that heritage. It is better when bands mature out of the spotlight, it gives them a bit of time to refine their vision and come up with some solid material. That is definitely the case here because ‚ÄúSunbathing Animal‚Äù is a cracking album. My response to it has been similar to ‚ÄúChange Becomes Us‚Äù by Wire last year: it‚Äôs a slow burner overall but there are enough hooks to get you addicted and into loving the whole thing over the long haul.

Let me start by shouting from the rooftops about the hooks. The album begins with the Strokes-like riff of ‚ÄúBodies Made Of‚Äù and then rushes into the single ‚ÄúBlack and White‚Äù. Listen close though, it‚Äôs not all wiry guitar work and crashing cymbals: there are some pretty cool lyrics there. Later on, there is my favourite song on the album ‚ÄúWhat Colour Is Blood?‚Äù (Still the same that it was, apparently) and the rollicking ‚ÄúDucking and Dodging‚Äù.

The template for those upbeat tracks is provided by all those New York punk bands you love (or post-punk in the case of ‚ÄúVienna II‚Äù and the title track). For the more mellow tracks the reference points are Lou Reed and Spiritualized (though I guess I should say Suicide to keep up the NYC connections) - in fact ‚ÄúAlways Back In Town‚Äù sounds like Jay Spaceman backed by The Strokes. The presence of LCD Soundsystem looms over the whole album too, in a good way.

There is simply too much to write about this album: be it the way that ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Rolling‚Äù lumbers in and out of view accompanied by the most demented harmonica work I‚Äôve heard this side of The Orb‚Äôs ‚ÄúTowers of Dub‚Äù, or how ‚ÄúInstant Disassembly‚Äù seems to compress an entire novel‚Äôs worth of story into its seven minutes, or even how the thrash of ‚ÄúSunbathing Animal‚Äù makes nearly four minutes seem like just one. Needless to say that, with all this going on, this album is a thing of unmitigated joy and beauty.

Max Richter ‚ÄúThe Four Seasons Recomposed‚Äù

Regarding Max Richter, the question is inevitably: why did he attempt to recompose the Four Seasons? Well mainly it was because he asked to. Deutsche Grammophon has decided to try and be cool (this decision, as is oft the case with humans and record labels, coincides with a base 10 round number anniversary), and commission electronic artistes to ‚Äúreevaluate‚Äù some of their classic classical recordings, sampling them to create new pieces. Previously Matthew Herbert, whose original work I have a profound admiration for, did various apaprently unspeakable things to a recording of Mahler‚Äôs Unfinished 10th). Judging by the reviews of the result in that case, see the quite frothy response on amazon here and here, not everyone is ready for music they love to be endowed with additional postmodern flourishes and/or conceptual weight. Traditional listeners of DG records might decide to swap ‚Äúflourishes‚Äù and ‚Äúweight‚Äù for more impolite nouns and I would not hold it against them. However, the modern listener, saturated with ‚Äúclassical‚Äù music from day one, may find that the conceptual widgets help to amplify particular signals amid the noise.

Returning to the Four Seasons, Richter decided that he couldn‚Äôt do enough with the recording he was due to work with and found that the only thing he felt happy to ‚Äúsample‚Äù and rearrange was the original score. As a prolific soundtrack artist, Richter no doubt felt there were motifs and riffs that he wanted to cast in a new light, and while sampling is an incredible technique in skilled hands, perhaps these were things he could only do at an atomic level. I‚Äôm aware of, but have not heard, his ‚Äúgenuine‚Äù (as opposed to screen) work but I do know that it is held in high regard. In particular a piece called ‚ÄúMemory House‚Äù that has been performed by the London Sinfonietta. The LS themselves can be relied upon to be ‚Äúup for‚Äù performing screechy modern pieces - not to say that Memory House is one of those. I‚Äôm going to find and copy and listen to it when I can.

When it comes to classical music, my tastes are shallow in some ways - I only dip my toes in the more traditional canon once in a while. I think you can be said to be enthusiastic for a piece if you seek out multiple performances of it and I‚Äôve only ever done that with three pieces. One is Mendelssohn‚Äôs Violin Concerto in E-minor (a dip of the toe into that deeper wider canon) and the other is ‚ÄúDifferent Trains‚Äù by Steve Reich (more akin to the usual bathing place). The third piece (and a second dip of that toe) is Rodrigo‚Äôs Concierto de Aranjuez - I have always loved the shimmering mirages of its second movement and have heard quite a few variations, including one by Miles Davis.

Anyway, to actually review the album in question. I like it. It‚Äôs now to fussy to be enjoyed in the way that the original is best enjoyed: with the lead violin role placed squarely in the hands of a bonkers virtuoso like Nigel Kennedy. Nevertheless many of the original‚Äôs charms are intact (that wonderful brooding and shimmering movement in Summer for example) and other facets of the piece are enhanced in Richter‚Äôs new arrangement: it‚Äôs much more emotional and lyrical than I remember.

The CD version also contains five electronic pieces by Richter (‚ÄúShadows‚Äù) that are fairly inessential and four remixes of a movement from each of the seasons. The first, ‚ÄúSpring 1‚Äù, by Richter himself is probably the best, applying all the electronics and bird song samples that he presumably couldn‚Äôt bring himself to adorn an original DG recording with. The remix of ‚ÄúAutumn 3‚Äù by Fear of Tigers is fantastic but presented in a truncated version: the twelve inch version available on SoundCloud and Spotify is far better. The other two mixes are fairly servicable too, Robot Koch even decides to turn ‚ÄúSummer 3‚Äù into hip-hop with results that are not too cringeworthy!

All in all, it‚Äôs a respectful undertaking that is a qualified success. As with all remakes and reboots and such like, it‚Äôs always best to retain a connection to the original - just as well there‚Äôs a companion app to help you explore both works if you like that kind of thing. Beyond that, I will certainly be investigating more of Richter‚Äôs work.

entry.title: Album Digest, May 2014
entry.content:
This month was strange. I didn‚Äôt listen to much new music and after last month‚Äôs bumper digest there‚Äôs probably a reason for that. Not to mention that Spotify gives you more reasons to look backwards than forwards. Nevertheless, this brief post features new albums by Little Dragon and Coldplay, along with the mini-album collaboration between R√∂yskopp and Robyn.

Little Dragon ‚ÄúNabuma Rubberband‚Äù

I discovered Little Dragon, like most people, I imagine, via Gorillaz‚Äô ‚ÄúPlastic Beach‚Äù album. When I investigated their ‚ÄúMachine Dreams‚Äù album I was surprised that their sound had transplanted to ‚ÄúPlastic Beach‚Äù intact. Sometimes you discover a band through a collaboration and their own work turns out to be disappointing, somehow diminished by the other artist(s) no longer being present. ‚ÄúMachine Dreams‚Äù is a fine album that breezes by, much like ‚ÄúEmpire Ants‚Äù and ‚ÄúTo Binge‚Äù do on ‚ÄúPlastic Beach‚Äù.

Unfortunately I completely missed their last album ‚ÄúRitual Union‚Äù album from 2011 (I haven‚Äôt heard it at all) and now ‚ÄúNabuma Rubberband‚Äù arrives with a bit of hype and a sprightly new art direction (not to mention a rush job ‚ÄúBest of‚Äù comp released earlier this year). The lead off singles ‚ÄúParis‚Äù and ‚ÄúLet Go‚Äù showed quite a lot of promise too. At first ‚ÄúNabuma Rubberband‚Äù (excellent title by the way) sounds oddly mired in collaboration mode, with the band seemingly collaborating with other people‚Äôs expectations for them. For example opener ‚ÄúMirror‚Äù sounds like Massive Attack picking up from where ‚ÄúMezzanine‚Äù left off. This is, of course, a very good thing because who among us does not pretend on a daily basis that ‚Äú100th Window‚Äù never happened? It‚Äôs a pretty song but it seems focus grouped some how, the right pressure points applied and the right references given.

That all said, ‚ÄúNabuma Rubberband‚Äù does seem to grow in confidence as it progresses. As I‚Äôve said, the singles are great and ‚ÄúKlipp Klapp‚Äù is a decent little runaround too. There is a very weird and very brief interlude that makes you think they‚Äôre about to go dub step or something similarly banal/atrocious but it all blows over, a witty musical red herring. Overall the album is a nice mellow affair and worth at least a background listen.

Coldplay ‚ÄúGhost Stories‚Äù

While I was travelling around South America I listened a lot to both ‚ÄúA Rush Of Blood To The Head‚Äù and ‚ÄúX & Y‚Äù. If I‚Äôm honest it‚Äôs because they fit well to both the business of staring out of the window at wonderful landscapes and that of taking a crafty nap while no one‚Äôs looking. To my mind they‚Äôre both good albums. I tried ‚ÄúViva La Vida‚Äù again too and I like it more than I used to. Apparently I quite liked ‚ÄúMylo Xyloto‚Äù, when I reviewed it on these pages in October 2011, but to be honest I lost interest in it (beyond the singles) after that.

Maybe I need to go back to ‚ÄúMylo Xyloto‚Äù though because the new album ‚ÄúGhost Stories‚Äù isn‚Äôt that great.
