It is one of those tracks that is perfect for soundtracking those moments where you think your head is falling apart, precisely because listening to it makes you feel like your head is indeed falling apart. ‚ÄúUptown Psychedelia‚Äù is dominated by Tim Hecker‚Äôs methods of processing existing sounds into new, fascinating, shapes and shades, but also benefits greatly from the greater attention to the underlying melodies and sounds, at least compared to the rather spartan ‚ÄúRavedeath, 1972‚Äù tracks. I‚Äôm guessing this is what Dan Lopatin brings to the party.

I need to listen to the rest of the album again to get more of a feel for the remaining tracks but overall I was struck by how well they‚Äôd made processed electronic music sound free and improvised, as opposed to mechanical and manipulated. At one point, on ‚ÄúGRM Blue II‚Äù, it feels a bit like listening to free jazz played by dial-up modems ‚Äì and I mean that in a good way.

Burial ‚ÄúTruant / Rough Sleeper EP‚Äù

This is the second Burial album that I‚Äôm going to be cack-handedly reviewing on these pages this year. The first was the ‚ÄúKindred EP‚Äù, which I wrote about back in February and I wasn‚Äôt able to say a great deal about it beyond talking about how difficult it is to review music by this guy because it is just so different from anything else out there.

The two tracks on this EP clock in at 11:45 and 13:47 respectively, and both tracks are mini-suites. ‚ÄúTruant‚Äù begins with a very confident and recognisable Burial sound: the rainfall, the shuffling beats and a female vocal sample (‚ÄúI fell in love with you‚Äù). However, at about 3:55 everything cuts away ‚Äì almost like someone pressing pause on a cassette player in the way that you can tell that it is stopping suddenly even as it stops‚Ä¶ What comes in next is much more insistent, almost the same elements though the vocal sample is now diced up and rearranged to the point where none of the original phrase is discernible. I love the way his tracks build in such a beautiful layered way that you nod along and yet every time he can fool you by switching the beat slightly and throwing you off. Even better, by about 6:30 ‚ÄúTruant‚Äù sounds a bit like an old KLF record for a little while, it‚Äôs just majestically done. At 8:32 we get another ‚Äútape pause‚Äù moment and a skittery D‚Äôn‚ÄôB rhythm comes in ‚Äì though even that gets completely taken apart in the minutes that follow, it‚Äôs as though all these beats just drown in rain and static.

‚ÄúRough Sleeper‚Äù is warmer and more melodic and even features some sax at one point. The weird silence trick is employed again on this track but ‚ÄúRough Sleeper‚Äù feels more like one evolving single track rather than about three glued together like ‚ÄúTruant‚Äù. I‚Äôd say the section from 4:00 to about 9:30 is probably the best bit of the whole EP: some really pretty vocals and melodies (with bells!) in there.

The thing that constantly surprises me about Burial‚Äôs music is how he is able to consistently create tunes that are instantly recognisable as his but are never boring or clich√©. Each new tune seems to add something different and offer a new take on what has gone before. Here he has taken a multitude of ideas and smooshed them together on two sides of vinyl. It might not be the length of a whole album but it certainly has enough invention and ideas for one. This pair and Kindred (together about 50 minutes) are well worth investigating.

entry.title: Album Digest, November 2012
entry.content:
Pretty much a sliding scale between songs and electronic wibble on this month‚Äôs albums and a particularly damp, chilly feeling to proceedings too.

  1. Bat For Lashes ‚ÄúThe Haunted Man‚Äù
  2. Ital ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù and ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù
  3. Bj√∂rk ‚ÄúBastards‚Äù
  4. Brian Eno ‚ÄúLux‚Äù

Bat For Lashes ‚ÄúThe Haunted Man‚Äù

When it comes to Bat For Lashes, I prefer her first album ‚ÄúFur And Gold‚Äù to her second ‚ÄúTwo Suns‚Äù because when I listen to the latter I don‚Äôt feel connected to any of the songs. For me, ‚ÄúFur And Gold‚Äù remains a wonderful adventure throughout, it‚Äôs a fantastic listen.

For a while I thought that ‚ÄúThe Haunted Man‚Äù just picked up where ‚ÄúTwo Suns‚Äù left off and I didn‚Äôt think it was that great. However, at some point the tide turned and I really started to enjoy it. I think it was when I really started to pay attention to the tracks towards the end of the track listing. As I have mentioned before, I like to listen to albums while walking to and from work, and because of this I tend to enjoy albums more if the best tracks are at the beginning: my walk to work is just 35 minutes and so I don‚Äôt often get to listen to whole albums.

I would say that ‚ÄúThe Haunted Man‚Äù is definitely ‚Äúback loaded‚Äù. Things really kick off with ‚ÄúLaura‚Äù (song number 5), it‚Äôs the song from this album that you are most likely to have already heard. It‚Äôs beautifully spare and sparse, a bit like ‚ÄúMoon and Moon‚Äù and delivered in the main from the piano with not much else to accompany it, just the odd phrase from a brass band.

After that comes ‚ÄúWinter Fields‚Äù, which I think really shows off of her songwriting skills with some beautiful imagery about the countryside. I think it is great that there is still music that taps into a sense of Englishness (in particular the pastoral aspect of English culture) and manages to draw out something dark and mysterious. It‚Äôs something that has been present right from the beginning in Bat For Lashes‚Äô music, it tumbles out of the speakers right from the opening verses of ‚ÄúHorse And I‚Äù.

Completing a hat trick of great songs in the middle of the album is the title track. I especially enjoy the glitchy intro, the strange Red-Box-esque drums and choir lines ahead of the chorus (actually it‚Äôs a lot like something off Kate Bush‚Äôs ‚ÄúHounds Of Love‚Äù too) and the variety of synth sounds throughout: there‚Äôs some spooky stuff on the opening verse and some rich deep veins of sound underpinning the main chorus. It feels like a suite of several songs brought together but all the disparate elements combine beautifully.

Elsewhere there are other really great songs, like ‚ÄúAll My Gold‚Äù (a rattling tribal affair that channels ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs A Girl To Do?‚Äù), ‚ÄúMarilyn‚Äù (like so many Bat For Lashes songs it is likeable because at points it just soars away into a beauty) and ‚ÄúA Wall‚Äù (simply because it was a grower and I have a grudging respect for songs that are growers). While the whole album doesn‚Äôt quite tell a whole story like ‚ÄúFur And Gold‚Äù did, I still believe it all hangs together well as a coherent collection of quality songs. Highly Recommended.

Ital ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù and ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù

These are two mini albums that Ital has released this year, ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù was released back in February (I got a copy in June) and ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù was released earlier this month.

It‚Äôs tempting to look at these two as two halves of a larger whole, especially as each ‚Äúalbum‚Äù is just around 42 minutes long. In the case of ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù, which consists of just five tracks, this mostly means long spools of near ambient dance music reminiscent of when ambient house had a significant house component to it. The music on ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù reminds me a lot of early tracks by The Orb. In fact it sounds more like The Orb‚Äôs early remixes like, say, Maurizio‚Äôs ‚ÄúPloy‚Äù (the astoundingly titled ‚ÄúBattersea Was An Island Of Mud mix‚Äù) ‚Äì particularly on tracks like ‚ÄúFloridian Void‚Äù that unravel into dark swirls of electronica.

On the other hand ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù puts that darkness front and centre. It‚Äôs a much more in your face record, it‚Äôs both aggressive and forthright. There are fewer, briefer, tracks though the opener ‚ÄúDespot‚Äù gets to be just that and rattle and stamp its way through nearly nine minutes of chopped up vocals and retro sounding synths (I‚Äôm sure I can hear something that sounds like a Fairlight in there).

Each album has a track that appropriates vocal samples from a big pop act: the opening track of ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt Matter (If You Love Him)‚Äù takes snippets of vocals from Lady Gaga and Whitney Houston and shreds them into a robotic mix. Even more drastic is ‚ÄúBoi‚Äù on ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù taking a sample of Beyonc√© singing ‚Äúbaby boy‚Äù and folding it back over itself over and over again for seven and a half minutes. Its one of those genuinely delightful repetitions that ends up seemingly distorted the repeated words into something else.

I really enjoyed both albums. They may not necessarily be two halves of one whole, but they are certainly enjoyable back to back. If I had to choose, my preference would be for ‚ÄúHive Mind‚Äù as it is a really absorbing collection of tunes and some of ‚ÄúDream On‚Äù is a little too abrasive for me.

Bjork ‚ÄúBastards‚Äù

Say what you like about Bj√∂rk, she doesn‚Äôt half know how to shift a lot of merchandise. This is yet another remix album, this time centred on the ‚ÄúBiophilia‚Äù album and mostly comprising a selection from a sequence of limited edition singles released throughout the year. I‚Äôve collected those singles and so I‚Äôve only listened to this album on Spotify because I have most of the tracks already.

It has to be said that I was really wanting to give this album a kicking because at first glance the tracklisting looks terrible - there are some glaring omissions and including one Death Grips mix (let alone two!) represents the inclusion of one Death Grips remix too many. Also, all of Biophilia‚Äôs tracks were covered over the course of the eight singles, so it makes no sense for this album not to do the same. Particularly when the most glaring omission is ‚ÄúCosmogony‚Äù which was the stand out track from ‚ÄúBiophilia‚Äù.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed the singles and so the bulk of the material here is good and I do find myself warming to the selection, it certainly flows quite well. Little experiments like including Matthew Herbert‚Äôs remix of ‚ÄúSacrifice‚Äù as a 50 second reprise after the horrible Death Grips version is a nice little experiment (though if I didn‚Äôt have the full version on single number 6 I would be a little miffed). There are still way too many mixes of ‚ÄúThunderbolt‚Äù for me, meaning that the line ‚Äúscrape these barnacles off me‚Äù (yes! really!) appears about four times over the run time of ‚ÄúBastards‚Äù.

The Oscar Souleyman mix of ‚ÄúCrystalline‚Äù is amazing and it wasn‚Äôt on the singles, it‚Äôs my favourite thing on the collection. But then the Current Value mix of ‚ÄúCrystalline‚Äù is awesome too and is sadly overlooked, admittedly in favour of his mix of ‚ÄúSolstice‚Äù so it‚Äôs not all bad. In my view, the wrong mix of ‚ÄúHollow‚Äù is on there too (but the good one is by Current Value too!) and if a mix of ‚ÄúThunderbolt‚Äù has to be there, then why on earth wasn‚Äôt it the King Cannibal one? Nevertheless, there are some small revelations: when I first heard the remix of ‚ÄúMutual Core‚Äù I was really underwhelmed, but there‚Äôs something about the way those Solomon Islands singers slot very nicely into the opening half of the mix.

Bj√∂rk has released better albums than ‚ÄúBiophilia‚Äù (something that I discussed last year) and has also released two better remix albums than ‚ÄúBastards‚Äù in the shape of the wonderful ‚ÄúThe Best Mixes from the Album Debut for All the People Who Don‚Äôt Buy White Labels‚Äù and ‚ÄúTelegram‚Äù. Those two told us new things about their parent albums: ‚ÄúThe Best Mixes from the Album Debut‚Ä¶‚Äù revealed anew the startling plasticity of her sound by manipulating the amazing songs from Debut into stellar symphonies of electronic music; while ‚ÄúTelegram‚Äù completely retooled ‚ÄúPost‚Äù into bizarre and wonderful shapes, into shapes so contorted that her next album would in fact have to be ‚ÄúHomogenic‚Äù in response. ‚ÄúBastards‚Äù does nothing for ‚ÄúBiophilia‚Äù, both are patchy albums and perhaps show that not only is Bj√∂rk is need of a reinvention (beyond apps) but that many of the people remixing her need new ideas too.

Brian Eno ‚ÄúLux‚Äù

‚ÄúA Small Craft On A Milk Sea‚Äù was one of my favourite albums of 2010 (it was, apparently, a reworking of a rejected soundtrack to Peter Jackson‚Äôs adaptation of ‚ÄúThe Lovely Bones‚Äù) and I wrote about how much I enjoyed last year‚Äôs collaboration on ‚ÄúDrums Between The Bells‚Äù with Rick Holland. I also chose ‚ÄúAmbient 2/Plateaux Of Mirror‚Äù as one of my understated classics, so there is a lot of Eno love on this blog.

‚ÄúLux‚Äù is a new solo album of four longish pieces, as with ‚ÄúMusic For Airports‚Äù each part would fill one side of vinyl. In general there isn‚Äôt much more to say. The music is like dappled sunlight or the shadows of billowing smoke: as much not there as it is there. It is not really minimalist but there is definitely an economy in the use of the elements of available. It drifts around the room and makes for very pleasant background listening.

entry.title: A Mountain Story
entry.content:
A cat reaches the top of a mountain after a long climb through the snow. He is cold from the bottom of his fur to the tips of his claws. He is sodden and wet, and we all know how much a cat hates to be wet.

At the top of the mountain there is not much to see. What may have been a breathtaking view is instead a murk of freezing mist and at any rate, snow assails the cat‚Äôs eyes and whiskers. He shivers and sneezes.

‚ÄúBless you!‚Äù cries a dog who is already there, he sits about twenty metres away and is wearing a pair of sunglasses. ‚ÄúCome here and rest a while weary traveller!‚Äù He motions to his left and sweeps about two inches of snow off the bench he is sitting on. It is painted green as though it has been just this instant transported from a suburban park.

The cat explains how arduous his journey has been. How he had heard the wolves howl in the evenings, how he had forded rushing rivers of water so cold he had feared that their icy grip would forever stain his bones, how the stark and unrelenting stare of the moon had borne down upon him with such cruelty that he swore that it had begun to mock him.

‚ÄúYou must be starving! How rude of me!‚Äù interrupts the dog. He offers the cat a bit of kitkat. It‚Äôs a green tea and white chocolate one, like they have in Japan. It tastes strange despite the cat not being sure whether he has ever eaten a regular kitkat anyway.

The cat gets upset. ‚ÄúWhy are you here? Did you not struggle also? Why are you wearing sunglasses? Why is this bench here? It doesn‚Äôt make any sense!‚Äù Hot tears streak down his face and they sizzle into the air, the warmest thing for miles around.

As the cat composes himself, the dog explains how all things are impermanent and transient. ‚ÄúAll of this is an illusion‚Äù he says, ‚Äúnot in the sense of whether it is real of course‚Ä¶‚Äù He leans forward and pinches the cat, who hisses in reaction. ‚ÄúNo, it is an illusion that any of this has a meaning and I am not just talking about park benches at the top of mountains or the cruel face of the moon‚Ä¶‚Äù

The cat stares out blankly at the snow. The mist billows into patterns that have never been seen before, patterns that will never be seen again.

The dog asks the cat to tell a joke.

The cat says that he doesn‚Äôt know any jokes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I never could remember them well and I could never really tell a story very well.‚Äù

To this the dog asks ‚Äúwell then, how on earth will you tell anyone about what happens next?‚Äù With these words, the dog hands his sunglasses to the cat and promptly disappears.

Meanwhile, on the mountain, the snow continues to fall.

entry.title: Understated Classics #21: Woob 2 by Woob
entry.content:
The second Woob album (AKA ‚ÄúWoob 4495‚Äù) is probably the greatest ambient album ever made and is certainly the best one you have never heard of. Originally released in 1995 on the em:t label it is also a rare record. I don‚Äôt have an actual copy but I have seen one! I downloaded it off the internet and even that is quite difficult to do. My friend is an avid collector of all the em:t releases and it is easy to see why: all the albums are titled in a specific way that is very appealing to people who like to collect things and they also have very striking nature photography on the covers. In a strange way, the label was able to create an identity for its releases in a way that many artists would try to.

Unfortunately the em:t label failed and it is hard to know if post-internet (things were still getting underway in the early/mid-90s) it might have had an easier time selling these albums. You can now get the first Woob album on iTunes and this second album was re-released in a remixed form as ‚ÄúRepurpose‚Äù back in 2010. There is a rabid second hand market for em:t records releases and ‚ÄúWoob 2‚Äù, sorry ‚ÄúWoob 4495‚Äù, is among the most sought-after.

When I listened to ‚ÄúWoob 2‚Äù again when I was writing this post something very obvious struck me about it. It is by far and away the most played record in my iTunes. I have played each track on the album (there are seven) between 57 and 75 times. I‚Äôve played the 25 minute track ‚ÄúDepart‚Äù 60 times, which means I have spent more than a day of my life listening to just that track.

Actually there is a very good reason why I have listened to this album so many times. It‚Äôs my favourite album for falling asleep to. I appreciate that this is hardly a ringing endorsement as it is unlikely that I would continually listen to it at night if it didn‚Äôt help me drop off ‚Äì and something that makes you fall asleep is not often considered as high art.

Except these are troubled times and reports show that people are finding it increasingly difficult to sleep. I know for a fact that my post containing five ideas to help you out when you can‚Äôt sleep is one of the most popular on the blog. Falling asleep is a big deal. In order to be able to sleep, you have to feel safe and secure, to be able to relax away from the stresses and trials of the day gone by.

As someone who cannot sleep without listening to music, I can tell you that there are actually very few albums that you can fall asleep to all the time. Granted there are times that you are so knackered that anything will send you off, but then on other occasions you can actively listen to something all the way through and be wide awake at the end. It‚Äôs also true that most ambient albums try to scupper any attempts to fall asleep, either with sudden loud noises or with spooky quotes. There‚Äôs an extended sample in the first Woob album that scares me too much to listen to at night, which is why it hasn‚Äôt be played anywhere near as much as the second one.

The music itself is very straightforward ambient music. There are synths, drones, chants, tribal drums, flutes, cheesy guitar riffs, bells, chimes, and insect chirps throughout. No vocals though (those formless chants aside) and so it‚Äôs a very pure natural experience. Personally I often find myself meditating on that toucan on the cover as I listen. Moreover, if you listen to it during the day (have a cup of coffee just in case), you find that it is actually a very active and engaging album. Sure, there is plenty of noodling that you can put to the back of your mind but the drums and melodies throughout are actually quite striking and emotive when you find yourself paying attention.

This album, perhaps more than other that I have written about, epitomises the understated classic. It‚Äôs an album that you are not likely to have heard of, one that you cannot get (unless you want to take a ¬£40 punt on a copy from eBay or go digging on useNet), one that is objectively brilliant, and one that I have a deep emotional connection to.

So what can you do if you fancy a listen? Well, if you know me you can obviously ask me for the MP3s or come over and have a listen first. Better still you could support Woob by buying ‚ÄúRepurpose‚Äù from their Bandcamp website (or you can listen to it there for free). ‚ÄúRepurpose‚Äù is described as a remastered ‚ÄúWoob 4495‚Äù with some detours and deviations, it really is just as good. Even better news (for me at least) is that there is also now a ‚ÄúWoob 3‚Äù (except it is called ‚ÄúHave Landed‚Äù) and you can buy that from their website too. All the collectors have already been there and got the limited edition stuff, but I‚Äôm off to get a digital version right now‚Ä¶ perhaps tonight it will be sending me to sleep!

entry.title: Ambitions
entry.content:
Sometimes, when I am feeling a bit down, I like to write down some of my ambitions. As you can see from this list they are mostly pretty humble but they are also a bit cheesy and embarassing, so I have put them after the fold!

  • Be wholehearted, cheerful, and sincere
  • Be creative
  • Look at the world and see its many faces, hear its many voices
  • Explore new recipes as often as possible when I cook
  • Learn to like the taste of tomatoes and cucumbers
  • Be more at ease around people
  • Listen to people and hear what they say
  • Play my part
  • Look after someone special
  • Become a parent
  • Share my values with others, help those who need it
  • Break up all the negative things inside me
  • Know what other people want, help them get it
  • When I wake up each morning I would like to remember my dreams
  • Understand art more than I do
  • Lose my fear of creepy crawlies
  • Learn to drive
  • Learn to write left handed (why not?)
  • Visit every country in Europe
  • Visit the radio telescopes on Mauna Kea in Hawaii
  • Let go of unnecessary things
  • Ditch social networks and the rest of the internet as much as possible
  • Learn to appreciate the noise around me
  • Meditate
  • Get over my reliance on sugar to improve my mood
  • Get rid of things I don‚Äôt need
  • Grow the garden
  • Write people letters
  • Learn the differences between species of trees
  • Be flexible and adaptable and positive about the future
  • Learn how to hang a picture on a wall

entry.title: Rust And Bone: A Short Review
entry.content:
So, two short reviews in a row. I had the day off work and went to see ‚ÄúRust And Bone‚Äù this afternooon. It‚Äôs the new film by Jacques Audiard, who directed ‚ÄúA Prophet‚Äù ‚Äì one of my favourite films of the last five years1.

‚ÄúRust And Bone‚Äù is a love story about Ali, a sexually feckless security guard who is struggling to look after his young son on his own, and St√©phanie (played by second most beautiful woman in the world, Marion Cotillard), who is injured while working as a co-ordinator of killer whale displays at an ocenarium. Needless to say it is not a minor injury. The film is basically their love story. I don‚Äôt feel so much responsibility to hide plot details about this film because, to be frank, I could type out the whole plot here and it wouldn‚Äôt convey the reasons why it‚Äôs so great.

Whereas ‚ÄúSkyfall‚Äù was an enjoyable film by virtue of being well paced dumb entertainment, ‚ÄúRust And Bone‚Äù is that other type of great film: the one that tries to tell us a new story while trying to explain something about all of us at the same time. It‚Äôs full of gritty moments, both physical and psychological, and also moments of transcendant delight and beauty. There were points were it felt like a wire was being worked into my chest and yet there are also moments of deep delight and sweetness. For the most part it is shot with a documentary style that makes it feel very immediate and real, but as with ‚ÄúA Prophet‚Äù there are also giddy slow motion shots and scenes that are loose and unstructured and dream-like. However, what drives it more than anything else is two superb acting performances by Marion Cotilliard and Matthias Schoenaerts.

Unfortunately, it‚Äôs not a flawless movie. It runs out of steam at the end despite maintaining the high drama and the fact that probably the most unpleasant scene is near the end of the film. I felt that it could have been slightly longer to help tease out some of what happened. Sometimes a lack of exposition in a movie helps to build mystery but here it just smacks of poor editing, to the point where I feel a bit like I haven‚Äôt watched a complete film. That‚Äôs probably harsher criticism than I intend given my feelings for the movie as a whole.

When I described the film to my housemate earlier this evening, I realised that so much of what I had seen had been geared to getting me to understand the characters and to feel for them. I had to describe convoluted cause and effect ripples through the plot as one person‚Äôs actions impacted on others. I was describing the characters (especially Ali) as though they were people that I knew (or at least had watched in a soap opera for a long time!) and it was quite disconcerting how far the film had got under my skin. It‚Äôs highly recommended.

Finally, I also really enjoyed the soundtrack. The score was by Alexandre Desplat who also did ‚ÄúMoonrise Kingdom‚Äù and the soundtrack also includes Bon Iver and Lykke Li, along with a dance remix of ‚ÄúState Trooper‚Äù by Bruce Springsteen ‚Äì something that I had long imagined myself.

  1. I will certainly be digging out my DVD copy of ‚ÄúA Prophet‚Äù this weekend.¬†↩

entry.title: Skyfall: A Short Review
entry.content:
I went to see ‚ÄúSkyfall‚Äù last night and I really enjoyed it. I knew nothing about the plot, mostly because I had avoided all discussion of the plot with people who had already seen it and I even avoided reviews as so many these days seem to just rattle off plot points, instead of discussing what makes the movie any good. With that in mind I will obviously try not to give away any of the plot in this brief review.

I think ‚ÄúSkyfall‚Äù is probably the most enjoyable Bond movie that I have seen. It takes a lot of the now familiar formula - starting in medias res, lavish animated intro (Adele‚Äôs theme song is stunning), a completely unhinged villain - and manages to produce a solid and entertaining film.

In one of it‚Äôs blogs this week the Guardian asked whether Bond had become too grim and serious. I‚Äôd say that Skyfall does have a more mournful tone but there are hints of light and brightness too. There were plenty of moments where the whole cinema laughed as one. I think the days of Roger Moore‚Äôs arched eyebrows are over, as are lazy characterisations of slapstick American sherrifs who are fat and short-tempered. I am glad that ‚ÄúSkyfall‚Äù isn‚Äôt a po-mo- deconstruction of who or what Bond should represent in the twenty-first century, I like that there is some suspension of belief.

Nevertheless it is a modern Bond film and I think it shows most in the cinematography. There were scenes that just looked wonderfully beautiful and bonkers at the same time. They reminded me of scenes from ‚ÄúEnter The Void‚Äù and I think it is great that a populist vehicle such as a Bond movie is being used to introduce people to wonderful cinematography. I realised a few scenes later that it is a large part of Bond‚Äôs popularity, that each Bond movie is partly a reflection of our times. For fifty years the Bond movie has been a sort of travelogue introducing (or re-introducing) us to parts of the world.

I thought the acting was excellent and to my eyes Daniel Craig is fast becoming the definitive Bond. Javier Bardem‚Äôs turn as the scenery-chewing baddie is really something to behold, though his performance feels a bit wasted in this plot and it might have been better for him to play someone intent on blowing up the moon or something. It‚Äôs always good to see Ben Whishaw in anything but he‚Äôs underused and I‚Äôve already been spoiled by his stunning performance as Richard II in ‚ÄúThe Hollow Crown‚Äù on the BBC earlier this year.

entry.title: Album Digest, October 2012
entry.content:
It has been a strange month and I found that I didn‚Äôt listen to a lot of new music. I have been a bit down and when that‚Äôs the case I tend to take refuge in music that I know well, stuff that cheers me up. I have listened to last month‚Äôs fave a lot, Nelly Furtado‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Spirit Indestructible‚Äù. I said a lot of nice things about it but it probably didn‚Äôt come over in my writing just how much I really liked it.

Meanwhile, there were five albums I mostly got my teeth into this month though I didn‚Äôt listen to them as often as I would have liked. I will write now about four of the five that are similar to one another. The fifth album is ‚ÄúThe Haunted Man‚Äù by Bat For Lashes, but I will wait until next month to write about that as I‚Äôd like to take a little more time to unpack it and get to know the songs better. The other four albums don‚Äôt really have songs, so it is less of a problem. All four are by and large abstract electronic albums and so I am going to write about them in a pretty general way. The albums are:

  1. ‚ÄúDependent And Happy‚Äù by Ricardo Villalobos
  2. ‚ÄúThe Expanding Universe‚Äù by Laurie Spiegel
  3. ‚ÄúJiaolong‚Äù by Daphni
  4. ‚ÄúMala In Cuba‚Äù by Mala

I had heard a lot of strange things about Ricardo Villalobos. He was one of the first artists to turn in a Fabric compiliation consisting solely of his own tracks (I wrote about a similar enterprise by Guy Gerber in June) and then there was that weird business of the 31 minute single based around a single trumpet sample or something (which I haven‚Äôt yet heard). ‚ÄúDependent and Happy‚Äù was released in two versions: a CD with 11 tracks and then a 14 track version across 3 12‚Äù packs (2 double and one single, making for ten sides in total). Despite already having adventures with vinyl this year, I decided to buy the CD version and then cheekily get the versions from the vinyl edition by (ahem) other means. It‚Äôs not just a case of missing out on three tracks if you stick to the CD version, the vinyl contains longer versions of some of the tracks. (I did not actually manage to get a rip of the third vinyl, so I am two tracks down on this version of the album, though one of them is on the CD and is probably, at 12 minutes long, unedited).

The tracks on the vinyl version are longer and are perhaps meant to be consumed at three seperate sittings, whereas the CD features shorter tracks that are mixed together and to be consumed all in one go. Either way it‚Äôs an exhausting album of minimal techno that on headphones worms its way into your ears and shatters your brain. I think I prefer the CD version for its brevity, though there is a lot to favour the widescreen and sinuous 12 minute vinyl version of ‚ÄúTu Actiuud‚Äù over the 9 minute one on the CD. I really haven‚Äôt listened to it enough to remember what else pops out apart from the amazing last track (on the CD) called ‚ÄúDie Schwarze Massai‚Äù, it‚Äôs quite short and it bubbles along in a crisp way ‚Äì like a slightly more animated version of Mohn.

If ‚ÄúDependent And Happy‚Äù is all sleek modern abstraction, then the reissue of Laurie Spiegel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Exanding Universe‚Äù represents an origin point of sorts. The music on ‚ÄúThe Expanding Universe‚Äù was composed and recorded with the computers at Bell Laboratories in the mid to late 1970s. Just 5 of the 19 tracks on this reissue were on the original album, so it represents a really interesting archive of music being made with computers at that time. There are really interesting liner notes with the CD and I‚Äôm looking forward to reading them more closely.

The music here is a gentle classical music of sorts entirely created on computers. Obviously there were analogue synths as early as the late 60s but computer music in the 70s would have relied on machines the size of a fridge and operated by punch card, a wholly different way of creating music digitally than is the case today. However, the important question is whether, as with Kraftwerk, the music stands up as something innately interesting rather than simply as a curio or evolutionary waypoint in the development of electronic music. I think that the music does indeed stand up well to the passage of time. It is quite minimal and relies on repetition and counterpoint, but it is really quite relaxing and beautiful. Perhaps the best example of just how pretty some of the tracks are is ‚ÄúEast River Dawn‚Äù, a wonderfully shifting piece lasting just over 14 minutes that evokes its title perfectly.

I had an interesting thought about this music in relation to the minimalism of Philip Glass and others. I often feel that the minimalist composers are not very compassionate to the people who have to perform their pieces. I did wonder whether the pieces on ‚ÄúThe Expanding Universe‚Äù, written to be performed by a computer, are in fact more human (and humane) than the pieces composed with the intention to be performed by humans. I guess it is a minor point.

I have not listened to Daphni‚Äôs ‚ÄúJiaoLong‚Äù anywhere near enough. I know this because every time that I do listen to it, I have a whale of a time. In many ways it is a similar album to Four Tet‚Äôs ‚ÄúPink‚Äù (which I wrote about last month): a collection of tracks recorded for various twelve inches and DJ sets ‚Äì this time by Dan Snaith, the central brain behind Manitoba/Caribou. These tracks are clearly geared toward the dancefloor, no mucking about, and they are all the more enjoyable for it. I tried to do some work while listening to this and I just ended up dancing along instead.

Another thing I like about this album is that it is pretty brief, so nothing overstays its welcome. My favourite tracks: ‚ÄúYes, I Know‚Äù a wonderful collision between something really wiggy like Vitalic‚Äôs ‚ÄúPoney‚Äù and a 70‚Äôs dancefloor hit‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶that sounds like it‚Äôs playing in a dustbin; ‚ÄúPairs‚Äù a steady simple track that is grafiti‚Äôd with all manner of basslines and synth squiggles; ‚ÄúSprings‚Äù which descends into tweaky acid madness that really does make you think of springs; ‚ÄúLong‚Äù, a warm and hazy closing track that is probably as warm and cosy as a track still aimed squarely at the floor could possibly be.

‚ÄúMala In Cuba‚Äù is an intruiging dubstep album built out of samples sourced by Mala on a trip to Cuba. Unfortunately, while it is certainly an interesting listen, I found that the fusion of the two worlds was not quite as complete as I‚Äôd hoped. It strikes me as much more of a dubstep album than one filled with references to Cuba or Cuban music. In fact it isn‚Äôt really until about halfway through the album (‚ÄúComo Como‚Äù) when a bit of real latin flavour really starts to shine through. ‚ÄúCuba Electronic‚Äù (which follows ‚ÄúComo Como‚Äù) is probably the first successful attempt to produce something genuinely new on the album ‚Äì a wonderful skittering rush that leans heavily on latin percussion samples. Up until then there are clearly latin sounds present but the atmosphere is much more Hoxton than Havana, it‚Äôs a rather homeopathic infusion of latin beats into the dubstep sound. (However I do need to listen to it a few more times‚Ä¶)

I think the track that really hammers home just how good an album ‚ÄúMala In Cuba‚Äù could have been is the final track ‚ÄúNoche Sue√±os‚Äù: the vocal helps to establish the flavour but I also think it is the reason for retaining more instrumentation so that while the synths and drum machines provide surface detail, there are also some organic elements that help to sustain the atmosphere. However, listening to the track again for the purposes of writing this, I found that there were more electronics present than I remembered ‚Äì again showing how much more successful ‚ÄúNoche Sue√±os‚Äù is compared to the rest of the project.

entry.title: Stevenage vs Portsmouth
entry.content:
Tonight, despite feeling a bit under the weather, I went to Stevenage to watch Portsmouth play a League One game at the Lamex Stadium. In addition, I met a ‚Äúperson off the internet‚Äù for the second time in a week ‚Äì this time Tom, a friend of a friend from Facebook: our shared passions being Portsmouth FC and really cool music. We met at King‚Äôs Cross and caught a packed train to Stevenage, a non-descript dormitory town that was even more non-descript than I remember St Albans being. I‚Äôm glad I went, even though Pompey lost. It‚Äôs funny how sitting in a shed in the cold watching your team lose counts as entertainment!

Impressions of the Lamex stadium

I haven‚Äôt been to many football grounds, until tonight it had just been Fratton Park, Twerton Park, Craven Cottage, La Romareda (in Zaragoza, Spain) and two versions of Wembley.The Lamex was pretty much how I expected it but it seems ideal for the needs of the club. It‚Äôs fairly functional but the constant drizzle was kept off our heads and our seats were decent enough to see everything. The funniest chant of the night from the Pompey fans was ‚Äúyour shed‚Äôs too big for you‚Äù ‚Äì a bit rich I thought, given the state of Fratton Park, but sometimes it‚Äôs nice to dish it out when you‚Äôve had to take it for years. One side of the pitch was standing-only, a definite echo of the club‚Äôs non-league past but also a source of (admittedly intermittent) buzzing pulsating noise. At times you wondered if their fans thought they were at a rave rather than a football match such was their admirable commitment to bouncing up and down like lunatics.

The match

Beforehand I‚Äôd said to Tom that I thought Portsmouth might lose. Stevenage are doing really well and were second place in League One going into this game. Meanwhile Pompey were unbeaten in five games prior to this match. Something had to give and my prediction was that it would be Pompey: it can‚Äôt be easy for our flung together bunch of players to get results (half) week in (half) week out. I was right, Portsmouth lost 2-1. On the train home, I ruefully looked at the stats in the programme I had bought and noticed that neither team had lost after taking the lead this season. It‚Äôs all the more frustrating then that Stevenage scored a soft goal quite early, taking advantage of some non-existent marking. After that Portsmouth, who had already started timidly, proceeded to disappear from the rest of the first half.

The second half was a much better performance from Pompey ‚Äì it probably helped that they were playing towards the goal that we were all roaring at them from behind and that they are the best scorers in the league in the second half of games this season. There was a great chance for Wes Thomas that nearly went in and I think that if it had the game would have been Pompey‚Äôs. As it was we had to wait a little bit longer until a rather flukey looking goal from Jon Harley (who was probably Pompey‚Äôs man of the match for me) equalised. Pompey obviously scented blood but Stevenage had settled and began to carve out chances of their own. Just ten minutes later they scored a well-taken goal from a set piece and it felt again like it had been a gift from Pompey, bitterly disappointing.

After that, all the attacking threat came from Pompey but with very little end product. Izale Mcloed was only intermittently lively (I was looking forward to seeing him play so it was a bit of a disappointment) and I think a lot of the players did not know how to make the right sort of incisive final pass or cross that would set up genuine opportunities. The number of shots and shots on target given in the BBC‚Äôs match report seems false to me (maybe they did better in the first half up the other end in the mist than it seemed in the away end) but there you go. Still, I don‚Äôt think any of the Pompey players were in any way half-hearted‚Ä¶ I went home sad rather than angry.

The end bit

Football is an expensive game now. The ticket cost ¬£23 and the train journey (lasting 26 minutes) from King‚Äôs Cross cost ¬£18. The food at the ground looked reasonable (well, certainly hefty) but I don‚Äôt know the price because I‚Äôd already had a pasty before leaving London. I certainly couldn‚Äôt afford that every week, so I definitely have a great respect for my fellow Pompey fans who sang amazingly despite the situation and the cold!

Oh and finally a word of praise must go out to the tannoy announcer at the Lamex Stadium, he was a sort of cross between Stuart Hall, Alan Partridge, and a vicar at a village fete. Could have done without the speakers being up at ear-splitting volume though, I bet it‚Äôs only like that in the away end.

entry.title: Nonlinear Systems: A Rough Intro
entry.content:
This is another mathematics post that does not actually feature any equations or graphs. It is intended to set the way clear for writing regularly about nonlinear systems. This in itself is a precursor to writing more about mathematical biology as biological systems are inherently complex and nonlinear. I am reading P. G. Drazin‚Äôs textbook on Nonlinear Systems and this post is a glossary of terms from the start of the book laid down here because I wanted to remember how to typeset definition lists in Markdown (though in the end I (ab)used <h4> tags because it looked better).

Nonlinear system

A set of nonlinear equations, which may be algebraic, functional, ordinary differential, partial differential, integral or a combination of these. Often the system will depend on given parameters. It is generally helpful to think of a nonlinear system as a feedback loop in which the response is not proportional to the the input. There are a great number of applications for the theory of nonlinear systems, as we shall see when the series of mathematical biology posts really gets going.

Dynamical system

Pretty much a synonym for nonlinear system but an emphasis is usually placed on the evolution of a solution over time or a time-like variable. The phrase comes from the name of equations governing the motion of a system of particles.

Nonlinearity, effect of

As a parameter that governs a particular system changes slowly, a solution may change into slowly and continuously or abruptly and discontinuously (a catastrophe).

Steady solution (steady state)

A persistent long-term solution of a set of nonlinear equations.

Stable solution (stable steady state)

Those solutions to a system that if perturbed slightly remain near their starting position for ever afterward. Usually such solutions are the more frequently observed (e.g. a body at rest on a smooth surface).

Unstable solution (unstable steady state)

Some systems can be perturbed from rest and not respond in a predictable fashion. The long term behaviour of an unstable solution will depend significantly on the nature of the initial displacement and the system may move a long way from its initial position.

Butterfly Effect

A popular characterisation of an unstable solution to a nonlinear system is that ‚Äúa butterfly flapping its wings in Tokyo today could cause a hurricane in Paris next week‚Äù, the intention being to capture how small changes in the initial conditions of a complex nonlinear system such as the atmosphere can lead to large disturbances in the system over time.

Bifurcation

If a parameter of a nonlinear system is varied and the qualitative nature of the solutions change, a bifurcation is said to have occurred. Specifically the study of bifurcations is the study of how the number of steady states of a nonlinear system change as its parameters are varied.

Symmetry breaking

Bifurcations can also alter the symmetry of solutions to nonlinear systems. By symmetry we mean that the set of solutions of the nonlinear system is invariant under some group of translations (but the solutions therein need not be invariant). The presence of symmetries is often closely connected to the stability of solutions of the underlying nonlinear system. Whenever symmetries are involved, group theory looms large. A refresher on groups will follow in a few weeks.

Periodic solutions

Some systems will have periodic stable solutions. Bifurcating parameters can also feature regimes with periodic solutions.

Chaotic solutions

Nonlinear systems may have aperiodic solutions that appear to be random yet have stationary statistical properties (the mean and variance do not change with time). These are called chaotic solutions. Such solutions can be considered stable if they persist for all time.

That concludes the list and is pretty much all that can be said without providing proper mathematical definitions. The next post in this sequence will also be rather basic, a list of types of bifurcations illustrated by a few graphs. There will be equations galore and hopefully the graphs will be special too, rather than jpgs exported from R. After that, we‚Äôll get into the good stuff.

entry.title: Album Digest, September 2012
entry.content:
I had a bit more time to listen to this month‚Äôs albums because I was on holiday for two weeks. I didn‚Äôt manage to write about them while on holiday though! In fact I bought and listened to a few more, but I will save them for next month. The albums I will discuss now (in order bought) are:

  1. Four Tet ‚ÄúPink‚Äù
  2. The xx ‚ÄúCoexist‚Äù
  3. Nelly Furtado ‚ÄúThe Spirit Indestructible‚Äù
  4. Grizzly Bear ‚ÄúShields‚Äù

It‚Äôs quite a diverse collection and, Four Tet apart, quite song based.

Four Tet ‚ÄúPink‚Äù

‚ÄúPink‚Äù is a collection of tracks that were self-released on vinyl throughout the last year. The first track ‚ÄúLocked‚Äù was featured on Four Tet‚Äôs fabriclive mix that I wrote about in last Semptember‚Äôs album digest (as was ‚ÄúPyramid‚Äù), there it was the closing track in the mix and served to wind everything down. It is strange how well it also works as a build-up track, I haven‚Äôt checked to see if they are the same version but the one on ‚ÄúPink‚Äù slowly builds, introducing various elements (including‚Ä¶) in turn.

‚ÄúLion‚Äù has a wonderfully spooky riff that looms into view at about 2:50 over an old school beat but it pretty much holds that structure until about 8:00 (with about 50 seconds to go) when the pulse of the track is lowered and some gentle chimes introduced. ‚ÄúLion‚Äù definitely strikes me as one side of a twelve inch, it‚Äôs structure is one of getting into a groove and holding that for a fixed period ‚Äì either until the chimes or until something is dropped into the mix.

Perhaps it is foreknowledge of how this album came to exist but compared to ‚ÄúThere Is Love In You‚Äù, ‚ÄúPink‚Äù definitely feels like a collection of discrete entities. Most of the tracks here could stand alone, but I couldn‚Äôt imagine listening to ‚ÄúLove Cry‚Äù without also hearing ‚ÄúSing‚Äù or ‚ÄúAngel Echoes‚Äù in the same fifty or so minutes. Here you have those floor-oriented tracks but there are also tracks like ‚ÄúJupiters‚Äù, which, despite being one of the shortest tracks, features about three movements in just under six minutes.

‚ÄúOcoras‚Äù is another short and simple track, while ‚Äú128 Harps‚Äù doesn‚Äôt seem to feature 128 harps but does seem to feature the main riff of ‚ÄúMoon‚Äù, the opening track from Bjork‚Äôs ‚ÄúBiophilia‚Äù. It also has some nice texture and a weird sampled vocal loop, one of those that seems to blur into swearwords as it is repeated over and over.

I don‚Äôt really remember where ‚ÄúPyramid‚Äù slots into Four Tet‚Äôs fabric mix but I do remember the vocal loop. I think we can count it as one of the set-building tracks here. After that comes ‚ÄúPeace For Earth‚Äù, the longest and most satisfying track on ‚ÄúPink‚Äù. It is quite slow and ambient throughout, at points it resembles something from Brian Eno and Howard Budd‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmbient 2: The Plateaux Of Mirror‚Äù. Elsewhere (around the 5:00 mark) it picks up the pace a little and could be said to resemble ‚ÄúSing‚Äù (a sort of slowed-down, weirder, cousin) from the previous album, especially the longer edit that appeared on the single.

‚ÄúPink‚Äù rounds out with ‚ÄúPinnacles‚Äù, which plays out in style of ‚ÄúLocked‚Äù and ‚ÄúLion‚Äù but is perhaps a little more interesting because it features elements that are closer to something song-based. I‚Äôm not describing what I mean very well!

The xx ‚ÄúCoexist‚Äù

‚ÄúCoexist‚Äù is the second album by The xx and much like the first one, it‚Äôs quite slight and evasive. Every song is short and fleeting, many are similar to one another, giving the impression of a thirty five minute suite of songs that are facets of one larger whole. That said, this album does throw in some spikier bits than the previous one (though admittedly that would not be that hard).

I think that the first track ‚ÄúAngels‚Äù is beautiful and I was blown away when I heard it in advance of the album. In many ways it is even sparer than most of the songs on ‚ÄúXx‚Äù and it weaves into that time between sunset and streetlights, a perfect song for dusk. Sadly, it‚Äôs the high point of an album that‚Äôs interesting as an experiment but not really that great as a bunch of songs.

‚ÄúFiction‚Äù has a nice pulse to it (the whole album is ‚Äúnice‚Äù), but the chiming guitar riff that runs through it and the previous song ‚ÄúChained‚Äù are like echoes of ‚ÄúAngels‚Äù so the first three tracks all feel like different parts of one whole.

Meanwhile ‚ÄúTry‚Äù has this weird slowed-down siren of a riff but that‚Äôs really the only thing that sets it apart from ‚ÄúAngels‚Äù, ‚ÄúChained‚Äù and ‚ÄúFiction‚Äù. This seems to be the problem with the album. On the first album, songs like ‚ÄúVCR‚Äù and ‚ÄúIslands‚Äù stood out from the rest of the songs on the album and also seemed to be about different things, whereas ‚ÄúCoexist‚Äù is a bunch of songs that basically do just that‚Ä¶ they coexist, layering over the top of one another and all moping about a point of indeterminacy in a relationship.

If you have ‚ÄúCoexist‚Äù on in the background for it‚Äôs thirty five minute runtime, you‚Äôll lift your head once or twice to pay attention and that‚Äôs it. Unfortunately it‚Äôs boring enough to work to (how do you think I got all this website organised on my holiday?!) but too boring to fall asleep to.

Nelly Furtado ‚ÄúThe Spirit Indestructible‚Äù

Fortunately, a Nelly Furtado album is never boring. ‚ÄúThe Spirt Indestructible‚Äù might be a bit lowest common denominator in parts and extra-cheesy in others, but it knows where your pleasure centres are and determinedly attempts to tap them repeatedly over its twelve song core. It is largely successful in doing so.

In general, the songs are better than they were on ‚ÄúLoose‚Äù and once again they can be divided into broad groups: relentlessly positive (the title track, ‚ÄúHigh-Life‚Äù, ‚ÄúBucket List‚Äù, ‚ÄúEnemy‚Äù, ‚ÄúBelievers (Arab Spring)‚Äù), hip-hop dalliances (‚ÄúHigh Life‚Äù, ‚ÄúSomething‚Äù), ill-advised sexual braggadocio (thankfully restricted to just ‚ÄúHoops (The Bigger The Better)‚Äù this time), party tunes (‚ÄúParking Lot‚Äù, ‚ÄúWaiting For The Night‚Äù) and keening love songs (‚ÄúThe Most Beautiful Thing‚Äù, ‚ÄúCircles‚Äù).

That classification might make ‚ÄúThe Spirit Indestructible‚Äù look like a bit of a mess and on the first few listens it is, a chaotic jumble of styles that very much confirms the rumours that it was repeatedly put back by the record company because they had no idea how to sell it. However, after a few listens it begins to knit together really well (despite the fact that much like her still-best album ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù it does sag a bit at the end) because there are tracks that span several of the categories. For example, the title track also has a party bit in it even if it is a shame that the lyrics to the middle 8 are just the repetition of ‚ÄúAEIOU‚Äù (well I did say it was lowest common denominator in parts).

NAS throws in a rather perfunctory rap and steals the limelight on ‚ÄúSomething‚Äù (nice Terminator reference though), which would otherwise be a rather sweet and understated song about love and trust (Hook: ‚ÄúI want to give you something / I know how to make something out of nothing‚Äù). However, on ‚ÄúHigh Life‚Äù the rap verses really add to the song and transform it into something bigger.

I was quite impressed with ‚ÄúParking Lot‚Äù. It might sound like M.I.A. (uncannily so) but smoothed down and made ‚Äúchart friendly‚Äù (whatever that means now that the charts mean virtually nothing), but there‚Äôs a nice spark to it ‚Äì and there‚Äôs no way that M.I.A. could squeeze in the deliriously demented doowop bit at the end either. (Also, M.I.A‚Äôs third album was terrible ‚Äì so we should be grateful for mainstream clones.)

I won‚Äôt carry on and tell you about every song, but I should mention ‚ÄúCircles‚Äù because for ages I completely ignored it. It‚Äôs tucked away deep in the album‚Äôs weaker second half and while it is rather understated, it‚Äôs a lovely little love song that deserves your attention. Nelly actually does these really well, I guess that‚Äôs why quite a few people pine for another album like ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù.

To finish up, this a great little mainstream album that will cheer you up if you are down and is great in the mornings for getting you pepped up for the day ahead.

Grizzly Bear ‚ÄúShields‚Äù

‚ÄúShields‚Äù strikes me as being similar to ‚ÄúLife‚Äôs Rich Pageant‚Äù by R.E.M., not so much in terms of sound but in terms of marking a point where a band suddenly clicks, realises its strengths, and decides to play to all of them at once. Another similar comparison might be ‚ÄúOK Computer‚Äù by Radiohead, where that band not only delivered the songs but also a coherent aesthetic to go with them. I think ‚ÄúShields‚Äù is a fantastic album, full of stunning songs all wrapped up in a gorgeous sound world that is at once both familiar and totally unique.

‚ÄúSleeping Ute‚Äù is apparently the sole surviving song from an initial recording session for this album and it still has the air of ‚ÄúVeckatimest‚Äù hanging around its shoulders. When ‚ÄúSpeak In Rounds‚Äù kicks in, the difference is obvious ‚Äì the two singers‚Äô voices are much more confident and the pace of the song turns on a sixpence thanks to the fantastic playing of the band. Previously Grizzly Bear songs shimmered and simmered but ‚ÄúSpeak In Rounds‚Äù just leaps out of the speakers and sounds like it has always existed, has always been a classic.

Everything on ‚ÄúShields‚Äù‚Äù sounds purposeful and engaged, even the hallucinatory little instrumental ‚ÄúAdelma‚Äù. Right from the first line of ‚ÄúYet Again‚Äù a story is being told, whereas on previous albums songs like ‚ÄúDory‚Äù (nudge, nudge, wink, wink) and ‚ÄúTwo Weeks‚Äù seemed to just hover and be impressionistic. Going back to the R.E.M. comparison that I started with, early tracks like ‚ÄúLaughing‚Äù and ‚ÄúHarborcoat‚Äù are among my favourite songs but more for mood than meaning, whereas something later like ‚ÄúWelcome To The Occupation‚Äù is much more engaged with the world.

The sense of atmosphere and place has not been abandoned though, the squally outro to ‚ÄúYet Again‚Äù and the dense sonics of ‚ÄúThe Hunt‚Äù (not to mention the more familiar vocal) capably show that. It‚Äôs just that now a sense of engagement and spirit now courses through the band‚Äôs playing. The lyrics are better too, I looked them up on the internet and the nature of the singing means that there are still liberal ‚Äú???‚Äù‚Äôs strewn throughout people‚Äôs transcriptions but as I listened closely and filled in the gaps, I fell deeper in love with these songs. Check out the lyrics to ‚ÄúA Simple Answer‚Äù, they‚Äôre excellent. The last time I remember being so deliberately engaged with a band‚Äôs lyrics was with those on ‚ÄúAlligator‚Äù by The National.

I‚Äôd write more but all the songs are quite dense and so I need to listen to them a lit more to fully get to grips with them. I guess that is a hearty recommendation in itself but let‚Äôs be completely unequivocal: ‚ÄúShields‚Äù is thoroughly recommended as one of the best albums of the year so far.

entry.title: Jon McGregor, Even The Dogs
entry.content:
Over my holiday I read ‚ÄúEven The Dogs‚Äù by Jon McGregor. I‚Äôve not quite finished it yet but that will at least prevent me from giving away spoilers. I am not sure I would want to give any spoilers anyway because it is unrelentingly grim so far. Perhaps there is a happy ending but both you and I will have to read it to find out.

I was introduced to Jon McGregor by the book group I was part of during my PhD. I think ‚ÄúIf Nobody Speaks Of Remarkable Things‚Äù was the first book I read for the group. At that time of my life, about eight or so years after finishing my English Literature A-level, I had not had to read a book that I had not chosen for myself for quite a long time. I found it to be a complete shock. I can still remember reading about half that book straight out of the amazon packaging.

After that I had his next novel ‚ÄúSo Many Ways To Begin‚Äù on my shelf unread for a while as I wrote up my PhD1 and I finally got around to reading it once I‚Äôd finished my corrections. Reading a novel in the evenings after work is a unique pleasure, a kind of escapism that I am now long used to but new to me at the time2. It is a bittersweet love story that shows how unresolved issues in peoples‚Äô lives can undermine and destroy relationships. I realised later when I re-read it that it contained numerous warnings that I should have heeded myself. All the best novels do.

What makes McGregor‚Äôs novels stand out for me is the way that is able to get into his characters‚Äô heads. The prose that he writes is a joyous cascade of thoughts tumbling out all over the page. It is remarkable how precisely he is able to match the rhythms and intonations of thoughts, though perhaps not surprising as the aim of the writer has long been to try and completely capture human experiences so that another might live them.3

‚ÄúEven The Dogs‚Äù is no exception. It begins with the discovery of a man‚Äôs body found in his derelict flat and as the consequences of this unfold linearly, those who knew him explain how he came to be there and how their lives had become so intertwined and similarly ruined. This is all achieved using the thoughts and memories of the people involved, who are nearly all alcoholics and junkies so you get very disordered and chaotic descriptions of what went on. Sections of the prose often end mid-sentence and sometimes they repeat, folding over themselves, detailing the obsessions and thought processes of these people who have been pushed to the very furthest periphery of society.

The novel boils with both rage and sadness. The sections where characters remember sessions of talking therapy and interactions with case workers are seared with a sense of incredulity both for the sincerity of those ‚Äúthere to help‚Äù and the fact that know they are there to ‚Äúget another script‚Äù. The description of life on the street is as relentless and as bleak as you could hope to imagine, and is utterly convincing in its realisation. It made me realise that even in a society where no one should be homeless or hungry or left in the grip of drug or alcohol addiction, people do still fall through the cracks. I don‚Äôt feel qualified to say how I think these people should be helped. However, the way that you experience the pivot points in characters‚Äô lives through their thoughts and memories made me realise that one of the best things that we can do is to prevent similar pivots happening in the lives of those people that we encounter. This is something I want to write about in more detail later.

Because of the subject matter, the book is not a pleasant read but because of the quality of the writing, it is thoroughly compelling. Here‚Äôs a short excerpt from page 108 of my copy:

Waiting for the gear to cool in the syringe, and peeling back your clothes to find a vein. Stroking the skin on your arms, running cold steady fingers down the pulsing cords of your neck. Easing your trousers down and spreading your legs to find the bruised and scabbing entrance wounds along your fem. There, or there, or there. Hushed and holding your breath.

Waiting to feel the gear hit home, those long seconds between sticking in the pin and the gear doing what it does to your body and your brain and whatever else, your, fucking, soul. Waiting for all that pain to just get taken away. Wiped away, washed away. Or waiting for the meth to seep into you and get rid of that rattling for a few hours more, get rid of all the things that come up on you with the sickness. To hold you for the few hours while you work on getting sorted again. To keep the troubles away. The fucking troubles. The things that come to mind when you rather they didn‚Äôt come to mind, certain things. Certain things which if you‚Äôre not careful they all come pouring out the same way your guts come pouring out when you get sick, when you go too long without getting sorted. Comes pouring out of you. When you rather it didn‚Äôt. When rather none of it came to mind.

Waiting outside the chemist‚Äôs all them mornings, Mike and Danny and Heather and Laura and Bristol John, Stevie, Maggie, Ben, necking our little paper cups of meth, draining the thick green syrup and licking our lips and Mike going Eh now if it weren‚Äôt for this stuff there‚Äôd be a what‚Äôs it called a like uprising or insurrection or something you know what I‚Äôm saying.

It‚Äôs the opium of the masses is what it is pal.

His most recent book ‚ÄúThis Isn‚Äôt The Sort Of Thing That Happens To Someone Like You‚Äù is a collection of short stories. It won‚Äôt be available in paperback until February next year but I will be eagerly picking up a copy when it is.

  1. Ah, the Waterstone‚Äôs 3 for 2, stealthily slipping books on to my shelves between 1999 and 2010.¬†↩

  2. Presumably my ability to distinguish between my PhD and a ‚Äúproper job‚Äù points to a deep defect in my personality (or at least explains why it took me so long).¬†↩

  3. I feel a great urge to cite Proust and his madelines here but until I have taken my tanker trip around the world and read ‚ÄúA la recherche du temps perdu‚Äù I will resist this temptation. Or at the very least until I have read ‚ÄúProust Was A Neuroscientist‚Äù.¬†↩

entry.title: Programming a Carcassonne Game
entry.content:
Although I have put off finishing my UNO game for over eighteen months, I thought I would get started with another pet project of mine: making a Carcassonne game. This is not a serious affair, there is an excellent app of Carcassonne available for those of you who have iOS devices (it works particularly well on the iPad). The game just strikes me as having the right level of complexity to be a taxing yet attainable project. I‚Äôd also like to understand strategies for playing the game and what better way to evaluate strategies for games of chance than to have a simulator to play all those millions of games that you don‚Äôt have time to play?

I wanted to have some rudimentary code ready for this post but it is misbehaving at the moment. I hope that it will be ready for another post in the next few days. That at least gives me an opportunity to explain the game in some detail, in case you have never played it.

Carcassonne is a tile game in which the aim is to build roads, cities, cloisters and fields, with the aim of having the most points by the time all the tiles have been laid. These are made by deploying little figures (affectionately known as meeple) on to a tile as it is laid. The tiles are supplied in random order.

Note

Update April 2017: The original version of this post included a dummy playthrough of a Carcassonne game but there were several mistakes. I have plenty of notes for an additional post of this nature so more may appear on this topic at a later data, complete with a corrected playthrough.

entry.title: Understated Classics #20: Folklore by Nelly Furtado
entry.content:
It‚Äôs rather spooky but shortly after deciding to write about Nelly Furtado‚Äôs ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù as the next understated classic, I found out that she has a new album out this week. As a result, I have been listening to a lot of her music while writing this post, and I‚Äôve been enjoying it too.

As always with these choices of mine, ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù is a record that I can link to particular events and emotions in my life and so I guess my perception of it is coloured by that. Nevertheless while re-listening to the album I tried to examine whether my feelings for it were entirely centred on those memories and emotional responses. I think the answer is not a simple one, because in recent weeks I‚Äôve felt very unsettled in many aspects of my life and so I probably have found it difficult to tell.

I think that there are songs and ideas on this album that do stand the test of time, songs that we can go back to and say ‚Äúyes, these are really good‚Äù, even if none of them make it into the ‚ÄúThe Best Of Nelly Furtado Minimix‚Äù that can be found on spotify (as a mix, it‚Äôs hilariously bad):

The album starts with ‚ÄúOne Trick Pony‚Äù (‚Äúfor you I will not dance and for you I will not prance‚Äù) and despite protestations to the contrary, she picks up from where ‚ÄúWhoah Nelly‚Äù left off with a glossy pop song and a positive vibe. It‚Äôs all banjos and finger picking before her wonderful soaraway voice takes up the chorus. The lyrics are about being strong and unique, and yet it has the same wistfulness that permeates through the whole album, something that is no doubt carried over from her Portuguese heritage (I often wonder if my own lusophilia started here).

‚ÄúPowerless‚Äù picks up a similar mood and revisits that theme of identity and uniqueness from a different angle, namely the way that people are presented to the world in videos and magazines. If you think about how things like Facebook can make us feel like there is some great current to our lives that we have to go on with, this song explores the question of whether we should live the life that others expect of us, or do we live as we want to, as we feel we should. I can remember being galvanised many times by the line ‚Äúbecause this life is too short to live it just for you‚Äù, even when the person I was thinking about was very much someone that I did just to live my life solely for. It‚Äôs strange now because it is ‚Äújust a pop song‚Äù and I can sit there and think about how the banjo lines are almost the same as the previous track, but back then it seemed really important because it connected so well to the things that were preoccupying my thoughts.

I feel less of a connection to the next song ‚ÄúExplode‚Äù but not because it isn‚Äôt heartfelt or because it doesn‚Äôt stir me, it is probably the most intensely personal song on the album, even if the events related in it might be fictional. It‚Äôs a song that looks back on teenage life and how the importance of things that happened in the past seem to change over time (‚Äúmore than a battle scar / more than a battle scar / such a good good story to tell‚Äù). It helps that her pronunciation of ‚Äúexplode‚Äù makes that word sound like ‚Äúexplored‚Äù because that captures the duality of our teenage years very aptly, that simultaneous explosion into and exploration of the world around us. The ending (starting at ‚Äúwe‚Äôre counting the stars‚Äù) always gives me shivers.

The lead off single ‚ÄúTry‚Äù is probably the best song here, a love song about how perfection is not the most important thing in a relationship but that wanting the best for each other is. As a piece of pop ballad construction, it‚Äôs immaculate (complete with woozy ‚ÄúMezzanine‚Äù-esque scratching), and if that maelstrom of an ending (including the lines ‚ÄúAll of the things we want each other to be / We never will be / But that‚Äôs wonderful, that‚Äôs life‚Äù) doesn‚Äôt cut you up then maybe pop music isn‚Äôt really for you.

Another nice thing about Nelly‚Äôs albums is that she includes some tracks in Portuguese (albeit she sang in Spanish on ‚ÄúLoose‚Äù and there‚Äôs nothing like that on the new album, but a Portuguese language album is apparently in the works). The two tracks like that on ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù are ‚ÄúFresh Off The Boat‚Äù and ‚ÄúFor√ßa‚Äù. Admittedly the first song only has a few lines in Portuguese at the end of the track and the second song only has a verse or two in Portuguese. ‚ÄúFor√ßa‚Äù was the theme song to Euro 2004, which was held in Portugal, but as with all these songs the references to football are rather forced and the song is a bit dreary. ‚ÄúFresh Off The Boat‚Äù is at least an attempt to do something a little bit different and the attempt to address casual racism is a worthy one but apart from the sing-song lines in Portuguese, the elements don‚Äôt really stack up for me. (Perhaps I‚Äôm just being tetchy because I still can‚Äôt quite translate all of the lyrics, I should jfgi.)

The album is very much front-loaded (I tend to prefer albums this way) and so by halfway through the real peaks have passed. Nevertheless side two begins with three very decent tracks. ‚ÄúThe Grass Is Green‚Äù is a simple ballad and, given the title, you probably could have written the lyrics but the quality is all in the delivery. As always, it is that voice that strains and soars into the choruses from out of the verses. The same is true of ‚ÄúPicture Perfect‚Äù, like ‚ÄúExplode‚Äù it wears personal experiences on its sleeve but unlike most ballads it doesn‚Äôt descend into histrionics. There‚Äôs a real and convincing sense of sadness and regret throughout and the musical arrangement is tidy, pretty but not fussy.

More remarkable is ‚ÄúSaturdays‚Äù, which starts out as a sung poem backed up by acoustic guitar but later on a backing vocalist joins in and his enthusiasm threatens to overtake the whole song. At one point they start laughing and so you can tell that it is all done in one take. The lyrics are much darker and more mysterious than anything else on the album so although the zany one-take version is excellent, I can‚Äôt help but be curious about what it might have developed into if the recording on the album is, as I suspect, a demo.

The rest of the album does tail away quite rapidly. ‚ÄúBuild You Up‚Äù sits too close in the track list to ‚ÄúGrass Is Green‚Äù and ‚ÄúPicture Perfect‚Äù so it sounds a bit samey if you listen to the album in order, though it does stand out better on shuffle. ‚ÄúIsland Of Wonder‚Äù features legendary singer Caetano Veloso and has a smoky trip-hop vibe, which is nice but not particularly remarkable. ‚ÄúChildhood Dreams‚Äù is rather gloopy and overlong, doing badly everything that ‚ÄúPicture Perfect‚Äù does well.

Other albums

Thanks to Spotify I finally managed to listen to Nelly‚Äôs 2009 Spanish language album ‚ÄúMi Plan‚Äù and I really enjoyed it. It was much more like ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù than it‚Äôs scattershot follow up ‚ÄúLoose‚Äù. For me the standout tracks were ‚ÄúManos Al Aire‚Äù and ‚ÄúBaja Otra Luz‚Äù. I‚Äôd write a more detailed review but I only understood about 30% of the lyrics.

‚ÄúLoose‚Äù hasn‚Äôt got any better with age. It basically fuses two ideas, namely ‚ÄúI can write half decent songs‚Äù and ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go hip-hop!‚Äù, and then proceeds to cock up both. Nevertheless there‚Äôs still some good stuff: ‚ÄúAfraid‚Äù, ‚ÄúPromiscuous‚Äù, ‚ÄúIn God‚Äôs Hands‚Äù and ‚ÄúAll Good Things‚Äù.

I will write about the new album in the album digest at the end of the month. It‚Äôs more like ‚ÄúLoose‚Äù than ‚ÄúFolklore‚Äù but it is a bit more cohesive. More info to follow.

entry.title: Album Digest, August 2012
entry.content:
Album Digest August 2012 is also from the stack of albums that I mentioned last month. I chose this selection (along with the Passion Pit album) because the colours looked good together in the mosaic of covers that I make each month. Last month‚Äôs digest was about the right amount of detail so this will be another briefer digest. These are all good albums but not ones that will change your life, they‚Äôll just happily sit alongside it. They are:

  1. Laurel Halo Quarantine
  2. Grimes Visions
  3. Auntie Flo Future Rhythm Machine
  4. Passion Pit Gossamer

As usual, there‚Äôs a playlist at the end but this month it‚Äôs in Spotify as I wasn‚Äôt able to find any free MP3s of songs from the Passion Pit album. Note also that I write this post while deaf in one ear, so if my descriptions sound skewiff that might be why.

Laurel Halo ‚ÄúQuarantine‚Äù

I first listened to this album in June and to be totally honest, I was a little underwhelmed. I think I was too perturbed by the artwork featuring Japanese manga schoolgirls committing sepakku surrounded by rainbows. The interior is worse with cartoon guts unspooling everywhere: it makes me feel queasy. After a while I understood how well that queasiness sits with the sound of the album.

The songs on ‚ÄúQuarantine‚Äù explore how the cognitive dissonance of listening to songs that are simultaneously beautiful and ugly. At least that is how it seems the first few times. As I became more familiar with the album, the songs seemed to be either match-ups of either a pretty vocal combined with grizzly challenging backing, or a dissonant unappealing vocal paired with pretty blissed-out atmospherics. Towards the end of the album on ‚ÄúLight+Space‚Äù this formula changes and all the appealing elements appear together.

With repeated listens I found that many of the elements that I had dismissed as ugly (e.g. the vocal on ‚ÄúYears‚Äù) were actually complementing the prettier elements. I got more used to her voice and her sound the more I listened to the album. I began to really enjoy it. ‚ÄúThaw‚Äù, ‚ÄúMK Ultra‚Äù and the aforementioned ‚ÄúLight+Space‚Äù are my favourite tracks.

Grimes ‚ÄúVisions‚Äù

This is another album with a cover that might put you off. There‚Äôs an alien head and the track titles are all weird. It‚Äôs as though there is a deliberate attempt to mask just how fun this album is! It‚Äôs the poppiest album I have heard all year. It‚Äôs hard to believe that music this poppy isn‚Äôt being beamed into all the places where we could possibly hear music. It‚Äôs that good. For now though it isn‚Äôt and so Visions is still a private party inside my own head. I urge you to track down a copy and join in.

‚ÄúGenesis‚Äù, the first full length song on the album, has a riff that sounds a bit like Kraftwerk‚Äôs ‚ÄúTrans Europe Express‚Äù and a vocal that sounds like an Enya record back from 1991. You won‚Äôt believe this but Enya was pretty cool back in 1991. She made concept albums about Saturn‚Äôs rings. The Kraftwerk-Enya combo seems way too corny to work but it does. The words are completely indecipherable and yet ‚ÄúGenesis‚Äù is still a massive ear worm.

Not convinced? What about ‚ÄúVowels = Space and Time‚Äù, which sounds like the songs that Madonna was trying to make all those years when she tried to be cool? A sinuous vocal winds around a funky synth line and it just works. This is the sort of pop music the world needs but rarely gets.

My absolute favourite is ‚ÄúBe A Body‚Äù. I love the short and simple lyric (entire first verse: ‚ÄúI close my eyes until I see / I don‚Äôt need hands to touch me / Be a body‚Äù) but the best bit is the enormous beat that kicks in at 2:00. It‚Äôs a song that relies on repetition and layering and these are things that I respond well to.

Overall ‚ÄúVisions‚Äù is a fabulous maze of an album. It‚Äôs full of little of dead ends and intricate details, yet never forgets the sheer pleasure of pop vocals and chunky beats. Many albums these days are po-faced and overly serious but ‚ÄúVisions‚Äù is a welcome reminder that albums can still be fun.

Auntie Flo ‚ÄúFuture Rhythm Machine‚Äù

One joy of the CAN ‚ÄúLost Tapes‚Äù box set is a little track called E.F.S. 108. The acronym stands for ‚ÄúEthnological Forgery Series‚Äù, a knowing nod to the creation of exotic-sounding but nonetheless fake ‚Äòethnic‚Äô music for a western audience. Whether music constructed in this fashion is more or less authentic than music that appropriates existing recordings via sampling is a debate for another day. (One that will in fact be sparked by a forthcoming understated classic, believe it or not.)

Obviously I say all this because ‚ÄúFuture Rhythm Machine‚Äù also seems subject to this debate. The main features of the album are a set of world-straddling driving beats spannning the distance from London to Rio and then back over to Africa. I feel embarrassed that I don‚Äôt know more about afrobeat to be more precise with the geography. It also has a similarly diverse set of vocals. Exceptionally, it is also really concise despite its breadth of influences and underlying energy. I often write in these digests that I like an album that fits entirely in to my walk to work. The album is thirty five minutes long, a party that makes you happy and doesn‚Äôt over stay its welcome. Perfect for that walk to work.

It‚Äôs not all worldbeat. The last two tracks span a third of the album‚Äôs short running time and sound completely different to the rest. Both instrumentals and have a more experimental feel that tapers off the album in a satisfying fashion. ‚ÄúTrain‚Äù owes a debt to ‚ÄúDifferent Trains‚Äù by Steve Reich and ‚ÄúFuturismo‚Äù also has a minimalist vibe. The latter perhaps has too many layers and is too melodic to be confused with a Philip Glass piece, but it does have a very similar insistent pulse. I only mention the change in style because of the short length of the album. Did they run out of ideas? I hope not because I would like to hear more stuff by these guys.

Passion Pit ‚ÄúGossamer‚Äù

I keep deriding the maximalist sound of Rustie‚Äôs ‚ÄúGlass Swords‚Äù album but Passion Pit‚Äôs ‚ÄúGossamer‚Äù gives those same maximalist tendencies a run at the pop mainstream. I say mainstream but the peak UK chart position of ‚ÄúGossamer‚Äù was number 56. For an album of melodramatic pop songs that chart the fall of a relationship, the maximal approach works really well.

The opening track ‚ÄúTake A Walk‚Äù is a highlight, charting a whole life story in four and a half minutes. It tells a tale of an immigrant family who end up undone by their ambitions. I‚Äôve adopted it as the sound track to my summer because of my fondness for choruses with an ‚Äúoh oh oh‚Äù line. I have probably mentioned this fondness before. I really like ‚ÄúCarried Away‚Äù because its cheeky tale of postgraduate seduction reminds me of PhD days (albeit with rose tinted lenses).

Elsewhere, too much psychological damage is in evidence for the whole album to truly be a comfortable listen. Examples include lines like: ‚ÄúI drink a gin and take a couple of my pills‚Äù (‚ÄúI‚Äôll Be Alright‚Äù); ‚ÄúAnd now I‚Äôm drunker than before, they told me drinking doesn‚Äôt make me nice‚Äù (‚ÄúConstant Conversations‚Äù); ‚ÄúYes I drank all those drinks on my own / My life‚Äôs become some blurry little quest‚Äù (‚ÄúCry Like A Ghost‚Äù); and ‚ÄúSorry I couldn‚Äôt be there, I was tied to a rocking chair / I was beat down to a pulp rocking back and forth somewhere‚Äù (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Not My Fault I‚Äôm Happy‚Äù). I think albums which explore the break up of relationships are always going to be pretty raw for me and this one seems rawer than most.

Overall, ‚ÄúGossamer‚Äù is as a well-produced set of dark songs that glow in the shadows of uncomfortably colourful illuminations. I have a feeling that apart from ‚ÄúTake A Walk‚Äù I may have forgotten all about this album by this time next year. I hope not.

entry.title: Understated Classics #19: The Dreaming by Kate Bush
entry.content:
‚ÄúI see the people working and see it working for them.‚Äù (Sat In Your Lap)

The Dreaming by Kate Bush is a strange 1982 album that many believed had destroyed her career.
